content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is really an amazing game. For people who like RPG, Action, Adventure, and building cities, this game is for you. Just note that it is in Early Access right now so there will be quite a few bugs and uneeded features. But aside from all of that, It is really fun to build a town, gather resources, upgrade structures, Battle against lots and lots of great enemies. Now, of course there is one huge downside to this game. As your progress, and as you build a huge and incredible Town, It starts to get boring. All of your structures end up being completely upgraded, everything is complete, and your end up with nothing to do. The worlds that players spawn in are only so big. they should be bigger though. Bigger worlds for building on, More enemies to take out, Stronger enemies to brawl with, More harder assults on your village from enemies. Everything becomes a bit too easy as your town becomes stronger and stronger.So those are my thoughts on the game. There are many ups, and many downs. But the game is still in Early Access so I can't wait until it is finished. I hope everthing turns out amazing in the end!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a map maker, modder and big fan of user generated content, I am very optimistic about this game and what it can entail. Looking at my hours played, this should be no surprise. Although it does not directly support modding, creators can make whatever they want of the game, be it modifying the city building, or simply create a standard RPG with factions, dungeons, boss fights and loot - completely skipping the city building aspect of it. Endless hours of fun definitely awaits.However, if you are just a player, content will be rather limited. Seeing as the entire campaign is going to be made in the editor they are giving to players. Then obviously the content has taken a hit and only 8-10% of the campaign is done (still some good hours though). You can randomize your own maps, pop in a couple of enemies and have fun fighting with them, but for a tailor made experience, you might want to wait a couple more months, wait for the campaign to be nearer completion or the integration and implementation of steam workshop.However, as it has developed, I am quite confident that it will live up to whatever expectations you might have to a game of this genre. if you are or have a little map maker inside of you, or maybe you want to tell a funny story, buy ASAP and start creating. If you are a player looking for a finished product, either wait for completion or grab the game when it pops up on sale.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great overall building game with some cool ARPG elements like equipment management and unique heros. Graphics are nice for the look the game is going for and it runs smoothly. It's got a helpful tutorial that will walk you through setting up a small village and teach you all the controls. It's definately more of a building and town management game right as combat is sparse in sandbox mode. Only the combat I've seen is  the occational bear that wanders too close to my hunters and the rat men that were guarding the iron mine close to the starting point. I'm sure it picks as you progress, and the campaign has more fighting if that's what you want.My biggest complaint is villager management. It's easy enough to assign villagers to a role through the building recruitment dialog, but there's no way that I've seen to select them from the overhead view without just clicking straight on them. It's hard to tell who's who unless you've learned to recognize the outfits at a glance and equiping individual villagers is an outright pain in the you know what. The only way to assign villagers to combat is to box select them, which is not ideal as you may be sending poorly equiped villagers to die while your axe-weilding woodsmen and bow-sporting hunters carry on like nothing's wrong. I'd prefer to see a window with all your guys in it similar to what a lot of RTSs have or at least the ability to set groups that can be selected with a single button click. Again, though, it's in good shape for an Early Access game, and they update on a regular basis. If you like ARPGs and RTS games, I'd give it a shot.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm going to try and give a quick review. DISCLAIMER: I'll go ahead and point out that I only have about 10 hours played on this game, and this game is far from complete, but I believe Folk Tale has a chance at being something great.Note that this game's developement has been very long and slow. It's unfortunate, but with small developers taking on big tasks that happens. I've definitely gotten impatient with this game's progress at times, but the one factor that gives me the utmost faith in this game, and its developers, is consistency. They push out a stable build about every month or so, and it bring content and mechanics every time. This game is shaping up, and it is starting to look very good.Right now the story line isn't fleshed out very well, so you've got a little bit of a city builder going. But the thing I find most captivating is that it is some sort of RPG-RTS-City Builder-Simulator hybrid. All of your townsfolk can level up and equip armor and items, making every unit you have unique. Then you have hero units that you recruit as the game goes on. Each one has different abilities (like rogues, healers, warriors, etc). You can give them gear as well. It's just a really cool idea and is improving all the time. There are dungeons to explore, enemies that try to invade, and everything between. The game is also visually appealing to me. It's not cutting edge by any means, but the art has that World of Warcraft kind of charm to me. The price of this game is pretty steep considering how much content is missing. As it stands you can get about 15 or so hours out of the content before you're stuck trying to find things to do other than min-maxing your units and town. But I recommend it if you see it on sell or you're looking for a game like this to get behind. If you're not looking to buy, I at least recommend following the development of this game. When it is done it's going to be very good.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like RTS games, I can recommend Folk Tale. It's a bit of both Warcraft 3 and Settlers. Warcraft 3 because it contains an RPG element and you build structures to gain resources but Settlers, because there's a little bit micro-management with your buildings and villagers.I watch the GamesFoundry stream on twitch every Wednesday and through that, I know they are constantly updating the game to become better. They also listen to the community and make changes if necessary.Which was evident from the start when the game wouldn't let you train female villagers into certain working roles, but people complained so they fixed it.As of this date: Aug/2015, there is no victory point. Meaning  you will play a map and it will simply never end unless you did badly. However, that'll most likely change soon.If you like to craft your own maps and give them out to a community to play, the game got a powerful and simple editor for you to mess around with. Steam workshop will be available for the game soon to facilitate map making and sharing.Finally, I would like to list some of my pros and cons:Pros-Fun game play.-Great British humor (Think modern Monty Python).-Excellent map editor.-Developers heed feedback.-Beautiful music score.-Heroes and villagers can level up.-Love the loot system and that you can give new gear to your heroes and various professions.-You can research upgrades for your buildings.Cons:-No end goal to a map yet.-Voice acting is a bit wonky and can be repetitive and annoying.-Sound design and foley is less than adequate.-No guard tower unless you build a wall which can ruin your village layout.-No story in the game, however, I know it is coming.-Professions, like the baker, will get flour and return it to the bakery and it'll automatically generate the bread. You will never see him make the bread which makes me feel like he should just be a carrier instead of a fully dressed baker.-While crafting is nice, it is a micro-management that becomes tedious for a large village, as you have to hunt down the house that can craft the item. It would be much better with a crafting tab that contained all the recipes.-You cannot set what sort of crop you want to grow until the field is complete. While minor, if you are pulled away from your field before or as it's being built, you might forget to set it to grow cotton and later on wonder why you never get any cloth bolts made.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
Early Access Review
								I bought Folk Tale at Alpha 29. I found the RTS part completely unbalanced as both settlers and soldiers alike are pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥when it comes to fighting. Melee characters like spearmen or the allegedly superior town guard can't even beat a couple of rabbits of the same level (no kidding) without major losses, and large numbers of them make little difference as collision boxes prevent (which is good) swarming a single enemy. Although I suspect major modifications will occur when game goes Beta, for now I feel like the only viable option for armies is going ranged (and kite or use terrain like rivers or cliffs as walls - since walls are out in that build) or mix (and use the melee as blocker cannon fodder).Playing a couple of games in campaign and survival mode I found out that some attacks are scripted and come from spawn points (which may at some point be right in the middle of your town). Beside the awkwardness of having some wolves spawning in the middle of your settlers and considering how weak all of your troops (including heroes) are, carnages often occur. Of course with a high morale, the losses of civilians aren't that annoying if you have auto-recruit on on your building, but for the useless soldiers it leads to you micromanaging them (as there is currently neither a rally point feature on the barracks nor the auto feature do produce anything else than the basic spearmen which you have to retrain manually).I also found out that monsters level up based on a criteria which I haven't been able to identify yet, but that I suspect to be town military strenght capacity, which may lead to game breaking situations (if you evolved your town too quickly comparatively to the leveling up of your troops and heroes, every unit will end up being one shot by monsters and - considering also the XP penalty for death - will never get a chance to level up and compete ever again) where heroes don't stand a chance to beat dungeons and where you have to kill thousands of monster with a swarm of arbalist (the only viable option) to get a chance to level your soldiers up to be more competive in small numbers). So you may find yourself in the dire situation of a very steep increase of enemy level when uncovering the fog of war of a new enemy (i.e. a spider nest) or going into a dungeon. That is a bad - and hopefully very temporary - design choice as players who will focus on upgrading their town and defense over exploring and expanding may end up in a situation where any progress is made impossible.I was at first very disappointed not to find walls, towers or anything that could actually make me compensate the lack of individual efficiency of my military units by using a bit of strategy. Alpha 29 has no walls. After some research I found out they used to be, along with several towers and, well, a major bug which may explain why they have been removed. Well, walls are essential and the new engineering turrets, while a cool addition, aren't compensating the huge necessity of having walls in this game.I was suprised that, having had Folk Tale on my wishlist since about 3 years now, the very good looking game was still so lacking in terms of polishing of the game mechanics and content. In fact, there seems to be so much remaining to do that this game may remain in Alpha for a couple more years. I understand that the scope and ambition of the game are huge, mixing all those genre from RTS, city builder, TD, RPG, MOBA, and it remains extremely promising (although as to be expected with such a hotchpotch that actually none of each element has any depth in it - i.e. the economy, while having some illusory layers of complexity is absolutely unchallenging and is extremely linear as you will always build the same things in the same order starting with one or two food sources, clothes and then mead).Still Folk Tale may end up being an entertaining game with more than decent appearance and sound (the atmosphere of the game sadly is déjà vu and overexploited for medieval cartoonish games, but that may only annoys you provided you are a veteran gamer) if it ever get finished with its actual ambitions. Considering how slow the development process was till now (despite the fact I have to acknowledge that besides the obvious placeholders and temporary features, there is a lot of polish in that game) it would be hard to believe that the final product is going to become some kind of reference unless many many years of work (or an increase in this studio's output) are assigned to this project.In its current state and considering the history of the product, I can't heartily recommend it. Though as the steam review system do not allow me to publish a neutral review, I'd like to be clear that if you understood the ambitions of developers through my or others lucid reviewers comments, if you understood there is little chance that when it will finally be released the game won't achieve some legendary status in terms of depth, strategical options and challenge (despite your settlers dying like flies) and is very likely to just be a very polished jack-of-all-trades game then it may be worth supporting, provided you are patient, or buying on release.

								I bought Folk Tale a while ago and have not played much, about 6 hours. While the game still has a ways to go, I am confident that Games Foundry will produce a very good product. Why? Because they pump out regular updates, take the time to listen to their players, and use surveys to find out what their investors/players want! They are a very pro-active company and I enjoy the way they are approaching this project. Their player-relations are also very good. Multiple times I have asked questions on the forums and have recieved rather swift responses! The game is on the right track, even though it did have a bit of an early turn around from a story-based RPG to a sandbox based RPG, where I can understand some players argument that they are not recieving the game they invested their money into. However, they may provide feedback to help Games Foundry produce the best game possible, because this company does listen. The best indicator of that is the fact that they made such a great turn around.Another something that I like is that they have a roadmap on their site, detailing and outlining what they plan on making. It helps regular players like me understand what is to come and increases our faith in the company. So with that said, I will be giving Games Foundry and Folk Tale a big PLUS ONE. Can't wait for the next update and keep up the good work!P.S. Defenitly more than one hour of playable content. No idea why people keep saying there is only one hour!

								Whilst not entirely finished (as was expected with an early access game) I thoroughly enjoyed playing through what I have played so far.  The game has a uniquely quirky vibe to it and isn't afraid to poke a little fun at itself which I find refreshing.  I absolutely adore the art of this game, it reminds me of games like Fable, warcraft or torchlight but has a personality of its own as well. - Dec 2014UPDATED REVIEW BELOW - May 2015:Does this game have longevity potential to provide more than 8-12 hours of village builder gameplay?Currently I have over 28 hours played, 24 of those hours have been recent experience. I bought the game when it first hit early access and played the tutorial several times through. This game has come a long long way since then. It still has a ways to go, but the sandbox game has a lot of potential. The management of all the different buildings, villagers, resources, upgrades and trying to keep the villagers warm, fed, happy and healthy all serve to keep you on your toes while you expand your village and explore the surrounding landscape. This is a game that I don't tend to burn myself out on, It's a game that I keep coming back to whenever the GF guys add something new.With only 28 hours played you can't really call me a fan boy, that being said, I do enjoy this game and I expect to get another 100 hours or more out of it in the next year or more. It has great potential, it has great art design, great mechanics and a great feel to it. If there was a downside, I would say at the moment it is content. With only three or four maps currently available if you tend to burn through content you might run out quick. With all that being said, with 24 hours played on the new content I can honestly say that I still have a lot more time to give to this great title and I really look forward to seeing more from Games Foundry. http://www.gamesfoundry.com/gameguide/gettingstarted/Check out the gameguide if you are interested in the features currently available.

content:
Posted: April 7
Early Access Review
A Surprisingly Fun Hybrid of RTS and ARPGThough still a little rough around the edgesFolk Tale is a pretty funny game. That's probably a good way to start off describing it. It is a tongue-in-cheek parody of many of the city builder norms, with writing that often breaks the fourth wall with self awareness, constantly referencing the player as a God named Bob. I wasn't outright laughing at any of the humour, but none of it was lost on me either, and the humour was just another aspect of the game that gave it its overall charm.Speaking of presentation, the game looks really nice, with a cartoon-like middle earth setting. The character models and building models all look pretty decent, if not slightly dated. That being said, I was pleased by the overall aesthetic of the game, as it all just works together.There's quite a bit of voice acting in the game, and happily, it's done excellently, with a Monty Python's esque gritty English to it. None of it sounds amateur, which helps to build on the immersion and the humour of it all.If only performance were as good as presentationThis game is still in early access, and from what I can tell by the negative reviews, it's been in early access for a long time, much to the dismay of many negative review posters. I would say my biggest issue with the game is that there is slowdown over time. I have a village with 130 some odd villagers. All of them are rendered, walking around, and mixed with dozens, if not hundreds of wild animals and monsters constantly walking around the map. Over time, the game becomes more and more choppy, though I found saving, closing out the game, and reloading it made my FPS feel more solid. For the record, my computer is pretty mid-level, with a GTX 1070, 16 gigs of high performance ram, an i7 4770, and running the game from an SSD drive. I feel like my computer should be able to handle the game a bit better, but maybe performance optimizations will be the developer's last major step, who knows.On the bright side, the game didn't crash on me, in my 5 hours of straight playing, though, as mentioned above, slowdown became an issue. Ok, enough about that performance stuff, what about the gameplay?I haven't played the campaign mode, but I did play the tutorial first, then jumped right into the sandbox mode. I do like me some sandboxes, and this one didn't disappoint. Immediately, armed with the knowledge imparted on me by the tutorial, I set about making buildings, assigning villagers to jobs, and having my heros (you start with 2, and it stays that way, as far as I can tell) do some light scouting. I found myself quickly upgrading buildings, researching new technologies, and seeking out more resources to increase the speed of my resource gain. My only gripe with the map I was on was that there was only one iron mine. This meant that all my resources were gaining so fast, while my iron was a constant and annoying bottleneck.Still, that didn't change the fact that I completely enjoyed all building up my village and even bringing my heroes into two dungeons to experience the ARPG aspect of the game. Speaking of which, the ARPG aspect is pretty solid. You take your heroes into a dungeon, and you're suddenly in a new, smaller map, clearing the dungeon of monsters and reaping whatever rewards you loot from their corpses. It's not the best ARPG experience I've ever had, but it's certainly good enough to make me glad it's in the game.So, would I recommend the game to others?I suppose that depends on how "finished" you expect the game to be. I had quite a lot of fun with it for those 5 hours I played it. In fact, the time went by so quickly, I suddenly realized I was not going to have much time to sleep before work. I don't experience that very often, as I usually have a VERY hard time getting into a game. If you're ok with the price for what you get now, a very solid city builder, I would say go for it. If you want the fasted development on the planet, you might want to wait. As I mentioned above, there is a pretty solid negative review userbase that almost entirely laments how long the game has been in early access. For me, I already feel like it gave me the emotional videogame joy that I wanted out of it, and as I said before, that is not an easy thing for me to achieve anymore.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This review will attempt to insight you, dear reader, about what isn't already obvious to you.Folk Tale is a fantasy city builder with dungeoneering RPG elements. There's loot and you get to assign it! Also it has a fantastic art style. At the bottom of this review you can find info on the games that inspired Folk Tale.The game is dedicated to being a sandbox & having a fleshed-out campaign. All of these facts give it very big boots to fill. The Good Lots of genuine potential. Everybody here gains exp & levels up! Woo! It's tackling a niche, if you're reading this chances are you feel drawn to something refreshing yet familiar Atmosphere is well crafted - both auditory and visually the game is beautiful. Build your town and raise your heroes & soldiers to glory, equipping them for scaling threats. Veterans of gaming, the developers have a clear vision but listen to the community Tools used to make the game are given to players, you get the same resources as the devs The modding community here could explode - parallels between WC3 and FT start to show :) Crafting Randomly generated items = this is not yet implemented!The Bad The game is Early Access, and it aims to be delivered by the end of 2016. And although I personally feel confident in the project, we all know of hiccups that can happen. There are a lot more features destined to be released soon, but it can be disappointing not knowing exactly what the full game will contain. The goods are a plus, the lack of clarity a minus.There's a lot of things on the plate right now, which means features get released but not everything already out is polished, you can really get frustrated at that - for example the UI needs some  updates. At the moment (and I will strive to keep the review up-to-date) there's not many hours of content to enjoy. Because the game has changed direction the updates seem patchy and can really be frustrating at timesThe VerdictOverall is it worth INVESTING in? Absolutely!As a game however - right now - you have to be willing to have patience. It's not complete and although fun, is brief.Hope that helps!-----------------------------------------Similarities-----------------------------------------The following titles I will try to arrange in order of how much inspiration they've served to Games Foundry:WarCraft IIIBanishedMore action orientated games (like DotA)

Early Access Review
								This game has it in it to be a great city building, town similation game.But it's a bit more than that. Like any city building game you build things like farms and butchers and make little production chains to keep your people happy, and watch them in their day to day lives. thats the City building and town sides of it. But what really makes it shine is the way you start to really get attached to your people. Each charecter can be equipped and taken on missions so you start to feel as though you have helped each one grow, and will probably get favourites and the ones you don't like so much and this brings your little town to life. There is also a pretty cool editor which lets you make your own map and therefore your own folk tale story.This is an EDITED review, my last one complained about the Devs never releasing updates nor keeping us informed for a long stretch of time but I have to say this has been sorted to I am now recommending this game!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale, the Fantasy/SRPG.Now Ive had this game since literally the first day its been on Steam. The game is by GamesFoundry, a great group of guys who are trying to make this unique game come to life more and more with every update. Although my hours logged arnt that much compared to the others here I have played all through the maps and am currently playing with the map editor, so this gives me a refined base for the game.Lets start shall we?Graphics:The graphics are like that of the Overlord game series, but with less doom and gloom. The etxtures are simply wonderful, even close up you can notice small details in the armor of your population, the riffits on the buildings, the notches in the shields and so much more. While the graphics arnt on a serious manner, it gives the game a serious cartoonish feel to it without being on the Borderlands cartoonish side. I would  give the graphics an 8/10.Audio:The games audio is beautiful as it has multiple sound tracks and a bit more short bits of music for special events. This makes the game feel alot more adventurous and a bit more mysterious.Aside from the music of the game there is also the ambiance to the game. You can hear the frogs croak in the swamps, the wind howling in the tundras, and the trees swooshing in the grasslands. If you zoom to street level in your town you can hear people talking, music playing in the tavern, bees buzzing in the bee hives ect. It really brings the game to life and I hope they expand on this.I would give audio a 9/10Gameplay:In the gameplay aspect of this game it gets a bit odd but fun. The basics of the game are like any other, build your base/village, keep your people fed and happy, defend yourself, profit. While its very copy and paste in other games its very unique in this one. During the missions in the game while you build your village up there are creatures which come for your villagers heads during any point in the game. It may be goblins, toadkin, or spiders (The spiders are 1337). If you manager to survive the onslaught to get enough city guards and crossbowmen then youre set pretty much, as long as you use them wisely. A unique thing the guys at GamesFoundry are working on is a Faction system, much like in World of Warcraft, or ArchAge once you build enough reputation with 1/2 factions on the map they reward you. You may pick a hero from each faction that youre high up in while the other faction tends to hate you more and more, like your ex. But unlike your ex you can actually kill the faction that doesnt like you, or the one you dont like. Another cool feature is the items in the game are used on the models in game. An example is the city guard, just a man with a helmet, padded dress armor, and a pike. You can give the guard a bigger pike and the model changes, an axe and it changes, ect. Same with armor, although not all models work for changing pretty much all of them do. Of course there are restrictions such as guards cant use bows and crossbowmen cant use flaming swords, its still a unique feature that focuses on detail and I love it.GamesFoundry also said they are working on a massive amount of content for the game as well, hopefully sometime in the coming months the content will be finished for the many items they are adding and I can make another eview on more aspects of the game.I would give gameplay a 9/10If you guys enjoyed this review I would check the game out! Watch the videos here or on YouTube, read the forums, or if I compelled you enough get the game?  The game is updated very frequently as well, so thats always a plus to have the creators improving their work often.Comments, questions, concerns? There are forums on 'Should you buy Folk Tale?' as well as the 'FAQ' forum for anything you could ask. Hope to see you in the community :)

content:
Posted: October 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								THIS REVIEW IS FOR SANBOX MODE: I haven't spent much time in campaign.I don't usually review games as I feel that, unlike most other entertainment mediums, video games are grossly personal experiences.  However, I would like to say that I strongly recommend this game to anyone interested in city building and management type games.  The interface and controls are very intuitive once you learn the basics, yet still give you plenty of flexibility later in the game.  And, in my opinion, later in the game is where things get fun.  Starting new villasges on the other maps while your first village continues runnung is a fun challenge.  I also really enjoyed the RPG aspects such as clearing zones and leveling your hero/heroes, training up your troops and doing the basic quests, as well as looking for the other heroes.Again, I know games are very subjective in nature, however when a game is done right, I beleive the developers should be recognized for their work.  This early access game is on par, or better, than many of the "full release" games I've purchased.  If you are looking for a very scripted, linear experience, this game probaly isn't for you.  But, if you like crafting your own experience in a well made sandbox, I belive you will find this game very enjoyable.Sorry for long winded review, just felt that this developer deserved a thumbs up from a long time gamer, I'm an old man compared to most of you, lol.  Thanks for reading and hope you enjoy this game as much as I continue to do.

Early Access Review
								This is marked as an alpha release I know that it is not intended to be a finished product but it is effectively unplayable.  It's more like a custom warcraft III map that nobody got around to finishing.  I spent several hours building a village with upgraded versions of all of the production buildings.  Eventually at a population of around 100 sickness will begin spreading and you will run out of medicine no matter what you do.  Your villagers will never be happy.  I made a fully upgraded monastary and tavern right next to eachother with a well and several beehives.  the monks stock piled thousands of honeycombs and produced mead far too slowly for my village even with 15 monks working and all research completed.  Don't try to make doubles of any of your production structures either if you do your villagers will inevitably be to far from a needed resource.  Villagers need to be in the area of a resources building to pick it up and if heir cottage is too far from say, the tailor's place they will be low on clothes even if the tailor has a stockpile

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								so Ive decided to change my review having messed around with the game. My old review was pretty annoyed at the fact that it was sold to me as a campaign based builder, and went sandbox. But that was a long time ago, so I decided to base my current review on what the game is now.My main issue now is theyve had *how* long to work on it and the game is still in E.A.? This game was one of the first announced E.A. games, and it was the first E.A. game I bought. That was in....oh....2013, summer I think?Thats a bit ridiculous. E.A. is not supposed to be for building a game from the ground up, as in "Hey, I got this great idea for a game...". Go to Kickstarter for that. This is supposed to be for near functional betas, that need a year or so of tweaking at the most. At least it does appear to be continuously worked on, which is nice.But enough of that. For what is there, the game is good if you like sandbox style city builders. Its just glaringly incomplete. Like even the tips on load screens have placeholders because they havent been implemented. And the game hung at least 3 times on load, seems really unoptimized. Theres a decent amount to do, but its hard to get into when theres so much obviously missingGraphics are excellent, think cartoony "Banished". The UI is very easy to use as well.This isnt a negative review so much as a withholding judgement to see what happens, but since Steam doesnt have that option I decided to write this review with a positive.Right now it has the framework of what could be an awesome sandbox builder. Kind of like when you send your guys to go build something and it slowly rises out of the ground. THe game's like that 3/4 built structure right now.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated Review:I bought into the early access for Folk Tale a year ago and I have never regretted my purchase.   Prior to buying in, I haunted their Steam forum for a few weeks prior, mainly due to the negative reviews on their store page, and the entire time I was impressed by how interactive and helpful the GF devs were on a daily basis.  There was a lot of animosity being leveled at them at the time because they did something virtually unheard of in game development and that was change direction based on the feedback they received from their fanbase prior to being Greenlit.  Whether or not one agrees with their decision, it's an admirable move because so much more often gamers are not listened to and their opinions fall on deaf ears.So here we are, a year later and even though Folk Tale is just a couple patches away from 0.3.0 (that's my estimate and I could be wrong), and that's the version the devs themselves caution those who want a playable experience to wait for, I am even more reassured than I was a year ago because I've seen first hand how accomadating and unfailingly interactive the GF devs are on a daily basis and I've been watching the weekly dev hangouts each Sunday since they first started and each week, I'm amazed at what they accomplish from one week to the next. Without a doubt, the GF devs are passionate about their game and it shows.  If you have even the slightest misgivings about this early access or just early access in general,  take a peek at the Sunday dev hangouts on twitch and keep tabs on it.  These guys go out of their way to make sure we know exactly what's going on in development.  How many other early access developers do the same?

number of helpful: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bernard, who had been recently recruited into the town militia, grabbed a shiny new helm and leather boots, before embarking on an adventure to reclaim some kind of artifact from a monastery filled with monk werewolves.  With one swing of his mighty halberd, Bernard barely scratched the first werewolf he encountered and was killed.  While short lived, Bernard rose from the ranks of nothingness to being a great knight and protector of his people.  Truthfully, he wasn’t so great, but nonetheless, he climbed from being a simple peasant to someone with tremendous potential, even though he never realized it.Much like Bernard, Folk Tale is a game with tremendous potential as it moves forward.  Before I continue, I want to remind everyone that this is an early access game.  Numerous features and concepts have not been implemented, bugs can pop-up anywhere, and the game is far from being completed.  It can be frustrating to see an icon that has no function or to open a building detail page only to notice several upgrades are listed, but none function.  If you are not prepared or have no desire and patience for an incomplete game, do not get this game.  Unless you would like to help fund the project, then by all means, purchase this game.   With that being said, Folk Tale is still an enjoyable experience if a fantasy city builder, with role-playing and questing elements is something that peaks your interest.  As of the current build, gameplay options include a campaign style tutorial, sandbox mode, and game editing.  The tutorial introduces the basics of building, economy and combat.  It is here that the RPG and questing elements are located.  The sandbox mode is what one would expect in that it provides total freedom to build your town without constraints or objectives.  This is the perfect testing ground to further learn the game and explore some of the currently available features Folk Tale has to offer.  And if neither the campaign inspired tutorial nor sandbox mode interests you, fire up the game editor and create your own content.While diverse gameplay modes and editors are great, it’s the core content that drives games into being worthwhile endeavors and consumers of our precious time.  Here is where Folk Tale has set itself up to shine.  From the moment you begin playing the game, the charming, fairy-tale inspired art direction and vibrant color palette catch and hold your attention.  The landscape and buildings come alive through color, detail and lighting (there is even day and night cycles).  The level of detail, whether it be a flower covered rolling hill, a waterfall fed stream with a pedestrian bridge, a newly constructed building or even a simple peasant, is visual treat.  While exploring the land, small, satisfying details are reviled, such enterable buildings that are alive with people and props, which make you want to continue on and see what else is down the road.  The sound is also on par with the great visuals.  The town is alive with the sounds of foot-steps, birds chirping, flowing water, wind and much more.  Once zoomed in close, brief conversations and dialogue from different peasants can be over-heard, much of it quite humorous.  The soundtrack playing in the background also does an excellent job of drawing you into the Folk Tale world with its whimsical melodies.Nice visuals and sounds alone are not enough to push a game into the realm of worthiness.  For that, there must be great gameplay mechanics and features.  With the present build, Folk Tale is just barely achieving that level.  Presently, a variety of buildings can be constructed and the basic economy system is up and running.  For example, you can build a mill and farms to harvest wheat, which in turn is taken to the stock pile to be stored and later collected by the baker so toast can be produced.  This system of intermingling buildings to produce a usable product is well received.  It’s no so overly complicated that excessive micro-managing of every aspect of life is required, but there is enough to keep you busy and engaged.  However, many other buildings and features, such as upgrades and research, have not been implemented in the current build, but the blueprint is there.  This can be frustrating at times, but as I said before, the game is still being developed and being able to see what is down the road is promising.One of the most promising and intriguing features are the RPG elements.  Going back to Bernard, I was pleasantly surprised when I selected him and noticed he was a named character.  In looking around the town, I noticed everyone, from the baker to the woodcutter to the barmaid, had a name.  While some where recycled, they each had a name nonetheless.  Beyond that, the foundation for character leveling, special abilities and inventory management was present too.  The farmers leveled up the more the fields were worked, the militia men leveled up after defeating enemies, and so it was for the rest of the working town folks.  Individual character Inventories could be accessed, which allowed for items, such as better armor or weapons, to be provided.  This in turn raised stats such as strength and armor, among other things.  And each different character, depending on their present occupation, had special abilities that could be activated.  For example, the town priest could heal units or pacify enemy units after activating some of his abilities.  Frustrating, many of these features are present, but not implemented into the current game build.  But knowing these will someday be implemented provides tremendous promise and intrigue.All in all, Folk Tale is a visually appealing game with massive potential.  It could become one of those rare games which successfully fuses different aspects of some of the most beloved game types into one cohesive unit all while still being unique.  However, time will tell as development is 45% complete at the present time.  Concerning whether or not you should buy this game, I’d say it depends to your level of patience with early access games and your interest level in city building, light PRG, and strategy gaming.  If you can deal with this game being a work-in-progress and have an interest in this style of game, then I’d say it’s a definite purchase.  For being incomplete and sometimes frustrating do to non-implemented features in the current build, I can honestly say I have enjoyed my time and can’t what to explore the finished world of Folk Tale.

number of helpful: 87 of 171 people (51%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale is a game that had the potential to be one of the best city builders ever. The art was a fresh detour from the norm, and the RPG aspect gave the game a more active feel. It is because of these specific things and all the pontential that I'm sad to say: this game has no direction. When is say that, I don't mean it has no direction in the sense that it lacks an attainable goal, nor do I mean that it is akin to Minecraft--the game that made directionless fun popular; Folk Tale is somewhere between what the devs said they were doing, and what a niche in the community wanted. This game doesn't deliver an immersive city building experience--in a fantasy setting, because of an impotent AI that doesn't work half the time; however, Folk Tale also doesn't deliver on its adopted promise to be a great sandbox game, because it has a particular fantasy, RPG/RTS feel to it that requires a strong, immersive base to stand alone in the sandbox enviroment. Even when you ignore the broken AI, odd development choices, and lack of clear direction, Folk Tale still suffers from a start/stop update cycle that adds incomplete, often empty features; during my time in Folk Tale it was common for me to come across a menu option, or tab and be met with "not avalible in this version of Folk Tale." The worst instance of this came when I attempted to change the scroll speed in-game; I quickly discovered that the control menu didn't exist, but the menu tab for controls was present. All things considered, I can ignore the fact that this game isn't what I originally paid for, that it still isn't even close to being a true playable beta, or even that many pieces of the current build are either broken/barely working. The reason I can't reccomend this game is because the developers lied; the developers lied--and continue to lie--because they refuse to admit that they've messed up. The developers pretend  that everything is as it should be, and that the game is progressing steadily; the truth is that this game will likely never be released, and if it is will likely be riddled with bugs and unfinished content. Today I gave this game a final chance to impress me after waiting almost a full year for it to be developed more. Today I finally let go of any final hope that Folk Tale will be anything to me, but another reason I don't trust or wish to support indie developers.In my humble opinion I would not reccomend purchasing this game, even once released--if it ever is--I would strongly advise anyone to steer clear of it.Do not waste your money.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I been wanting to try this game for a while but never thought about buying it until yesterday, since it went on sale and I was all hooray its on sale I can finally test it out.1. Tutorial map is easy and you get the hang of the game if you start on that map first, not like me who was all ooh okay load this easy one and try to figure out how to play.2. Village pictures are all bald men even for the women when clicked on Oo3. Rotation is pretty slow and clunky it takes foreeeeeeever just to turn the map around in order to see a different angle.4. Micromanagement is not fun. I do not want to keep lashing or rewarding my workers to keep productivity up, though I do like the research idea that increases productivity. Get rid of the Lash and Reward, keep the research.5. No matter how many taverns I put out to give villagers fun, there never seems to be enough fun and they all end up leaving the village cos it sucks. I even had all the research done on the taverns and that did nothing to help the situation at all.6. Sometimes it crashes.7. The storage house has research but sadly you can't do any of it, the same goes for the barracks you can't do any of the research on that either.Edit:After the responses from the Developers some time ago I have continued to play Folk Tale, and in addition I have also put out videos on youtube of me going over some of the points and gameplay. I can only say this game continues to improve despite slow progress, so far I've been doing the experimental builds and honestly like how things are going so far.Games Foundry also watch my videos for any points that I make, and have often left me tips and hings in the comment section to help me on my way. Which I can only say this is pretty top notch of them, so in this regard I will continue to play and video Folk Tale with each new update and review the changes. I have changed my recommendation from No to Yes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I been wanting to try this game for a while but never thought about buying it until yesterday, since it went on sale and I was all hooray its on sale I can finally test it out.1. Tutorial map is easy and you get the hang of the game if you start on that map first, not like me who was all ooh okay load this easy one and try to figure out how to play.2. Village pictures are all bald men even for the women when clicked on Oo3. Rotation is pretty slow and clunky it takes foreeeeeeever just to turn the map around in order to see a different angle.4. Micromanagement is not fun. I do not want to keep lashing or rewarding my workers to keep productivity up, though I do like the research idea that increases productivity. Get rid of the Lash and Reward, keep the research.5. No matter how many taverns I put out to give villagers fun, there never seems to be enough fun and they all end up leaving the village cos it sucks. I even had all the research done on the taverns and that did nothing to help the situation at all.6. Sometimes it crashes.7. The storage house has research but sadly you can't do any of it, the same goes for the barracks you can't do any of the research on that either.Edit:After the responses from the Developers some time ago I have continued to play Folk Tale, and in addition I have also put out videos on youtube of me going over some of the points and gameplay. I can only say this game continues to improve despite slow progress, so far I've been doing the experimental builds and honestly like how things are going so far.Games Foundry also watch my videos for any points that I make, and have often left me tips and hings in the comment section to help me on my way. Which I can only say this is pretty top notch of them, so in this regard I will continue to play and video Folk Tale with each new update and review the changes. I have changed my recommendation from No to Yes.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was pretty harsh on this review when I first purchased the EA title... about 2 years ago.  I'll leave my old review up so you can see why this game has so many "mixed" reviews.  In that review, I was a bit upset because I hadn't seen any real progress towards the game and had just played the tutorial.  I recently gave it another go, based off of the devs suggestion that it has in fact changed and there was a lot more content. So far, I'm having a lot of fun with it.  It reminds me a lot of "Banished" but I feel I'll get more than the 40 hours game time I put into that game because it has some RTS elements in it as well.  I've only just begun playing the story mode, so I'll post yet another review when I'm finished with that.  Kudos to the devs for reaching out and suggesting there is more content.I will change this review when the final game comes out... or IF the final game ever comes out.  It shows plenty of potential... however the devs are extremely slow to release updates and it hasn't really had anything more than a few empty promises and a quick little tech demo.  Please do not purchase this early access title, as it is more of a farse to the whole Early Access system and a scam than it is a game in development.I challenge the devs to prove me wrong and finally release something... anything... that shows what they are doing with the $$$.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's beautiful. It's a city-builder RPG that plays like an RTS. It's Folk Tale.For a company with only 9 developers, only one of them being a programmer, this is amazing. It takes a long time for this game to develop, but it is already looking nicely. Artstyle is glorious, and the idea is great. They are focusing on gameplay now, and they are adding several gameplay enhancements and mechanics.The game still has a long way to from the time of writing this, january 2015, but I believe that they will get there and this will become an awesome game.Be sure to be watching the developer streams on wednesday (previously on sunday), to pick up the latest development progress and ask questions to the developers.Edit: To anyone wondering if you can save in sandbox, the answer is YES, via console. Look for the console guide on their website. It might say that it doesn't fully work, but it does work. In fact, right now, it's almost bug-free.

Early Access Review
								As of August 8th, 2016, the game is enjoyable and playable. I used to not recommend this game, but I have changed my mind. When the project lead asked to contact me it made me realize that he actually gives a ♥♥♥♥ about what people think. That being said, he's not asking for money. He's not asking me to suck his♥♥♥♥♥♥like EA or Activision. He's not throwing me off out onto the street like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. That's respect. So I've changed my mind. PROS: +Great atmosphere+Nice voice acting+Awesome loot system (Every peasant in the game has their own inventory)+Wonderful build mechanics+Unlimited building +It's great to know that every villager has their own jobCONS:-I'm not a fan of map editor so that being said, more maps would be great.

Early Access Review
								Folk Tale, in 3 points, is a great game, has extreme potential, and still has a ways to go. These developers (though a small team) are truly dedicated to this game, they will not give up, and have plenty of great ideas for both short and long-term growth. This is a large world, and the options are continuously growing!More buildings, units, races, quests and adventure are to come, and this team is pouring in the hours. If you want a game that is good from the start, but will grow with you, adding more content down the road for constant exploration- becoming great- this is it.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Where are the RPG elements?.. let alone "fully explorable building/dungeon interiors and an adventure-focused RPG component"?..Right now this seems to be just a city builder with an overly elaborate food system (several different types of food that give you satistfaction bonuses if you present a diverse, with different options for how to provide them, but apparently you should totally build out all of them and use them all because the tutorial said so.but! there *is* (in some configurations) this totally separate hero dude whom you can make walk around and kill things when you are bored of waiting for villagers to do stuff. And he gains levels for killing stuff! and then you can choose to assign a skill point! SO that's an RPG element I guess?.. until he inevitably dies from clunky controls (and OP poison) and you discover that you can also send hordes of villagers to do the same thing if you really want.Meanwhile for a resource management game, it does not give me nearly enough tools or information to 'debug' my resource flows. Made me appreciate Prison Architect that much more for its great tools for both micromanagement (e.g. following a prisoner/set of prisoners around and actually being able to discern bottlenecks) and macro summaries.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok, so my first review was on Feb 11, 2015. It was for a very different game from the one that currently exists. That game was essentially a tutorial that wasn't complete and couldn't be saved. And it got a negative review from me because of these things, and because of changes made that seemed to confuse the game's center. Now, however, the game is much more filled-out. I will note that this game is a LOT like The Settlers, most specifically the single Settlers game I've actually played through (6, Rise of an Empire). Not exactly a clone of the game, but definitly in the same general region of Sandbox-Campaign gaming. It's worth a play, even if it's far from complete at this time.0) Overall - 7/10 - Campaign is small but has a lot of potential if they can expand it across multiple maps and over about 12 more hours worth of space. Sandbox is fun, needs bigger maps. Combat is poor, but workable. City Building has some issues, but is overall a very fun and functional aspect of the game.1) Campaign - 5/10 - The Campaign certaintly shows promise. As of right now it's fairly short and seems to just be a number of placeholder missions to keep the Dev Team aware of what the campagn is meant to be. So while it has a decent overall plotline the campaign is short, fairly flimsy overall, and doesn't give you the impact needed for a solid game campaign. Hopefully this will be expanded as the game continues.2) Sandbox - 7/10 - I've just started playing the Sandbox mode, and so far I'm enjoying it. I won't lie and say it's perfect (it's not lol) but it is fairly fun and I do enjoy building cities and the like. They need to add some more features (roads would be nice, as would more types and teir of building) but for the most part the sandbox has no issues. [This is Subject to Change as I play through the 3 Sandbox Maps]3) Factions - 7/10 - The factions are rather unimaginative overall. Undead v Fae Folk. On the surface it's pretty bland, but if you look a little deeper you'll find that it actually has some decent points for both sides being in a Gray&Grey morality. Needs work on that aspect though - Greed v Self Defense doesn't leave much space for Gray&Grey. It would also be nice if there was a third factions (besides your own) that was fully neutral and could be interacted with. Finally, being able to create peace between the two factions would also be a nice touch.4) Combat - 4/10 - Combat is... not very pleasant to be honest. Heroes are hard to level up past a certai point, but by that same token there isn't any cost of losig a hero (or units in general for that matter). Training them doesn't have an expense, and you don't lose items when your units die in battle. If every time a hero died they lost off of their gear it would be decidedly more difficult and much more important to keep the hero alive. By that same token, if City Watch units died and lost items it would make people more careful about losing them. If that was the only issue it would be fine, however the inability for heroes to self-activate their special moves is rather annoying and leads to more deaths than is really needed. Maybe I'm just not good enough xD5) City Building - 8/10 - City building is fun. As a city builder this definitly ranks with some of the other games I've played. However, it is not without it's (rather large) assortment of flaws and weak points. The biggest of those is the complete lack of roads. Without placable roads that buildings lock to (which was/is my favorite feature in The Settlers games) city planning is a haphazard thing at best. With proper roads and road-locking players could build cities with a lot more planning and functionality than we currenty can. Another issue I have is the space needed between buildings. Granted, the games I usually play that are like this (TheSettlers & Banished) allow buildings that are rammed right up to each other and both have a well-designed road mechanic, but still. There shouldn't need to be enough space between two buildings to cram an entirely different building.6) World Map - ?/10 - This feature is only partially implemented, but oh boy do I like the look of it! If the world map does what I expect it to do, it'll enable more kinds of city, larger and smaller map sizes, and a dozen other cool features. I really hope that it means we will get to see a campaign that's spread across multiple maps with different types of landscapes and creatures to fight, trade, and otherwise interact with.7) Custom - ?/10 - Haven't tried this yet, it's on my list.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to preface this with the game is very much an early access game, so unless you really want to support the devs I DO NOT SUGGEST BUYING IT YET.This is a very promising game in a lot of ways. When I first played it I thought "yes, I can get behind this easily, so long as they fix the massive lack of features and bugs."I'm rewriting my review to better reflect the game. Its an awesome experience, and the devs are on top of things for the most part. The releases seem rather slow in a lot of ways, or so I felt at first. Theirs a lot of key features that seem absent (managing your units is an awful time, saving has to be done through the console, etc). In reality, they are trying to flesh out the sandbox aspect, and in turn a lot of the basic things fall behind. The little things that make it easy to pick up and play (no descriptions for buildings, no explanations of why someone cant equip an item, etc). If you read a lot of the posts they are focusing on fleshing out the actual game, which from what I can tell plays pretty good. Just don't expect to jump right in and know whats going on, and spend a lot of time micromanaging and finding your villagers (which is the most frustrating part)

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								To whom this may concern,I've decided to redo this review, a third time. This time, not because anybody asked, but because I felt the game deserved one for shot. So, here I go.The game is fun, it will hold your attention, and it has DEFINENTLY improved over time. This is, after all, early access. But of course, it has its flaws. I thought this game to be a waste at first, of money and time. But, maybe I was just tough on it. I found the game to be easy, but then again, maybe I'm just good. Folk Tale had a certain charm to it. But, this didnt mean it was perfect. I had trouble with alot of the controls, and the tutorial helped a little, but I was still confused. Now, after playing a while longer, I created my game. I had fun, for awhile atleast. Handled the placement bugs, the bears, yada yada yada. But, eventually, sooner than expected, I hit the point where the game is complete. I've done everything, only too easy. At this point, I stopped and, said "Ok, that was fun for awhile". Deciding that I didnt wish to continue playing. Maybe I just dont like the game, not my cup of tea. I would recommend to get this game, on sale, or to get it and, make sure you decide wether you like it or not before you've gone past the TIME OF NO RETURN (2 hours). But if you like Town building, or are able to just connect with your characters, I think you'll like it.If I could tell the dev team anything, I'd tell them to continue working hard. To keep adding and, adding. A few bug fixes, and some updates, and this game will certainly be great. Sincerly,Mastersimoligy

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great potential but still has issues.  Reminds me of warcraft 3 - my favorite game.Issue #1 ... I have to buy shirts from market because I can't build the necessary buildings. Took me a 2 games to figure this out because everyone eventually left the village which is frustrating.Issue #2 ... The campaign got stuck when I went to talk to Nara. It created a permanant Willow character stuck at the throne room and an additional one that became playable.  I could get the antidote for the quest but when I returned nothing happened and the stuck Willow was still there with "talk to Nara and return to Nara" both remained unable to be checked off. Issue #4 ... If a non hero character dies any inventory dies with them.Issue #5 ... Many of the buildings and upgrades are not supported yet which makes balancing economy and defence semi difficult. Issue #6 ... If you craft weapons at the blacksmith for a proffession (in my case woodcutter) you are unable to unstack them. - I created 8 axes for 2 different camps (4 woodcutters each) and was forced to drop all 8 in the camp inventory. Additionally once an item is placed in a building inventory - it is unable to be removed while in use even if only 1 item on a multiple item stack is being used.Issue #7 ... The carrots harvest value is too low.  I had 6 fields of carrots with 50 population and couldn't keep carrots in inventory.Issue #8 ... Berries stop being able to be harvested as soon as you build any other type of food harvest building.Issue #9 ... I wiped out the camp of Tauren type creatures but they would randomly spawn an attack - either have them respawn in the camp so you can guage when an attack will come or eiliminate them once they are gone.Issue #10 ... Better defined use of gems, rings, charms etc... I can equip them but there is no indication of what they do. Same for many lootable items... spider webs etc .Issue #11 ... I chose to leave the goblin in the cage in Kenny's hideout but then it was permanantly there... possibly an option to come back and release him later. All in all a good game and I understand it's still somewhat in development. Hope this helps!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game when it was in early access a long time ago and when the game was headed in a different direction, so the current incarnation isn't what I thought the game was going to be. That being said, I am happy with the direction it has gone in, and even though it is currently incomplete, it's still a pretty fun game.I've spent pretty much all my time playing the campaign and sandbox modes, so I haven't given the map editor a whirl yet. This game's primary focus is on village building, but all your villagers can be equipped with gear and called upon to fight, and everybody levels up. You can create soldiers and arbalists as your primary fighting force, and there are unique characters with special powers, abilities and gear. While there are plenty of enemies on the maps to make conquering it challenging, they do leave you alone for a short while so you can establish your defenses enough.The level of involvement is great and I can't wait to see what else they add to the game. Building placement is extremely flexible, only preventing you from placing them on top of other buildings or in rivers, on cliffs, etc, so you can plan it out pretty much however you want. Even in Alphas, the game is pretty stable and I have only experienced one or two crashes. Controls and UI are pretty easy to pick up, for it being such an involved game.My only possible complaint would be about the combat. It's cool fighting with the unique characters, since they have some special abilities, but at the moment, NPC AI is pretty bad. If there are enemies close enough, your villagers will attack automatically, so long as you don't click anything. Several times my melee fighters have let my ranged attackers get slaughtered, while they were moving from one mob to another, so you kind of need to direct them to each mob you want dead. It'd be great if there was an option to have them protect ranged units. These devs are pretty active and seem dedicated, so I don't doubt they'll be making improvements for a while now.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wrote a review for this game back on April 2 and at the time I did not recommend this game.  It was not due b/c of poor content or lack of updates, but I felt the game had not been developed enough.  To me, it seemed that Folk Tale was missing some basic features.  Now that I am playing it again a month later; I want to update this review.  In the April review I listed a few concerns/issues that I had.  There were:1) Lack of right clicking the screen to move the map.  2) Main resources not on the main screen.  I would have to go into menu system to view this important information.  3) Easily calling soldiers to the fight. Here is my update, plus a few things for a wish list.  1)  Even though the devs never put in a right click and hold feature to move the map quickly like in most RTS games, they did implement a "shift" function.  You still move the map with WASD keys normally.  To traverse the map more quickly, you still use the WASD keys but also hold shift.  At 1st I didn't know if I would like this, but I will say that this works pretty well.  I have been told in the next few patches they are going to refine this feature further to give the player more control.  (Will be able to adjust speed of the camera, etc.) 2) They fixed this.  The important rescores (wood, stone, iron, food) are all on the main screen, plus more.  3) This one is kind of sort of on me.  The game has yet to have a patrol function or a QRF button (quick reaction force, military term)  but you can group your soldiers to a number key and call them into battle that way.  One thing I did notice in my earlier review; you could only have 4 soldiers at a time.  At the time the game did not have an upgrade feature for the barracks.  As of now, it does and you can recruit more soldiers through upgrading the barracks.  The devs have really been listening to the community and this is a huge plus!  In fact, after I wrote my 1st review, I was contacted by them and they talked to me about my concerns.  Amazing!! For that and all the said updates, I am now "recommending" this game!  However, do realize that it is still in early access and it has been for a while and probably will stay that way till roughly early 2016 (per game page on steam).  Do not think that this is finished project.  It is not, and the devs would agree.  However, it is still a fun game.  Visually and audibly, the game has really set the bar in this type of genera.   I look forward to future updates and Dev Hangouts on Twitch.  Wish List:  I will update as more ideas and thoughts come to me.  Roads:  It would cool to be able to build roads in the game.  It seems like on the map there are lanterns and wall around that look like they should be on a road.  Or as you build buildings close to each other, maybe a road will automatically appear.  Peasants:  I am not sure if there is quicker way or not.  But having a feature where you can quickly find peasants.  I always seem to have to look around my town to locate them, when I want to manually task them.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								While I do recommend the game for what it is trying to acheive, in it's genre; I was somewhat dissapointed by it.The game is fun, don't get me wrong, but it is nothing NEW. A lot of reviewers say it's a blend of a city builder, RTS, crafting game, etc... well, simply put, it is not a blend, it is just a plain old RTS game that has been done many times before since the days of Warcraft 2. The city builder part is a complete joke. And while, yes, you do need to build it, there is no micro managing, or strategic placements and very light balancing; Basically just plop what you need to unlock, or sustain the resources that your villagers demand. I think my biggest gripe with the game had to be that each building has it's own upgrades. These upgrades seem very unique, with there own images (icons), and a breif description of what it does to the building. But in the end, all they do is produce a little more of the item you are making - nothing about what it really describes is unique. After this you realize the game is very simple.It a very appealing game, pretty graphics, gameplay flows nicely, and is fun if; you're young, or someone new to RTS games all together. But if you are looking for something that is truely something new that contains city building and some strategic gameplay, unfortunately you won't find it here.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'll give Folk Tale a recommend.I bought it during the 2016 summer sale, it's in a very playable state and gave me a few hours worth of fun I don't regret - for that - recommend. Below, rant.The campaign was an alright 3 hour of slow action.The campaign was a mixed experience, it has positives- good story, jokes, voice acting, and negatives- pointless running between the same locations, no challenge, the fact that the city building didn't play a role in the whole affair.The sandbox  is not a challenge, there are only 3 maps, and I'm afraid the difficulty instead of giving you more enemies is dictated by constraining your building space. Too much. It sort of fails as a city builder. And on any map, the special resources and random rocks are everywhere, it's difficult to build especially large buildings like the barracks. You don't decide where to build the barracks, you wave the mouse around the screen until you see green, then plop it right there. I wish there were waves of attackers (and not a spider every 5 minutes), perhaps raid sort of dungeons and all you could go to and run over and over for loot, with the heroes AND city watch or whoever you want to bring along (looking at you, campaign!). That'd improve the RPG aspect and give some replayability. There isn't much replayability, I built a city in the sandbox now, all the buildings are up, all enemies killed. The only joy is that one village of enemies is respawning, but they're oh so weak and don't move... I guess I'm done with the game. Hoped for a city builder to really get my teeth into.

Early Access Review
								The game has alot of ambition and promise. The environment really stands out with its vibrant colours and very neat graphics and fluid animation. I kept a eye on this for a while since it first came to be 'Early Access' but never purchased it until recently from seeing people play it on Twitch. The detail the the characters are beautiful, especially when you play it on a laptop that isnt even meant for gaming. But it runs like a charm and even on low settings the game looks just as beautiful. Just to point out I am VERY fussy when it comes to games but this one definitely deserves positive feedback and a like +1. I havent been playing it for to long but I keep finding myself coming back to it and to tell you the truth I havent had this much fun since Stonghold 2 and The Settlers series. I really can't wait to be able to play the game once finished and fully updated. Speaking of updates they are really regular and the development team are doing a great job!. It is alot to ask for and it makes me seem ungreatful, but seriously on a level, I very much appreciate all the time and effort the team has put into this and I am one happy customer!. -Feedback-There is one thing I would love to see happen though, this being, more Hero characters in one town, maybe add a inn where you can choose to hire a hero or two from a range of 10-20 characters or even be able to fully customize the looks of the Heros. :) Keep up the impressive work guys! This game is a Gem!

								Both the sandbox and campaign games are fun. I've played a good few hours. The gameplay action is easy and seamless, whilst the depth and resource balancing make it fun to play. content:

								The mixed reviews this game has gotten are a little unfair. The reason it is like this is because development is slow, they have a small team. Don't buy this game if you want a complete and finished product, don't buy any early access games if that is what you are looking for. That said the game is starting to get in great shape, but there is still a lot to be added. I recommend looking at their main page and roadmap for the game. They have massive plans for Folk Tale that will ensure a distinct and enjoyable game for those interested in sandbox rpg's, city building and hero development. The transparency with the development team is one of the best I have encountered, and they really are creating a quality game.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game takes a piece from many genres, RTS, RPG and Open-world. You have your peasants as your basic unit which you then promote or demote as needed to keep your city going. They can focus on gathering resources, resource processing, and combat. As it stands now the project has basic gameplay available - no resource processing yet but the buildings and roles are there just no logic behind them./workhat onAs an IT scrummaster, for a team this size working 2 years on this game it looks great. Some may complain about the lack of content up to this point but you need remember that first they need to build the world and they made some changes based on community feedback which causes rework of many of the upstream tasks, thus changing their plan. The more that support their development by purchasing the Early Access to allow them to increase team size, even with the time needed to onboard the new people it would increase their velocity.  They want their game released as bad as the rest of us but I'd rather them take a page from Blizzard's book and release it when it's done that EA that patches it when it's released. Great job guys./workhat offI've bought numerous early access games and this is by far one of my favorites. I'm looking forward to the continued progress and watching as the game fills in it's already beautiful world with both life and death.
