content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've only played sandbox.---- Immersion ----The game has some funny voice acting and generally very high quality artwork.  The UI looks nice.  The tone and artwork of the game remind me of Torchlight.  The voice acting was clearly done with as few voice actors as possible, some parts obviously the same person's voice - but they are really nice to listen to.  I would say this becomes a major contributor to making the game enjoyable.The maps seem to all be static (i.e. there's currently no map generator).---- City Building ----Growing population goes slowly, to make sure balance is maintained and people don't get upset and leave.  If they do get unhappy, a downward spiral can happen as resources are no longer available and more people become unhappy.  There is an initial learning curve for getting up to maybe 30 people (that felt like an accomplishment), and growth needs to be methodical and calculated to ensure stability.  Because of this balancing act, the city can also be vulnerable to the unhappiness spiral if there are attacks to key systems.Also if the downwards spiral leads to a ghost town (everyone has left) there's currently no mechanism allowing people to come back and starting over.Each building has a tech tree which pushes the anticipated game time out into relatively longish games.---- RPG hack and slash ----The connection between the hero and the town is that an army can eventually join the hero in fighting otherwise impossible opponents.  Weapons and armor can also be built in town.  This becomes a high motivation for enlarging the town, and creates the "play a little longer" syndrome which makes this game hard to stop playing.Each hero has special moves that burn "special move burning delay thing" (oh maybe it's called mana or stamina or a combo of the two: stamana... :)  lol  :)  I didn't bother reading the game manual.---- Customization ----Oh...  I almost forgot about this!  Modding capability in this game is through the roof, as they provide a full visual node-based programming system to control enemy or camera behaviors for generating cut-scenes and drama.  In fact, when I first installed the game I went straight to __the edittor__ of all things!  I was so excited to want to look at the system right away!Please look at the FAQ threads pinned at the top of the discussions for videos showing what it can do.  This means there will undoubtedly be continuous content being created by the community of players, and more than makes up for the lack of random map generator.---- Grinding ----For RPGs my favorite element is storytelling.  But you may want to cover your ears, as what I will say is not so nice - but after years and years of reading or hearing typical fiction, I don't much care for most pre-written fiction, including fantasy, and especially including canned RPG adventures.  There comes a point where it all seems so arbitrary and whimsical at the author's imagination.  The only storytelling so far in RPGs I've enjoyed are in <a different game> which is also a roguelike, and shows up in my list of games, and has the word waz in it...  But the stories in Folk Tale won't be generated at run-time randomly -- they will be the canned type, and that makes the game feel a bit grindy after a while.  I can already anticipate getting tired of it.---- Putin Jokes ----This always makes me a bit nervous.  Then again I am paranoid.  Then again, paranoid might have good reasons.  Nonetheless, it makes me a bit nervous.  But Gamesfoundry is based in England, so maybe there's nothing to worry about:  http://www.gamesfoundry.com/about/developer/---- Overall -----I found this on sale at a token discount, and checked Steam price charts at some other website which showed the game's price doesn't move much.  It's a fair price, especially considering the long games and the modding capabilities, and if you really love RPGs, this might be just right for you too.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm really enjoying this game. I noticed it ages ago, so when it went on sale a few days ago, I took the plunge despite the mixed reviews. I'm glad I did. I can see Folk Tale becoming one of my all-time favorites. I've played city builders since early Caesar, and plenty of RPGs. The art is cute and really crisp. I love the look of my village, and the various looks of the upgraded buildings (only gotten to level 2 so far, though). I feel like I've barely scratched the surface, and am looking forward to getting into the RPG aspects more.I know it's not finished, but I have my own list of things I would love to see improved sooner rather than later:-- Labor management needs fine-tuning. There needs to be an easy way to list all the villagers, and see who is working where, so you can spread out the workforce the way you want it when there's a population downturn. Plus, It's virtually impossible to find your peasant. Yes, you can click on any building an see him or her on the left, as the lone unemployed person, but the Find button doesn't work for this person. Also, who is living in which houses? (Less critical, but could be fun.)-- The odd language choices confuse me. Yes, "on nom nom" is a cutesy way of saying "eat", but it looks like gibberish on the screen. Worse is "very work, much happy" which appears under every character's mini portrait in the building menu. Very weird -- it made me think the game was being made by non-English speakers, but the studio is based in London. King's English, people! Another suggestion: lose the "some" in the activity status -- because "retrieving some bolt of cotton" is grammatically incorrect and bugs.-- The buttons around an individual's portrait are confusing. What is the brain-like thing that has a dotted green line around it? I didn't see it mentioned in the Tutorial. Add the job title to these mini portraits -- they now appear only if you click on an individual's inventory. That's really tedious. I want to click on a person and see their job title immediately. -- It would be nice to be able to cycle through your citizens so you could quickly put extra armor and whatnot on them. Also, I'm tired of seeing the same guy's face, even for the women. He's not even cute.-- When a villager is sick, a green cloud appears around him or her, but there's nothing in their personal information that says they're infected (or what with, which would be a nice detail).-- Any chance of a time fast forward? That green expansion bar moves really slowly, even after you've corrected an error. It takes a long time for the changes to take effect. This is normal for city-building games, but most of those have pauses and fast fowards.-- I can't figure out a good way to use my troops. There's no real patrol function, since they don't respond to attacks unless you tell them to. I tried posting them on the borders -- that helped some, but they still seem pretty ineffective. Also, it's not clear (to me yet) how you can have both melee and rangers in the same barracks. Seems to be an either/or? I admit I haven't fully researched this -- I hope a future Tutorial will delve into town defense.-- I found some villagers doing tasks unrelated to their jobs? (Like harvesting carrots when they're a fisherman.) Is this intended?-- The resources totals at the top don't seem to go past 1000 -- even the town gold. I know I had more than 1000 coins, I just collected more taxes, but the number never changed. I'm not sure if I got credit for the money or not. I assume it's a bug and not a real cap. For another resource, iron bars, the inventory pane showed more than 1000, but the top bar didn't.-- After playing for awhile, and using the inventory, items show up as white boxes.-- What does the woodcutter do once all the trees are cut down? Supposedly I got some tree seeds, but I have no idea how to use them.-- I wish there were scenarios, ones that gradually increase in difficulty, like in Tropico or Caesar IV. And more building options (as in variety of buildings).I'm very excited by all the possibilities with this game. I hope it all comes to pass -- the city-building genre needs some great new titles.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
 It's everything you could have asked for from a city builder strategy AND simulation game!     As a huge fan of both RTS and simulation games, city builders have always captured my attention. I've played Cities:Skylines, Age of Empires series and Sim City. Some are focused on battles and conquering the opponents, whereas some are purely simulation games to the point you feel like you are sitting and thinking in your ivory tower. However, Folk Tale makes you a part of the city you are building for.PROS:+ Your citizens' happiness and needs are not just there to be taken care of. You have to act carefully, make sure they keep a balanced diet, have clothes, and of course, have a job! Your citizens are not just workers like many other RTS games, they go through a lot of hardships of a training to become a lumberjack, baker or miner. And no, you can't demand a baker to chop some woods. Please don't force them to do stuff they don't want to, it'll break their heart.+ Micromanagement is almost absent from the game so far. Not sure how that would turn out in advanced levels.You don't have to click on hundreds of people give each of them a specific task, but you can still do it if you want to.+ Economy and needs are the strategical part, yet the action never goes down. It doesn't necessarily mean there are non stop conflicts and battles, they might be. But even there isn't a single soldier on the horizon, just managing and bettering your city is enough to keep you interested. I never liked turn-based games like Civilization, so if you are like me on this matter, the chances are you are going to like the experience.CONS (and missing features): Since it's still in early access, I'd assume they'd add them sooner or later, and so far the improvement is promising. - Being unable to add people to the selecting. For example, you would expect CTRL+left click to add other units to the current selection of units. Tried other combinations, but haven't found one.- Being unable to select all units that are the same in an area. Double clicking on a lumberjack will not give you all the lumberjack or workers ready to your command.- Personally, I wished for a bit better textured and meshed graphics, the only thing that's not appealing at first glance is the looks. The more you progress your city the better it looks, but the graphics could have been better to get that "I did this!" feeling. To be more precise, the issue is about the grass while the buildings and characters have much better looks compared to pixelated look on the ground. Also, it's hard to see at night, maybe we could get an option for that or even torches and lanterns or something.- There's no achievements or trading cards yet. I'm eagerly waiting for them!- You can't drag the windows within the game. Sometimes resulting in not seeing what you are looting.Updated the review after a couple more sessions.

								This game has truly come a long way since it first launched and since I first bought it. I know this is going to be an excellent game when it is done. It had gone from a test of the game engine basically up to the status it is now which is much more immersive. Fans of city builders and rpg adventure would do well to buy this game and join in influencing how you want to see the game develop. You can even create your own maps. When this game is completed you are going to be kicking yourself and wondering why you didn't get it for that cheaper price earlier on. Sure plenty of people have been burned with games that were early access and never saw completion, however, this Dev team is dedicated to what they are doing and come out with regular updates and fixes to the existing game. (Written around alpha 16) Keep in mind that it is still in Early Access. So if you are looking for a lot of playability immediatley, you won't get that right now. But a lot of recent updates to the game are culminating into what will be a large increase in playability and content. I am truly more excited for this game then any Triple A title or any other game for that matter. (Alpha 22.3) (0.3.2.3)

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has a lot of potential in the way of sorytelling, visual theme, and developer interaction. Unfortunately, it is still very far from obtaining the gem they wish to create, and could possibly take too long. From what I've gathered, the focus of the game is currently being shifted toward a less scripted sandbox mechanic as proposed by overwhelming popular majority(I think). Also, the amount of features required to give this game any replayability is quite daunting for a team of this size, and as a result they will be facing a very long roadmap. In any case, I always have support for dedicated developers, and I hope they will continue to hold costumer feedback in the highest regards. For these reasons I have personally invested in their vision, and will be an active contributor if development continues. I would expect others to understand that you will not be paying for a very long period of play, but it could possibly become an engaging and extensive game in a couple painstaking years. If you don't want to throw money at the situation like i have, then at least keep an eye on it for a sale of some kind, or an update that really seals this economy pinch they're in. -Thanks for reading!

content:

Early Access Review
								If you enjoy sandbox style games then this is showing promise.The resource gathering, harvesting and building is presented very well. With the cartoonish graphics, audio and weather / atmospheric effects adding to the game play. (Which was the main reason for my purchase).  More has been promised (see further posts).---- original review ----Game has completely changed direction from what was first offered.  Purchased years ago on early access for a promise of a fun and interesting story.  This has now been totally removed and the game changed into 100% sandbox.  Its now a micro management nightmare, with a clunky GUI and a slow camera.After 2 years in early access there seemingly no end in sight with no clear vision from the developers.----

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale is a village management game which combines a sandbox “Stronghold” style settlement management system with a story driven scenario manager. The game is in early access. The basic settlement management system works now and there is 5 maps to play on. Pros- It's beautiful graphics create a lovely atmosphere- It's  fun to play now. I have had about 18 hours of play out of Alpha 20. Alpha 21 came out yesterday (roughly a month after alpha 20) so I will see how play I can get from that.- It has some intriguing build tools for making both maps and scenarios. - Being part of the development process itself is quite fun. Games Foundry goes out of its way to keep the community informed about progress.- The village mechanics with tiered buildings, villager experience, a village tech tree are great (although still in the process of being adding to and balanced).- The concept is a good one, and basic way it is being implemented is far sighted. They have designed mechanics for village simulation, character progression,  and story mode. They have made editors to create maps and scenarios. They reworked their game concept to based on a sandbox simulation (which I get the feeling was not the original plan) and did this successfully. They have been doing this for 2 years and just keep at it… this game will be finished and be an impressive beast at the end.Cons- The game has been developed in full view on early access for most of its life. This gives the impression of a "slow" development pace. If this bothers you then hang onto your money for now...- It's still unfinished - More summary information is needed on the village simulation side to make the user experience less cumbersome. Sometimes is hard to keep track of all the things that are going on (alpha 20).- Combat control also is a bit hit and miss at this stage (alpha 20).In conclusion, if you like the idea of early access games, enjoy being included in the development progress and are patient enough to wait around for 2-3 years for a finished product to appear then I strongly recommend this game. I liked this game enough to buy an extra copy from my wife... I notice she has already run up 4 hours on it in the first evening...

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								At the current stage the game is fun to play.It is a mix of city builder with RPG elements.There is one fundamentally nice thing - in other games as Your population grows, their deamands also grow and if suddenly You run out of certain supplies - You have the game end because everyone leaves or dies.Here it is a bit more balanced - You will be noticed about lacking resources but Your village will not die out - the happiness and some other attributes will degrade, but You still have a chance to recover.I really like this aproach.There are rough edges and bugs, but nothing game breaking.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I just bought the game on May 5th, 2015 so I have not played a lot yet. I will update when I put more time in, but so far I enjoy the game. Lets keep in mind I bought it even though there are mixed reviews. It is an early access game that has been early access for a long time, but so are many other games I currently play. To me that isn't a deal breaker so long as there have been updates made.----------------------------------------------------It reminds me of Banished, but adds another layer to your townspeople that was lacking. I like that I can research new armor to equip onto each person and learn new ways to make my farming or mining more successful. It feels like I have many more options to customize my town how I want. Plus there is even combat and looting!I was confused at first how I was supposed to find anyone in my town when I needed lets say my Hunter. Reading reviews this was a major concern to others as well. After a little while I did figure out a simple way in locating anyone that is assigned to a building. Just go to that building and it will list your workers with a little button that selects them. Not the easiest way ever. This isn't something pointed out to you in the tutorial either, so I am guessing there is plenty more that I will have to discover for myself.Even still I like the look of the game and the music as well. The voices used are pretty solid, but don't vary a ton.I am looking forward to future updates and playing the game more myself to get a better feel for it!

content:

Early Access Review
								This is one of the few games in greenlight that I have purchased that actually works, to a degreen and is well made enough to have the smoothest voice bloke doing the tutorial.I will say there are a few things I enjoyed:1. the style - visually impressive and not bad when zoomed in all the way2. the resource tree - great idea of having ANN0 styled production trees3. variety of enemies and the the variet eney types and models.4. building placement - Love it that you can place structures anywhere, no grid or snap mechanics that constrict creativity.I will say here that there are areas that need improving1. speed upa nd slow down functinallity2. larger maps with more resources3. items in the inventory showing up as white boxes4. the storehouse not having employees and also would be a great place to hire dedicated item trasporting workers like the teamsters office in Tropico5. group wide item distribution or customer templates for civs to have put on them6. more in depth city building and customisation - only scratching the surfice, you could have guilds, temples, grand halls more item manufacturing for later in the game with specifi reasources.These are all just suggenstions as the game is only in early access but thought I'd throw my thoughts in.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								A neat game that takes city building ideas in a new direction, by adding RPG qualities. You can build and equip weapons and armours to help your citizens in battles. I'm very interested to see how this game will evolve.There are a few issues right now. My main problem is that there isn't enough information to view in the game: like what villagers are doing what. It becomes a little difficult to manage as population increases: I might want to grab a random villeger, and have them do something, but it's pretty difficult to find out what job that villegar was doing to reassign them back to. Similarly, I equipped some armour onto a few villegars, and it was just sort of "well, good luck, guys!" Because, as far I can tell, there's no way to ever find those villegars again, other to randomly click on every individual person in the town to see what they're wearing. I hope to see more ways to view information in this game, because the new concepts here are neat; but as the town grows, the game becomes a little unweildly. Quite a fun game though.

content:

Early Access Review
								I have fallen in love with this game. I have only recently bought it for myself, but I have already been asking friends to try as well. It is so vibrant and full of potential! From the beginning of the game it has a sense of humor, and slightly reminds of Fable somehow. The city building aspect of the game is hands on, and you really need to keep an eye on everything, while trying to defend your city. The Heroes and Soldiers you can train can be customized, while only a few cosmetic things change, their stats can be boosted which really REALLY helps. I could go on for ages about all these amazing features, but to sum it up. If you are interested, it is an amazing game and I cannot wait for the final product. I tip my hat to the Games Foundry. Amazing work guys!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								A neat game that takes city building ideas in a new direction, by adding RPG qualities. You can build and equip weapons and armours to help your citizens in battles. I'm very interested to see how this game will evolve.There are a few issues right now. My main problem is that there isn't enough information to view in the game: like what villagers are doing what. It becomes a little difficult to manage as population increases: I might want to grab a random villeger, and have them do something, but it's pretty difficult to find out what job that villegar was doing to reassign them back to. Similarly, I equipped some armour onto a few villegars, and it was just sort of "well, good luck, guys!" Because, as far I can tell, there's no way to ever find those villegars again, other to randomly click on every individual person in the town to see what they're wearing. I hope to see more ways to view information in this game, because the new concepts here are neat; but as the town grows, the game becomes a little unweildly. Quite a fun game though.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								After playing a bit, my reaction goes like this:At first, I was WTF!  I had a lot of trouble figuring out some of the most basic concepts - like how to get more people in my town.  And once I figured the basics out, I was WTF!   Spiders.And so I decided to give it another go with my new information, I was WTF! This level was a cakewalk once I killed some random guy and picked up his uberOP weapon which allowed my character to pretty much singlehandedly kill everything else on the map.And then I was... WTF! Because I couldn't tell if there was more to do on the map or not - I had uncovered all of the fog of war and killed everything that I could.a. Starting resources should include some food.  Get rid of some of that stone and just start with 100 each of wood, stone, ore, carrots, bread, and fish.   b. Add some kind of patrol command for the various troops.  c. My town is being attacked? Great!  How about telling me where?   All of that said, the only real "complaint" I have is that the camera feels very sluggish when being moved.  All of my other comments were either documentation or balance issues because it's early access.    I definitely want to see the game developed further and would like for it to one day have a fully fleshed out campaign.

								I got this game back when it first was released as an early access and I will admit that the progress has been very slow and I stopped playing it for a while. I came back and so many things were different but the way it has gone has been a major improvement to what it was before. If they released the early access where the game is now they would not have so much of a mixed review.  Well now into the pros and cons:Pros - Not every faction is an enemy - Easy construction system - Make your own maps - The appearanceCons - No tutorial (they used to have one for the old system) - Little confusing to get startedSuggestions - A random map generator would be amazing for it - A better way for villagers to come (something like a birth system)I am looking forward to see how this game develops over time because it has so much potential I just wish they would make it a little bit faster.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								The Concept is a lot like Empire.  You build using settlers and huts to increase settlers.  I like the medieval twist using Kobalds and quests (Though I have yet to be able to do any quests.)  graphics are pretty cool, nothing great. Some big issues thus far though. 1:  The adviser who says you need more bread or meat or whatever, never stops once it starts and repeats every second.  There needs to be a way to turn that off.  2: You need to VASTLY improve the skill levels to match each accordingly.  Right now even on training level it is nearly impossible to learn or improve your village.  That's ridiculous.  Training level shouldn't need advisors beyond that of the actual training and frankly shouldn't have any worries at all as training level should strictly be a learning level ONLY..  You should be able to build anything and you should never lose settlers.  The next level, the beginners equivelent should only be slightly harder, needing a timy bit of food and maybe losing settlers only after having no food for like 30 minutes or something.  Then tweak the higher levels accordingly.    3:  When you send a Villager to do something they dance around at the spot for a few minutes before doing anything, wasting valuable time you have to gather resources and build things.  Overall the concept is pretty cool and has the potential to be a pretty decent hit but much work needed yet before it's really playable for any length of time.

								I haven't played much prior to the current patch 0.3.0.0 because I was have graphic issues. That seems to have been resolved. number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Imagine if Banished and Warcraft 3 had a love child, it was so beautiful and they both swore to love and take care of it. Then they took one look at it, threw up all over the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, andsent it to The Wall, to serve out the rest of its digusting, crap life, plagued by the "free-folk," White Walkers, and the knowledge that they will never have hair as great as Jon Snow.I have rarely ever given a game a thumbs down. I usually find some sort of saving grace in a game. I purchased this quite some time ago, I attempted to play it and the tutorial was so dry and uninspiring so I gave up on it. Fast-forward a few months later I really get the urge to play this game. I re-install it, and decide to opt out of the tutorial and dive into the game. It's good at being simple enough to not need to really look at instructions or a guide/tutorial. However the game is borderline TOO SIMPLISTIC. Half the items you click on say: "THIS HAS NOT BEEN IMPLEMENTED YET." The other half, that do work are filled with so many bugs that you want to cry.There are barely any sound or visual cues, the game doesn't do a good job in telling you when your town is under attack, there is one sound cue "YOUR BASE IS UNDER ATTACK." However it only happens after somebody pretty much already dies. Visually many of the creatures are so tiny that even when you watch your town, you have not a clue that there's a god damn spider killing people.My Windmill was glitched out the♥♥♥♥♥ It rendered 3 townsmen as "ghosts," as in they were there, not clickable, but weren't farming. The tier 1/3 walls make no sense, there's no cost on them, yet they do take resources and I calculated how much it would be for the wall, but when I built one section it refused to let me build any other walls on the entire map. I tried everything to fix this. This game may have potential, if it were 2008. The whole concept seemed cool, but the developer's take on it is so dated. To re-address my previous point, they combined two great games. The RPG elements of Warcraft 3, and the town building experience of Banished, but they somehow managed to only take the awful parts of both games, making this probably the worst experience I've ever had playing a "city builder." This game is quite awful. I have not met a single person that played this game and actually enjoyed it. Yes, I know what you're thinking I only have 1hour on this game. I usually hold judgement of a game until I either beat story mode, or have at least 10 hours in the game. This is a very huge exception just because I am uninstalling and never playing this horrid game again.Overall I would give this game a 3/10. This is the lowest I have EVER given ANY game. All in all they tried something out, they had a great concept that was butchered with awful interactions. Your "main character" in the game, the dude that explores and beats people is underpowered, he comes with a healer who sometimes refuses to leave him, and other times runs around the other side of the map because I guess they stopped liking each other. Half the buildings make no sense, some don't even work properly (the bakery), yet you are told your villagers DEMAND it. This game is just so incomplete, broken, and left such a sour taste in my mouth, I cannot justify it getting a better review from me in this lifetime unless they fix all the bugs and make it playable. Even then I don't think they would get anything more than a "meh" from me.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Clearly I haven't played this game a ton, but I would like to share my very initial impressions of this game before I come back later on to write a more cohesive and holistic review.First, I'd like to say that I've always loved sandbox games. As a fairly creative person, I'm able to enjoy them for hours on end without losing stamina. If sandbox games aren't for you, you might not want to play the game in its current state. That said, the minimal amount of time I've spent in-game has been positively GREAT. You know that feeling you get when a game just... gets you? That's the feeling I get with this game. There's a certain nostalgia that comes with quaint village sims like this, and I for one am a huge fan.I'm gonna stop here, since I can't really justify much more of a review on 0.4 hours of play time, but I will say that if you're a fantasy-head, enjoy RTS games, and prefer a somewhat relaxed if strategically oriented playstyle, you will enjoy this game.EDIT AFTER A COUPLE MORE HOURS OF GAME PLAY --As I suspected, additional play time has presented a few caveats you might like to know about before you purchase the early access version of this game. The game runs well, and has enough depth to allow the user to explore with a decently sized military regiment if they expand their land enough, but the game is INCREDIBLY unstructured after the tutorial. Eventually you get into a rythm where you don't really //need// to expand, all of your resources are generating at a solid enough rate, your villagers have access to medicine, clothing, food entertainment, and life is peachy. You've positioned guards around the town so that rogue spiders really aren't an issue, and the game just gets... quiet. Sure, you can opt to venture forth with your armed militia, but this provides little more than additional resources, and on rare occasion an item or two that might make ONE (not all) of your militia men a little bit stronger. I'll reiterate that this game is great. It has a great vision, shows promise, and is fun to play, but I do agree with others when they say that the game needs more direction. Like I said, it's all too easy to fall into a position where there's absolutely no tangible reason to expand.

								I haven't played much prior to the current patch 0.3.0.0 because I was have graphic issues. That seems to have been resolved. 								Picked it up on a sale. Love the idea. Thus far I played through the tutorial map. I like where its headed, very much.  Worth the current price, probably worth full price. I'll update my review after more play.EDIT:Played most of the morning. I see great potential here. Currently it really needs some interfaces for things like:Idle citizenCycle through your populationAssign default gear for a professionA market cart that can be moved or multiples of to make multiple food points around your city instead of the butcher or a stock pile or a bakery.A way to find other designs, maybe its there but I researched swords and got a goblin sword... and thats all I can make for swords.Some planning tool like, clear this area which would send the appropriate professions to remove rock/wood/ore/whatever from an area so you can build without just destroying it. Also I noticed a crazy thing at the tailor... they had made way more basic cloths than my population and most of the town was just hanging around buying them up as fast as they could be made instead of working. Seamed odd. Military research does not seam to work.Where are the heros? As I said like where its going, foundation seams good, however some quality of life things to reduce fatigue of highly repetitive tasks like ... giving your population armor/weapons everytime one goes off and attacks a spider then dies. Worth $15 for sure.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great gift for your future grandchildren, so they too can enjoy the alpha version of Folk Tale, which it will surely still be in.All kidding aside, this game has been plagued by terrible design decisions, throughout its entire EA process. (and I bought this in July '14).Way too many genres being mashed up here and none of them are done particularly well.And somehow, this game went from being "single player fantasy village builder RPG" into a RTS/ARPG... with no pause?I just can't get behind this game.  After over 2 years of development, this game is still a giant, unsorted mess.  I bought a sandbox village builder rpg... 2 years later, i have a campaign-oriented RTS with dated graphics.  Whatever this game is trying to be (at this point, i no longer care) there are games out there, that do each part of this mess, ten times better.  This game forces one type of gamer, to endure a mountain of crap, just to enjoy the parts they bought the game for.For example, I absolutely hate RTS games. I LOVE city/village builders.  When I bought this, there was no mention of RTS gameplay and when I played it, there was not much of a hint to that.  Yet, that is now what we have here.  On top of that, even if I bought it FOR the RTS aspect, they won't put a pause in this SINGLE PLAYER game.  (zero people on the planet, want their STRATEGY GAME to not have a pause).  So they essentially turned their RTS game, that nobody asked for, into a even more unasked for ARPG/RTS. - UPDATE - Pause has been added.I wish the devs luck and I am happy some people are enjoying it, for me however, even when it is released, I have no desire to take the time to even install and try it again unless things change.Do your own research though, this may be for you.  Utilize the refund system and try it if you are on the fence, there are clearly many people who enjoy it.In closing, I have one positive to mention... the devs are very nice and have pretty good communication with the community.  Although this is one of, if not the longest game in EA, never have i ever felt it was abandoned. ( i DID feel the updates were few and far between for a while but that seems to be a thing of the past)

								At first I was reluctant to buy this game, but I decided it was worth the shot. It was a winning bet. This is a great "Settlers" style builder. If these already exists I haven't discovered it yet, but I'll keep looking.With that said, I'm really enjoying playing Folk Tale and appreciate the hard work that is going into the project. I believe the end result will be great.--  I found that I could "tab" through a group of villagers. That does make it easier to equip the townsfolk, but I would like a better interface for that. -- I didn't work with the "v" camera control enough before I made the comment on rotation. That works just fine and it does make it easier for placement of buildings.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played through the campaign to where I hit a problem right at the end, but that's to be expected in a beta/alpha mode.The game is intersting and fun.  I like it.  One has to take it with a garin of salt though as it's an unfinished work.  I appreciate wherr it's going and what it's trying to do.  If you will be overly frustrated with features that are not yet implemented or some balance issues that are not ironed out yet, just wait for it to get further along before you buy it.  But you SHOULD buy it because it's a nice piece of work.I see a lot of folks making a big deal out of demanding that the devs add battle pausing.  To the point of claiming the game belongs to the players and not the developers.  I'll just toss in my opinion here...  are you ready?  Poppycock.  The game belongs to the devs.  They can do whatever the dratted well please to do.  You don't like it?  Don't play it.  You get one vote and one vote only, in economics it's call the dollar vote.The battles can be a bit challenging and I can certainly see where someone is thinking "But if I could just fire off every ability for every character at once I'd be able to win!!!!!"    Sadly this is a false assumption.  The game just needs some additional balancing, to where what you CAN get done is ENOUGH to get you through. But that's a bit further down the road in the cycle where they get into the fine balancing. In the meantime, stop trying to dictate what they develope based on your one little viewpoint.  If you've ever spent years of your live slaving away over making one game in a small team, send them a nice letter explaining your viewpoint, I'm sure they will appreciate it.  Otherwise accept that you don't understand every factor in what you are asking for.  Don't assume that just suddenly ADDING pausing after the game engine is essentially written is all that easy.  Depending on their queueing and methodology that could be a highly complex change that theratens to break many deep and intrinsically complex aspects of the code.  I can see a lot of love and sweat went into this by a small team and you just need to give them some time to work things out. Anyways.  Two thumbs up for making something I found enjoyable.  Can't wait to see where it's going and try it out again in a few months.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have put some time into this game and I want to recommend it now but I can't yet.  I would like to clarify that it has alot of promise however and this review can easily change!  If your interested in funding the developer on its progress and don't mind that the game is not completed yet then please do support by purchasing.  If your looking to progress through the entire story arc you won't make it very far as it is not completed.This Review is based on experimental build (v5) I like:-Building structures to meet resource and happiness requirements-Assigning workers-Upgrades, Research, Items Oh My!-Microing Heros Abilities and Stats-FIghting stuff-Optional tactical pause (Like FTL)It has a warcraft RTS kinda game feel which is not bad IMOWhy I don't Recommend:It is not finished.  The game is incomplete, bugs, and lacks UI optimizations as well as (IMO) some needed RTS features such as select all military units or the ability to hot key buildings to quickly zoom to your base.  The development team is very active on the forums however and the game is making good progress in development in my short time here.Overall this game looks like it will be amazing!  I have high hope that the developers will flesh this game out and it will turn into something special.  Untill then I'd say move along and follow this games progress.  As long as this team does not pull a "space base DF-9" move on us I believe it will be a great RTS single player game during the final stage of development in the future.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pleasantly good game. A very good mix of city building and diablo-style dungeon crawling. The combat could be further refined, as the AI is competent but you would like to see more capacity for managing different roles among your party. I did find a frustration with the constant marauding during campaign mode, a day/night cycle will likely go without challenge, and due to the creatures scaling faster than the xp of your heroes, the lowly vermin start to ravage your town. Something to tune this down, allow for better early defenses (ai for guards, making the guards even somewhat self-sufficient), or some other solution would be appreciated. Overall a good time, reasonable graphics on 4k w/ ultra settings, and cheeky humor make for a fun distraction. 8/10, worth full price, must buy if its on sale.

content:

Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game, with that said I do not have much play time. I tend to hop on for the minimal amount to check updates and see whats new. I don't want to burn out prior to release like rust. When i first started the game it was a true alpha game in the sense that the menu was clunky and commands were unresponsive etc. Today the game plays smooth as butter. The menu's are smooth and easily accessed. It has a settlers 6 feel to it that I have missed for a long time. This game has a very bright future.The biggest thing with the development of any early access title is developer communication and patches. The patches for this game are consistent and worthwhile. There is a roadmap on there site showing which direction they are headed in and whats going to be in each patch. I am also impressed to see the developer actually posting in the forums and responding to questions etc when he has the time. This is one of the few titles that will be completed in early access and I am proud to have supported it in some way. If you like city managing/developing you won't be disappointed. There is alot of things still coming to the game and I could not be more excited. Anyhow, I highly recommend this game to everyone.

number of helpful: 33 of 66 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been following "Folk Tale" over the last few years and slowly but surely, it's been making progress.  Gone is the scripted story and static building placement...instead, you now have a relatively free-form light village builder.  It reminds me a bit of "Banished", but with a few differences.  For one, it's not as harsh.  You can also loot enemies in the environment and equip things on your villagers (in addition to individually leveling them up). Combat is a bit bugged right now...that is, enemies will retreat and auto-restore their health to full making them hard to kill.  With that said, I'm enjoying the direction this game is taking.  It's important to stress what I said earlier about the game taking a while to develop...this isn't your "three months in Early Access then done" deal.  It entered Early Access sometime in 2013 and won't be done till 2016 (per the game's Steam store page).  Those seeking instant gratification and fast/regular updates may want to wait a while.  I'd recommend it for those who enjoy "Banished" or "Hearthlands", though keep in mind that the resource chains aren't nearly as complex (at least at the moment).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I've been watching this game on my wishlist for... about 3 years now. Since it's still in Early access... in it's 3rd year on steam... that says a little something, but I digress. When it finally went on sale this year, I picked it up to play it finally.Now, this game is pretty fun, and I do recommend it.. if you have patience, it does have faults.It kind of doesn't know what type of game it wants to be... on the one hand it's got this cool kinda city builder thing going on, and on the other it's got this dungeon crawler stuff... That sounds interesting, right? Well.. yes and no, it's a little clunky.It also still has bugs, two that I've had in the last hr or so of playing. During a boss fight one of my characters became charmed, and when he was released from it.. he was 14 levels higher and had 999999 hp or something like that. At another point I ran from a battle and two of my heroes died... and the game tried to pull a "Your character will revive in 4079:59 (68 real life hours)." I restarted from an earlier save and lost some progress because of it. Also I discovered pretty late into the campaign that the world map can be used as a teleporter. If it ever tells you this, I don't know, but I wasted wayy to much time playing errand boy running from one dungeon area to the next repeatedly, and was annoyed when I figured it out.Either way... Was this game worth 3 years waiting for a sale to get? I'd say yes, it's not worth the current full price in my opinion. It's not really even worth the price on sale unfortunately. Edit: After thinking on it a little more, I do think this game will be ok in the future, but I don't recommend buying it right now.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Bought this game two years ago thinking at the time that it would be a pretty cool game. Since then I've checked in and re-played it every few months hoping it would get better and improve over time but it's just been a let down. Hugely disappointing. Feels like a game that doesn't have it's chit together and will never deliver something that is really worth playing.August 14, 2016 EDIT:I've since played for 10 hours and made some notes during and after. Bit long, sorry.Folk Tale has come a long way since I tried it about a year ago. I was disappointed back then as it went from a game having a fun if brief tutorial/campaign section to taking a huge step backwards towards being completely unplayable. It was upsetting to think that something that had been so promising had become yet another Steam early-access failure.This time around I've enjoyed the village building aspect immensely and am happy the game has retained the sense of humour that made me buy it in the first place. The combat however is a huge turn off. I found myself getting frustrated with buggy controls and overpowered waves of bandits, spiders and cow people while trying to get a fledgling village up and off the ground. Don't get me wrong, I'm very fond of developing and redeveloping a settlement but what's the point of pouring resources into repairing/rebuilding vital buildings when a few minutes later everything gets destroyed again? This is particularly annoying when villagers get upset and start leaving- your productions chains grind to a halt and everything crumbles to bits. Conscripted villagers aren't much better than their peasant counterparts either and don't do much in the way of defense.I've had fun for the most part in the ten or so hours but found myself getting progressively more and more frustrated with the combat. I go from happily plonking down buildings to trying to fight off spiders/bandits with a small platoon of guards and Heroes and it's a complete mess. Heroes are far too weak- Sir Gregor is supposed to be a tank and yet he dies in a couple of hits. He's got all the skills for tanking but even when I used console commands to equip and level him and Quixl they were still absolute pansies. Trying to use Hero skills is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and it's infuriating trying to move him and other units around with the mouse in combat while being unable to use skills bound to keys. They simply do not work and this absolutely needs to be fixed. Combat should be fun and fluid, not like wading through knee high muck.Admittedly as a result of clunky, unmanagable combat I haven't played very far into the campaign- I was more interested in building up a self-sustaining village before gearing up to go and quest. The questline feels so entirely separate from what goes on in the village map and with combat the way it is at present I simply don't want to go and do any of it. I did some for a bit but it's simply not fun and it feels uninteresting.Combat is depressingly awful and I'd throw a warm dog turd at it if it was a person to express my displeasure but the city-building aspects of Folk Tale are it's redeeming feature and what really makes this game incredibly fun. At the moment it does feels like the game is trying to do too much and really isn't doing it well. I'm almost tempted to say ditch the quest bits because they're so boring and cumbersome it's mortifying but removing those would make this purely a city-building simulator (albeit a rather fun one).Folk Tale has made significant progress over the last year in development and it really shows. However even with all the improvements that have been made so far combat absolutely needs to be fixed or it will kill the potential success of this game. If Folk Tale was purely a city-building game right now I'd zealously recommend it to all my friends despite being in early-access/development, but because it's not and because the combat is terrible I cannot recommend it as it is at present.I am optimistic though. What I've seen so far has shown that Folk Tale can be a success if given more work and more time. One of the biggest problems it has right now though is that the game has a reputation as being yet another failed early-access game stuck in perpetual development hell. I believe that this will gradually improve given the work that the team has put in, particularly in paying attention to feedback from the community. Plenty of developers say they listen to their fans, but for many of them it's just lip service. The contrast between a year ago and now is night and day- I went into this ten hour Folk Tale binge with very low expectations and about thirty minutes in I actually went to Google to see if the entire development team had been changed. That's how different it felt and how great an improvement had been made. Thank you for taking the time to contact me on Steam. I'm a bit burned out from playing Folk Tale right now but I'm looking forward to checking back in a couple of months and seeing how things have improved.------When using a skill (bound to key) Hero is unselected. Have to reselect Hero again before being able to use another skill. Very disruptive, breaks the flow of gameplay. Tested a few times and this happens both in the tutorial and the campaign. A few times it worked properly but most of the time it did not.-Doesn't appear to be an option to hide/minimize the quest pane. No dedicated quest log? Odd, would like to be able to hide the quest pane as it blocks the expanded inventory + character windows.-Inventory sorting? There used to be an option for this early on but it seems to have been removed.-Roads or toggleable grid system to help with keeping the placement of buildings neat would be nice. Building placement is messy and disorganized. Terrain is also inconsistent on where you can place structures and where you can't. Why the hell does a small rock in the way keep me from building a house there? I like making my village neat and tidy.-When speaking to npcs I have to move mouse up and down to click continue, speech options, etc. Space bar works fine for linear speech options but it would be nice to be able to press 1, 2, 3 etc when there are multiple speech options. Minor preference.- In the workers tab for buildings I'd like to be able to use mouse wheel to scroll through list of trainable peasants. Not a big fan of the click up and down, doesn't feel very fluid.-Would be nice to have a pause button that works while you pan around the map and a fast forward option. Was surprised that this is not a feature.-Moving around the map feels slow (especially as you can't zoom out very far) and could be helped along with some keys you could bind to various locations (ie zoom to town center, farming area, etc). Banished has a good example of this where you can custom bind locations to keys. Makes moving around the map much more convenient.-Custom keybindings do not persist and have to be reassigned for each new game. Building rotation keys cannot be reassigned. Keybindings tab says they are, but they seemed glued to [ and ]. Haven't tried all of the keybindings but they definitely are an issue at present (ie Hero skills).-Enemies destroy buildings entirely- would be nice if they reduced them back down to an empty frame or ruin. It's unrealistic- buildings that get bombed/burned/etc don't just magically disappear- but my actual beef is having to place everything all over again (especially when this game isn't big on being neat and organized) which is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ particularly when you've got unrelenting waves of enemies who apparently really despise your village architecture.-Have restarted the campaign 6 times so far.  My biggest complaint is combat is terrible and that characters are WAY too squishy to withstand the waves of spiders and bandits early game. Ridiculously squishy. Combat is very clunky and feels cumbersome.

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've had this for a while, and although I don't play it too often (I think the time played counter was reset with a big version change), whenever I do play I always have a good time. It's changed quite a lot in the time that I've had it, and although progress is quite slow, each update makes the game more robust technically, and more interesting to play. It's a bit like old-skool Settlers, but with a colourful, chunky Warcraft-like feel to the graphics. The VO work is professional and very well done, and the script is much better than average too. I suspect some of the unhappy reviews are from people who have followed it for a long time and are dissappointed by the speed of the updates, or the fact that it's more of a city-builder/RTS/RPG hybrid, but taken on its own merits, it's solid fun, and quite engrossing too.

Early Access Review
								So many unnecessary bad reviews!!! This is not just a game but a game within game creation software!!! It is almost unfair to call it a game. Most of the bad reviews mainly discuss the 2 years in early access. Yes i agree that 2 years is a little long for early access but... the producer is small and METICULOUS so deserves a little slack. o.k. i did not buy this game 2 years ago so maybe my frustration level is not as high as someone who did; but all you have to do is mess around with this "system/game/what have you" and you will see the potential this title has. I look at it like this; if you have a game that allows modding or level development you have a virtual unlimited game. Add to this that mod levels are often better than the developers. Look what the world has given us with the Bethesda products! Skyrim is 5 years old and is still relevant in any current game of the year discussion. This title has not reached that level but it has the possibility. As far as updates to this game?? After i promised to not "buy" any other games i started to keep an eye on this one. I started in January and by May there were significant additions and changes to this title so that i decided to break my decision and purchase this game.  I am not sorry i did...btw i have significantly more time in this title than is illustrated.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I've been watching this game on my wishlist for... about 3 years now. Since it's still in Early access... in it's 3rd year on steam... that says a little something, but I digress. When it finally went on sale this year, I picked it up to play it finally.Now, this game is pretty fun, and I do recommend it.. if you have patience, it does have faults.It kind of doesn't know what type of game it wants to be... on the one hand it's got this cool kinda city builder thing going on, and on the other it's got this dungeon crawler stuff... That sounds interesting, right? Well.. yes and no, it's a little clunky.It also still has bugs, two that I've had in the last hr or so of playing. During a boss fight one of my characters became charmed, and when he was released from it.. he was 14 levels higher and had 999999 hp or something like that. At another point I ran from a battle and two of my heroes died... and the game tried to pull a "Your character will revive in 4079:59 (68 real life hours)." I restarted from an earlier save and lost some progress because of it. Also I discovered pretty late into the campaign that the world map can be used as a teleporter. If it ever tells you this, I don't know, but I wasted wayy to much time playing errand boy running from one dungeon area to the next repeatedly, and was annoyed when I figured it out.Either way... Was this game worth 3 years waiting for a sale to get? I'd say yes, it's not worth the current full price in my opinion. It's not really even worth the price on sale unfortunately. Edit: After thinking on it a little more, I do think this game will be ok in the future, but I don't recommend buying it right now.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Bought this game two years ago thinking at the time that it would be a pretty cool game. Since then I've checked in and re-played it every few months hoping it would get better and improve over time but it's just been a let down. Hugely disappointing. Feels like a game that doesn't have it's chit together and will never deliver something that is really worth playing.August 14, 2016 EDIT:I've since played for 10 hours and made some notes during and after. Bit long, sorry.Folk Tale has come a long way since I tried it about a year ago. I was disappointed back then as it went from a game having a fun if brief tutorial/campaign section to taking a huge step backwards towards being completely unplayable. It was upsetting to think that something that had been so promising had become yet another Steam early-access failure.This time around I've enjoyed the village building aspect immensely and am happy the game has retained the sense of humour that made me buy it in the first place. The combat however is a huge turn off. I found myself getting frustrated with buggy controls and overpowered waves of bandits, spiders and cow people while trying to get a fledgling village up and off the ground. Don't get me wrong, I'm very fond of developing and redeveloping a settlement but what's the point of pouring resources into repairing/rebuilding vital buildings when a few minutes later everything gets destroyed again? This is particularly annoying when villagers get upset and start leaving- your productions chains grind to a halt and everything crumbles to bits. Conscripted villagers aren't much better than their peasant counterparts either and don't do much in the way of defense.I've had fun for the most part in the ten or so hours but found myself getting progressively more and more frustrated with the combat. I go from happily plonking down buildings to trying to fight off spiders/bandits with a small platoon of guards and Heroes and it's a complete mess. Heroes are far too weak- Sir Gregor is supposed to be a tank and yet he dies in a couple of hits. He's got all the skills for tanking but even when I used console commands to equip and level him and Quixl they were still absolute pansies. Trying to use Hero skills is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and it's infuriating trying to move him and other units around with the mouse in combat while being unable to use skills bound to keys. They simply do not work and this absolutely needs to be fixed. Combat should be fun and fluid, not like wading through knee high muck.Admittedly as a result of clunky, unmanagable combat I haven't played very far into the campaign- I was more interested in building up a self-sustaining village before gearing up to go and quest. The questline feels so entirely separate from what goes on in the village map and with combat the way it is at present I simply don't want to go and do any of it. I did some for a bit but it's simply not fun and it feels uninteresting.Combat is depressingly awful and I'd throw a warm dog turd at it if it was a person to express my displeasure but the city-building aspects of Folk Tale are it's redeeming feature and what really makes this game incredibly fun. At the moment it does feels like the game is trying to do too much and really isn't doing it well. I'm almost tempted to say ditch the quest bits because they're so boring and cumbersome it's mortifying but removing those would make this purely a city-building simulator (albeit a rather fun one).Folk Tale has made significant progress over the last year in development and it really shows. However even with all the improvements that have been made so far combat absolutely needs to be fixed or it will kill the potential success of this game. If Folk Tale was purely a city-building game right now I'd zealously recommend it to all my friends despite being in early-access/development, but because it's not and because the combat is terrible I cannot recommend it as it is at present.I am optimistic though. What I've seen so far has shown that Folk Tale can be a success if given more work and more time. One of the biggest problems it has right now though is that the game has a reputation as being yet another failed early-access game stuck in perpetual development hell. I believe that this will gradually improve given the work that the team has put in, particularly in paying attention to feedback from the community. Plenty of developers say they listen to their fans, but for many of them it's just lip service. The contrast between a year ago and now is night and day- I went into this ten hour Folk Tale binge with very low expectations and about thirty minutes in I actually went to Google to see if the entire development team had been changed. That's how different it felt and how great an improvement had been made. Thank you for taking the time to contact me on Steam. I'm a bit burned out from playing Folk Tale right now but I'm looking forward to checking back in a couple of months and seeing how things have improved.------When using a skill (bound to key) Hero is unselected. Have to reselect Hero again before being able to use another skill. Very disruptive, breaks the flow of gameplay. Tested a few times and this happens both in the tutorial and the campaign. A few times it worked properly but most of the time it did not.-Doesn't appear to be an option to hide/minimize the quest pane. No dedicated quest log? Odd, would like to be able to hide the quest pane as it blocks the expanded inventory + character windows.-Inventory sorting? There used to be an option for this early on but it seems to have been removed.-Roads or toggleable grid system to help with keeping the placement of buildings neat would be nice. Building placement is messy and disorganized. Terrain is also inconsistent on where you can place structures and where you can't. Why the hell does a small rock in the way keep me from building a house there? I like making my village neat and tidy.-When speaking to npcs I have to move mouse up and down to click continue, speech options, etc. Space bar works fine for linear speech options but it would be nice to be able to press 1, 2, 3 etc when there are multiple speech options. Minor preference.- In the workers tab for buildings I'd like to be able to use mouse wheel to scroll through list of trainable peasants. Not a big fan of the click up and down, doesn't feel very fluid.-Would be nice to have a pause button that works while you pan around the map and a fast forward option. Was surprised that this is not a feature.-Moving around the map feels slow (especially as you can't zoom out very far) and could be helped along with some keys you could bind to various locations (ie zoom to town center, farming area, etc). Banished has a good example of this where you can custom bind locations to keys. Makes moving around the map much more convenient.-Custom keybindings do not persist and have to be reassigned for each new game. Building rotation keys cannot be reassigned. Keybindings tab says they are, but they seemed glued to [ and ]. Haven't tried all of the keybindings but they definitely are an issue at present (ie Hero skills).-Enemies destroy buildings entirely- would be nice if they reduced them back down to an empty frame or ruin. It's unrealistic- buildings that get bombed/burned/etc don't just magically disappear- but my actual beef is having to place everything all over again (especially when this game isn't big on being neat and organized) which is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ particularly when you've got unrelenting waves of enemies who apparently really despise your village architecture.-Have restarted the campaign 6 times so far.  My biggest complaint is combat is terrible and that characters are WAY too squishy to withstand the waves of spiders and bandits early game. Ridiculously squishy. Combat is very clunky and feels cumbersome.

								Folk Tale has changed a lot since my first review, so I decided to give it another chance.Whilst I didn't exactly fall in love, I feel quite strongly that the game has a lot of promise. It's very, very good-looking, has a great soundtrack, and an appealing UI. Playing it is very soothing - it's very smooth to play, and I reallllly enjoy the graphic style. It reminds me a lot of The Settlers series. I'm really surprised to find an alpha indie game looking this good. Folk Tale still has some way to go, with plenty of stuff still to implement, but it's definitely worth looking at if you're into this type of game. Everything that is implemented so far looks professional and I came away with the feeling like the game is now being developed by competent people. If they can make the gameplay and complexity to the same standard as the art direction, then this will be a great game.

number of helpful: 33 of 66 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been following "Folk Tale" over the last few years and slowly but surely, it's been making progress.  Gone is the scripted story and static building placement...instead, you now have a relatively free-form light village builder.  It reminds me a bit of "Banished", but with a few differences.  For one, it's not as harsh.  You can also loot enemies in the environment and equip things on your villagers (in addition to individually leveling them up). Combat is a bit bugged right now...that is, enemies will retreat and auto-restore their health to full making them hard to kill.  With that said, I'm enjoying the direction this game is taking.  It's important to stress what I said earlier about the game taking a while to develop...this isn't your "three months in Early Access then done" deal.  It entered Early Access sometime in 2013 and won't be done till 2016 (per the game's Steam store page).  Those seeking instant gratification and fast/regular updates may want to wait a while.  I'd recommend it for those who enjoy "Banished" or "Hearthlands", though keep in mind that the resource chains aren't nearly as complex (at least at the moment).

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was hesitant to buy another Early Access game, but I'm glad I got this one. Although you can tell it is far from finished, what is available in terms of gameplay is enjoyable. So far this is a sandbox village builder with a little army building/combat. The presence of good voice acting and polished graphics/UI is something I have missed with indie games and makes it feel like a quality project in the works. I really like being able to zoom in up close and watch the villagers go about their lives. Your military villagers have inventories and take upgraded gear and weapons, and I look forward to seeing that fully implemented.Micromanaging resource production is neat, though on the easy map not really necessary as there is no challenge to keeping up resources. At this time there are 3 maps to play in sandbox mode and they are not randomly generated yet. That will be a nice feature to see.As far as drawbacks, it's too early to start critiquing. If I had to come up with a gripe it would be that the game can feel a little slow and it would be nice to have a hotkey to speed things up occasionally rather than tweaking it in settings. I also could not sit through the tutorial, but after skipping to sandbox it didn't take long to figure everything out with trial and error.I am excited to see where this game goes and the activity and responsiveness of the devs gives me hope that this could end up a really fun game at completion.

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok definitely a good game. Actually it’s a phenomenal game! Some people complain about it being in alpha for a bit too long. Personally Idc, I'd rather they took t heir time to polish it than release it early and have it be incomplete. Before you read all the way through though, Ive only played the game for a few hours, and haven’t beaten any of the maps yet, so this review comes from limited experience and knowledge.The Good:-It’s fun and challenging, especially after you've progressed past your basic buildings (woodcutter, stonecutter and a food source) -Challenging, but not too challenging.♥♥♥♥♥♥wanders into your town to cause a bit of havoc and stretch your resources. But you don’t have Beholders and Owlbears coming into town to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up with lasers from their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on a regular basis. They took most of my favorite things from Age of Empires, and combined it with my favorite things from Banished (also a good game, check it out) and then threw in a pinch of Skyrim/Oblivion and Stronghold 2. The result is amazing. You can't just turtle-up and mass an army of foot soldiers to steam roll from one end of the map to the other like you can in AoE. However it’s not as stupidly infuriatingly wonderfully hard as Banished is.-It has the added bonus of being actually able to create soldiers (unlike Banished), and gives you enemies that you can go fight and loot. But by no means do you have to. If you like, you can just focus on the drinking of ale, the smoking of pipe weed, and finding a love of gardening.-If you do decide to go out and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up, it’s a challenge. The♥♥♥♥♥♥you fight keeps, proportionally, 1 step above you. So you have to actually engage in your combat. Most games allow you to step on spiders and kill mice and call it experience. Folk Tale does not.-Individuality of the peasants. Now 9 out of 10 times this doesn’t actually matter. The 1/10 of the time it does is in the army. You can, after you've killed something, loot it for gear and treasure! So ♥♥♥♥ing neat, cause with that gear, you can equip Joe the manure shoveling leper, with the Mithril Great sword of ♥♥♥♥off and the Diamond Chest plate of Not In My House ♥♥♥♥♥, and then make Joe the savior of the land, riding valiantly on the monstrous size of his own♥♥♥♥♥♥which he presumably discovered after finding out he was such a badass and could slay demons with his own♥♥♥♥♥♥and a can-do attitude. Each peasant can be leveled up uniquely and it’s ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. You can either take the equipment or divide it out between your forces, making a well-rounded security force that is to be reckoned with. Or pour all of your resources into one hulking behemoth that could fight and beat Zeus, god of gods.-Visually pleasing to look at-Audio is likewise pleasing (kind of reminiscent of LOTR [which is the best series of movies ever made by mankind])-There's a great variety of building to be placed and they all do different things.-Enemies get more difficult to beat the further you venture from your starting point.♥♥♥♥♥♥gets crazy yo'.The Bad:Actually I don’t like 'bad' cause really this game is a gem in the making. So we’re going to say the Mediocre.The Mediocre:-The Elasticity leaves something to be desired                This is one big category cause every problem I have comes back to this blanket criticism. What I mean is that       the game doesn’t flow as smoothly as it could have. 1.	Buildings= There's a variety of buildings, which is good yes, but I feel some of them could be condensed. For instance I had run out of clothes and my villagers began to complain as their nips were starting to fall off from frostbite. Tight. Places Cotton field. Good. Places Tailor. Good, clothes will start to be produced. Wrong. Turns out you also had to place a “Weavers Emporium”. So my warehouse had stockpiled like 50 stocks of weaved cotton, that I then had to go into overtime to catch up on both rewarding and lashing the weavers to get them to work as fast as possible. It just seems to me, that since the only thing you use cotton for is clothes, it seemed kinda silly that you needed 3 ♥♥♥♥ing building to make one product. Placing, monitoring and upkeeping and extra building took away from the flow of the game.2.	Your army/security force (4 people isn’t really an army). I have no problem with the small size, in fact I prefer it, it emphasizes tactics over brute strength. I have a slight issue with the equipping of your soldiers. If there was an ‘equip all’ button, that’d be fantastic. Having to click on the guardsmen, open their inventory, open your inventory. Click boots, move boots, click mail, move mail, click gloves, move gloves, click coif, move coif, then do that 3 to 7 more times is more than a lot tedious and it takes away from the game. Like♥♥♥♥♥♥I got wolves eating Jim the peasant and ♥♥♥♥ing the stonecutters just caught fire I gotta take care of this but noooo first I gotta do this painfully slow process.3.	Researching Tech is a pain. It has a AoE feel of spending resource to research new tech, which is legit. Don’t fix what’s not broke right? Well you can go ahead and buy as many upgrades as you can afford at once, the problem is that once one is done, it won’t bounce to the second one. Say you research Chisels, hammers and masonry. Once Chisels is done, it’ll stop there, till you re-click the building, go to the tech tab and select the next tech to research. It leads to a lot of needles bouncing form building to building to check and recheck what tech is at what progress in what building then bouncing back to select the next tech to research even though you’ve already purchased it. Long story, anyway. It would be nice if, once you’ve bought a tech, it got automatically researched in the order they were purchased.4.	Assigning peasants a job. This one has two in one. So 1.1 you build a building, tight. Assign 3 peasants to chop wood so you can leave your last one to keep foraging berries. Then later, when you have more peasants you go back to the building, assign a 4th peasant. Jim the farmer dies from a goblin attack, go to building and take 1 woodcutter and unassign him. Go to farm, assign new farmer. Now this doesn’t sound TOO annoying and honestly it’s not. This is my smallest beef with Folk tale. It’s nearly remedied by the ability to check a box on each building titles “auto-assign” which automatically makes sure the building is full of workers if able. You do however, have to go to each building and check the box off. Otherwise no luck. It’s be nice if the box was automatically set to autoassign or you could go to the options menu and make it so. Another (preferred) solution would be to do what “Banished” and have an entire menu that shows all the jobs, how many workers could be there, and how many workers are there currently. It accommodates the fast pace of “Banished” where the east section of your village can just die from a surprise earthquake. I think it would do well here In Folk tale to.1.2 This, logically, should be my smallest beef, but it’s not. I like knowing where my peasants are. Like, in Aoe, you have a button to select all inactive peasants, in Stronghold they gather around the fire. In Folk Tale, I’ve got no ♥♥♥♥in’ clue where they are. And that bothers me immensely, as Im more than slightly anal-retentive and I like to specifically assign individuals to certain jobs. When I have to find four free peasants to turn into herbalists by scouring every nook and cranny of my town, its slightly annoying. Anyway. That’s all. Sorry for the long post but I do really love this game already and wanted to offer every thought I had on the matter. As of now, I give it a solid 8.5/10. With some improvements to the flow and elasticity of the game I’d easily and happily give it a 10/10.
