content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
Early Access Review
Folk Tale ReviewFolk Tale is a game that combines elements from a wide spectrum of genres including RTS, citybuilder, simulation, and RPG in order to bring gamers a totally new and unique experience. The game is still in Early Access and it already has an incredible history. I first began tracking this game during its successful Greenlight campaign. It reminded me of a modern take on The Settlers series but I was hesitant to jump on board until I could see whether it would follow the same path as so many of its predecessors or perhaps it would offer us something new. And it has.When Folk Tale originally applied for Greenlight status on Steam, it was planned to be a typical RTS citybuilder simulation with a full-length player campaign. And while many of the features had yet to be fleshed out, the core game structure was already in place. In order to give themselves the greatest chance of funding success, the game developers at Game Foundry decided to ask the Steam Community what they wanted to see in this game and an eventual Community Poll determined that most wanted to see Folk Tale as a sandbox game. I can't recall any other time when a game's development was halted mid-stream and completely shifted in a different direction based on our opinions. But here we are. The team from Game Foundry strapped in and accepted the challenge. This has lead to some timely delays in the game's production and the developers have unfairly caught a lot of criticism for not releasing a finished product yet. Keep in mind, this is the game we decided on and they are doing their best to give us what we asked for even though it added a lot more work for them.  There are still a ton of cool features they plan on adding to this game and they are very active in its production, providing constant updates and weekly progress blogs to keep us informed every step of the way. The game is already in a stable, playable state though. So getting the game now is not a bad idea. And, because the developers are so open and active with the Community, you could possibly help shape part of the game's future.But what can you expect from Folk Tale right now? For starters, the graphics for this type of game are very rich and full of vivid detail. There is a fully-rotational 3D camera that operates smoothly and easily. The user interface is in place and functional, although many of the mouseover tooltips are still missing. Its not too difficult to figure out what each button does though. A majority of the sound effects and voiceovers are now finished. Most all of the buildings and economic/resource elements are in place and functioning properly. Multiple maps are available for play and editor tools have been included already so the Steam Community can already begin working on their own custom additions. The mobs of creatures have been released into the wild and will offer a bit of a challenge during your otherwise tranquil building experience. Loot and treasures can be gathered after defeating enemy threats, which can be used to equip your villagers and troops with better armor and such. A lot of research and upgrades have been added to the game already, but even more is on the way.Many of the planned features are still being developed though. Building upgrades have not been implemented as of yet. Eventually, heroes will be added into the mix but are not available at this time. The villagers and troops have abilities and skill points to be distributed as they gain experience, but currently this feature is not working. All of the villagers still share the same facial image in the user interface when selected. Other units are expected to be added in the future as well (wizards, for example). And since changing from a story-driven campaign to a sandbox style of play, there is no longer a tutorial to get players started. I believe one will be added fairly soon, and if not, I strongly urge the game developers to consider including one in order to familiarize new players with the basic concepts of the game. While I thoroughly enjoy the game already, it is quite clear that there is still a lot of work to be done. If you're one of those players who are only interested in finished products then you might be waiting on Folk Tale for a while.The Good:=======+  Rich and highly detailed graphics+  Quality sound and voice acting+  Fully-rotating 3D camera w/smooth controls+  Variety of buildings and research+  Well-designed economy and resource structure+  Extremely mod-friendly w/editting tools included+  Varying difficulty to offer greater challenge+  Save game feature implemented and working+  Friendly and active game developersThe Bad:======-  No tutorial included-  No skirmish options or goal-oriented features-  While stable, there are still a few bugs-  Mouseover tooltips only half-complete-  Many features still not implemented or under developmentFinal Thoughts:===========Folk Tale is still a long way from completion, but is highly enjoyable already. The team at Game Foundry laid out plans for a game that will offer a multitude of exciting features and they continue to work diligently trying to make it a reality. If they continue down this path then Folk Tale is sure to be a strong candidate for GOTY (whenever its fully released). For those who enjoy real-time citybuilding simulations, I'd encourage you to go ahead and buy the game now since its fully playable. Those who are impatient and only want to experience finished products should add the game to your Wishlist and wait for completion or else you will most likely have a negative experience given the game's currently un-finished form.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: April 2
Early Access Review
								Overall I had fun playing this game. I don't buy early access based on future promises, and it has enough to offer right now for you to enjoy the game. I think if you enjoy citybuilders its got enough for 15-20 hours of play, and the RPG elements make it unique from other entries in the genre.Having said that, there are definitely some areas I'd love to see improved so that I can come back and play this game some more. A citybuilder and an RPG - This is what makes the game unique. But I would have liked to see some difficulty sliders for each portion of the game. I prefer city builders, and doing the RPG part of the game was honestly a chore. I would have liked a difficulty slider that made the RPG part much easier, and the city builder part a little more challenging.  Level scaling Leveling is a core part of the game. Villagers get better, heroes get better, and monsters get better. But the monster levelling can get pretty annoying, once I had levelled up my heroes to level 6 the monsters had gotten almost too difficult for my troops to take on. I had to rush my heroes around to every little combat event. Until this is fixed I'd like a way to turn off combat level scalling altogether on the village map (for everything except heroes), or don't include the heroes in the monster levelling calculations. To fix it long term I think there should be some kind of training building that slowly adds experience to your lowest levelled troops up to the level of your highest levelled troops. I also think there should be a global ticker that says what the monster level is, and clearly shows what effect you are having on it. I think what effects the monster level should be the size of your city and the amount of loot available in it. So if monsters successfully break your defense and destroy your buildings they would fall down to an easier level. This would also force larger cities to invest more in defense.  Building synergies Right now all of the buildings are very independant, they have their own research paths, and they don't really have any effects on the buildings around them. I think the city-building aspects of this game would be greatly improved if each building also provided some synergistic benefits to nearby buildings. Some of the synergies I'd like to see: Cottage provides bonus to worker productivity of nearby buildings. Since villagers no longer need to walk around to provide for their needs, forcing players to keep the cottage closer could simulate the benefits of having their home close to their workplace.  Sawmill and hunting lodge next to each other. Animals like the tree cover so maybe provide a benefit to animal spawning near a sawmill Towers that are garrisoned will increase the range of nearby buildings. Walls near a gatehouse are strengthened Blacksmith provides small productivity bonus when next to any building that it could provide tools for. Town improvementsIt would be good to get a building that can serve as a research center for general improvements to all buildings. Like a town hall, maybe the supply wagon serves as the first level of the town hall. The town hall would have research available for lower fire chances, increased health of buildings, increased productivity of workers, starting level of new workers, improve xp gains for soldiers/workers, etc. This building could also serve as a lock on tier improvements, like it has to be tier two before other buildings can be tier two. It would be neat if this building replaced the lamppost for fast travel. Maybe this building would also provide a special minor-hero unit 'the mayor' he could level up like other characters. He would be able to cast productivity enhancements on nearby buildings, if "killed" he would lose 10% experience but also hide out in the town hall for 2 minutes while he recoveres. RTS improvements -  Rally flags for military buildings. I found it easy to create a choke point where new monsters would go and I would just leave a bunch of my soldiers there. It would be nice if military buildings could create rally flags so new soldiers would automatically go to the spot. Also there need to be a way in the barracks to auto create arbalists or city guards, right now it will default to auto-creating spearmen who are the weakest.  Patrols. I want to be able to assign military units to patrol a certain area. Formation behavior. If I tell a large military group to go to a location, I don't want the cavalry charging in ahead without support from arbalists.That is a long list of suggestions. I don't think they are all absolutely necessary, but they would all be nice to have. If I find out any of these features have been added in the future I will try to ammend my post to reflect those changes with  Strikethrough text

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								So...People have said it already. I'll say it again. But instead of retyping this, I want you to imagine the following two scenarios:You decide to make a cake. That's pretty simple - add some dough, and some sweet stuff, and you've got a cake. Right. Well, what kind of cake do you want to make? Chocolate? Vanilla? Who knows? Depends on who will be eating it, right? Right? Well, let's go ask those people. But wait! We can make a bigger cake! A better cake! A cake that everyone will love! So we will now have a chocolate / vanilla / starwberry / cheese / ice cream cake baked in a god damn oven but the chilled in a freeze and oh god we really don't know what we any more other than making everyone happy so here is a big pile of burnt cake, melted ice cream, mouldy cheesecake andf you can dig through it and try to find something you like.Welcome to Folk Tale. This game started witha  tons of promise. It has since veered of course...and I'm not sure what this game is going to wind up being. I voted for it on Greenlight, I was really excited for it when it came out on Early Access and did something almost as dumb as sticking my gentleman's sausage in a drawer and slamming it fully♥♥♥♥♥♥ I believed that the developers would stick to their original vision and deliver the game they said they set out to make.Ahahaha. Aha. Aaaahahaha. Yeah. Nope.This game is one of the many reasons why I no longer buy into Early Access - I've seen them do this exact kind of thing too many times, which is a shame. I love this style of game. I've player Settlers since Settlers two, I've played the Anno series, Sim City series - any kind of management / city buidling game, I really look forward to. It is an underserved market, and Folk Tale had the potential to be really cool. But then, the devs threw their vision out the window to try to appease to everyone (I mean, sandbox games are the hip thing now, right? Right?! Everyone loves sandbox! So hip! So cool! Like beards and old bicycles and plaid...yeah.)Basically, this is going nowhere. It has been in Early Access for "A Very Long Time". I really don't know what's going to come out of it, but I can't recommend anyone buy this until it's done and released - at which point, you might at least have a chance at knowing what you're buying.F*@*!* Early Access.

Posted: April 7
Early Access Review
								If you like building along with tactical defense and RPG this is the game for you. In campaign mode you will need to build palasades ASAP to block raiding spiders. Building a single palasade on the other side of bridges saves resources early on. Then you can stage your heroes by the main spawn outside your village until you have the resources to build a full length fence there. Add a market so you can unlock spider bounties in your research. Now you will have lots of gold for research. Building a blacksmith and researching halberds and xbows will get you the city guards and crosbowmen you need. Stage the crossbow guys on gate house facing a known spider spawn and watch them crank the gold and xp for you. You can add towers to either side of the gatehouse as you see fit. If you get bored of building take out your heroes for adventure and exploring. Research,adventure and building. For me this game is amazing. Even my slower Dell Inspiron 660 with 6gb of ram can handle this game okay. Using the experimental build runs a bit slower and sometimes it sits at 92% for about 1 min then its fine. Cant wait to see what they add next. Marathon gaming sessions may occur so they should add a warning about how addictive this game is LOL :)

It's certainly not a dead project for the devs, and I see that as a positive for the future. I'll pop in every couple months and play through a game mostly for the RTS side of things. The dungeon crawling bit is just a cherry on the top for me. I'd recommend this title to anyone that enjoys building their little settlement into a village, all while fending off the invaders that inevitably try and take the comforts your villagers enjoy.Overall it's been worth my 20 bucks. 8/10, would buy again.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Folktale’s elegance is noted in its simplicity. By, only being an RTS, RPG, Village Builder, and World Editor; with accompanied feature such as character progression, multi-tier crafter and building, dynamic worlds, a wide verity of units and heroes, and lastly accompanied by a multi-pathway questing system, which utilises all the functionality of the very powerful Workbench tool, Folktale takes the modest and humble themes of traditional game development and innovates to point where a new genre of gaming is created.	Created with the Unity engine, GamesFoundry have created a game, which occupies a niche of its own. Folktale’s RTS gameplay is common to its contemporaries; accordingly, the new or aged gamer will find the left mouse and right mouse button clicking an easy mechanism to grasps. Classically there are units to counter units, units to tank, units to heal, and units to shoot or be shot at. Heroes too, will find a suitable place in the players armies, filling a diverse roll based on which and what stats the player has chosen, perhaps electing the hero to focus on their DPS, or their PTSD if the war wages for a little longer than necessary. Sometimes, maybe, war is not the only way to peace. In fact war for peace is an oxymoron. Or is it? It is.  	However before sending your lovely villages to war for that plus 10% increase in wood production, perhaps the player would first like to contemplate the mechanics of the game’s village building. Unique only to its self, Folktale’s village management requires the constant attention of the play; for, lest the play grows lax in the exploration of Folktale’s many regions, caves, dragon’s lair and sepulchre like dungeons, the player might find that goblins, or kobolds, or yetis, or tall wooden things with weird pulsating fungi erupting from what one would mistake as their head, are coming to set fire, steal and kill your, lovely, lovely villagers. Certainly these villagers are the example of sophistication. Surly the player will never once more find people with tastes so refined, as they would find here, in this game. Surly.  	In short Folktale is a beguiling game, forming a flawless compilation of game mechanics and visuals, the development team have created for the player the perfect complement for an afternoon of luxurious gaming. So why not now, before the sun sets on another day of wasted opportunity. “Do not the valent find the days of weary, home, hearth and Folktale calling their names”…ISH…

Early Access Review
								I definetly have to recommend this game, i got it at the very early stages and i had to say that the game itself was decent it was humorus with the lack of toast in the game.... I stopped playing the game for awhile but when i had come back to Folk Tale i saw that the game had developed from just an easy building tutorial game into something really exciting. The game mechanics have gotten updated and made the game more challenging and the amount of buildings and how the economic system in the game have become make the game just that more interesting reminding me of a stronghold mixed with age of empires online feel as the game uses the same popularity scale as stronghold but has the ransacking destruction of age of empires online when your villages are big enough and you go questing. The tundra and swamp maps are pretty challenging if you dont understand the game at first because of the lack of resources or even the amount of orcs coming at you all at once. Overall this game is a very fun game, very humorous and has tons of potential and i cannot wait until the game is completed! One thing i hope for is a added multiplayer option where you can build and compete against your friends in a rival trade town.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is the first review I have ever written, and I was compelled to write it to make sure people who are interested in this game feel confident in supporting it despite the (currently) mixed reviews.I thoroughly enjoyed the tutorial when I first purchased this game, but as the devs focused on the sandbox mode I was hesistant to give it much of a go.  Most of the negative reviews are people who weren't happy with this decision, as I initally was.  After spending some time in sandbox mode, I can see that this game is still going to be something unique and intersting.  With the sandbox genre getting beat to death by developers over the last few years, Folk Tale is a breath of fresh air and a fascinating perspective on the genre.The resource gathering is challenging but understandable and logical.  The sense of humor is on point but not over-the-top.  The RPG elements of crafting, equipping, and experience for the villagers are unlike any other game I have played.  While only having spent 3 hours playing as of writing this game, each time I return to it I am greeted by improvements and new and fun mechanics to learn.Despite how interesting and intriguing the game itself is, the main point I wanted to make in writing this review is that this game will make you feel rewarded for supporting the developers in Early Access.  They are accessible, focused, responsive, and provide a great sense of involvement and community in the developing of this game.  Early Access can be messy, it can be fun, but it the case of Folk Tale, participating in Early Access is as much of an adventure as the game is.  Trust me, you won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								"Review is after Rant. Spaced appart and marked clearly"So I was responding a to  a4440a's review and steam said my post was to long, what I was going to post:"I have no issue that they askedd for positive feedback. They even said in the request that if you feel that the game does deserve the negative feedback it's been getting that it's on them. But requesting the people who do enjoy it to have their voices heard is not wrong. People are WAY more likely to post things when they feel negatively about something than when they feel positive. As a person who works in retail we ask for customer feedback to know how we did andd to see that we made a persons experience enjoyable. So few people actually give positive feedback for anything and there post looks no different then when a clerk asks for feedback about the service. And more than 98% of people don't give feeddback if not asked. I know this because 2% is our goal and we rarely hit it with asking.Also the Dev's seem to be pretty good at responding to every review. So the dev team is clearly still active. Even coming back to this review after they had responded when a new patch came out. That's fantastic service. "It should be noted one of his/her main issues was that they had asked for the fans and people who were enjoying the game to give feedback. They didn't force anyone to. They merely, and quite frankly very politely, asked people to give feedback. Yet he/she, like many others, made it seems like a horrible thing that they had done. like they had enroached on their freedoms and it was unethical and immoral. infact a few posts stated it was immoral. . . SERIOUSLY????And it made me realise ♥♥♥♥♥♥ it is that people have been treating this game and dev's like dirt. This game is someone's and like a group of someone's dream. They may not get patches out as fast as some other dev's but they also haven't abbandoned it like SO many early access games before them. I've been watching this game and sure it's taking a while but they are working on it. It is looking good slowly but surely. They're working hard a doing a damn fine job. If you really don't think so then why not try writing some lines of code to fix the issues you are having with the game yourself and submit it to then, and wait to see what conflicts it causes in the code. Then A) you could see just how long it takes to actually write the code and B) how it almost always creates more errors that will need fixing. And hey if you do a great job maybe they could use you or you could make your own game, who knows. You don't that's for sure, not till you try.to wrap up keep it up guys/gals ignore the haters and the nay sayers. The doom talkers and the ones who act holier than thou. They aren't making a game they aren't dealing with crap you are and they are just being plain old rude. As promised (key dramatic drum beat) BUM BUM BUM (Thank you band, I'd be lost without you) REVIEW TIME!!!!!!!!So been watching this game for a while, and as horrible as this may sound at first I ask you to hear it out, I even pirated this game when it had that short story with the monastery/temple thing in the snow with if memory serves were-wolves? I don't really condone piracy flat out but clearly not against it. It's a grey area for me. I believe in supportive piracy. Demo's don't really exist any more and the few that do are tailored to be as appeasing as possible which sometimes ends up being NOTHING like the game in question. So I coined the term supportive piracy, in which is you like what it was you pirated you go out of your way to support them by buying the program, movie or whatever and or donating too them the amount. Because if you support them they will make more of the things you like, and not go bankrupt. Rules for supportive piracy is if you find yourself playing it for the full story line and enjoying it. . . SUPORT ITFind your self playing it for more than 5 hours?. . . SUPPORT ITWhen back to play more after the first week you DL'd it. . . SUPPORT ITAny one of those equalls a support even if say you only played for an hour the first week then a week and a half (or longer) later you go back and play again. Yea that counts. Sorry rant. . .As I was saying I had pirated the game. It was lacking in content, and was over fairly shortly. But it had promise, still does.so I followed it on steam and added it to my wish list so I'd know if it went on sale. It did and my buddy gifted it to me, before I was ready to buy it and after I asked for a diff game.But I decided to try it out again it had been a while, a LOT had changed graphics are way better and the interaction with your citizens is really cool. the voice acting is fun and enjoyable and has that classic british. . . smart ace to it. Is there more to be done? Sure but it's coming along very nicely and i'm excited to see what they do. It's also going a diff way then I originally hoped it would but that's not surprising I have yet to find the game style I have envisioned in my noggin. As someone else had said it's a bit like banished but simpler. And not just in difficulty but also in concept. However also has different features, that being the exploring RPG elements that make the simpler city building aspect fit. I don't think the hard ships and deep intricacies that banished has would work well while you're out leading your troops in battle.All in all I'd say the game is very enjoyable For those wondering about the game concept in my nogginI guess the closest thing it would be is a castle/city builder. But builder is wrong word. . . more like upgrader. You take on the role of the person/thing/higher power? in charge. You don't control the movements of anyone (like in banished). You control what get's upgraded where funds go, perhaps the blacksmith which allows him to upgrade his furnace, or higher on additional help. Funds into captain of the guard so he can reinforce the walls with more guards or the barracks for having an army. You can also decide if certain upgrades need to be researched or if an attack is coming to call the citizens in behind the walls. As time goes on and the city grows outer walls would be made, your army goes out and secures roads from bandits. if you declare war your generals and armies attack but how and when they choose. your only concern is uprgrading the castle, city and such.

content:
Posted: February 26
Early Access Review
								Personally, I never check out Reviews on games submitted to Steam simply because I don't care to read negative comments or the ones that  feel more like rants to me. It's the game, not the player's opinions that makes me want to try it out. So I just go to You Tube to look for videos showing a players 'first-run' of games to see if anything might interest me. And that's just what happened for me when I found a 'Let's Try' You Tube video by VertigoTeaparty for Folk Tale. I was so excited about the city building theme blended with RPG elements I didn't hesitate to come here and buy it. I've been waiting for something like this for years and am so happy to be playing it now, bugs and all.If you're interested in this game remember it's still an Alpha game, it's still growing and constantly changing just like any small child. They both comes into the world all new, still growing and changing until they're full grown. It can take a long time, but it can be very rewarding to watch and experience the process along the way. I really enjoy this game and being a small part of it's growth by sharing any constructive feedback when I find what might seem like little odd bits and bobs. Maybe it's because I'm a Mom of 2 grown children and know what it's like to feel the pride and joy of watching something I had an important hand in helping them grow into mature adults, and how it can sometimes hurt when someone doesn't like what you've created just because it's young and not yet fully grown. In all, I really want Folk Tale to keep on growing  into a full fledged game that will be played and enjoyed by others looking for a unique gem of a game that I think this will turn out to be.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game this morning.  I've played for about 9 hours so far.  I maxed out everything in my village and have killed just about everything on the map.  It seems when you chop down trees you have to replant with seeds.  So far the only way I found to obtain seeds is to kill monsters.  Eventually the monsters no longer respawn and then you can't find any more seeds.  So you wind up running out of firewood, and your villagers declare that your village sucks (literally) and start to leave.  I was unable to find a way to reverse the mass exodus, and became frustrated.  I really want to like this game, and I hope eventually I will when the devs finish with it.  Right now it just seems there's no way to sustain a permanent village in sandbox mode, and that's unfortunate.  I am going to give this game a thumbs up regardless in hopes that things will change soon.  Its worth the $15 I paid for it on sale.  I wouldn't pay much more than that though.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Good Concept, excellent models and graphics, however lacks many things and has a few bugs, needs more balance. After i reach about 35 - 40 population things go haywire, stocks run low on everything no matter how much i supply, and if i manage to get stocks under control no matter how much I have stored i contantly get a flow of "running out of so-and-so, villagers need this, villagers need that" etc. A functioning supply chain for everything needed is difficult, as once you get enough villagers to work the proper amount of buildings for the supplies needed, there arent enough in each building to properly supply the amount of villagers total (I.e. 30 villagers total split between the many buildings sucha as farms, fishery, iron and stone mines, weavers and bakers and hunters and woodcutters, but with only 4 in each building they are unable to supply the amount needed for the population as a whole. Too few villagers with too high of demand split between too high of a variety of buildings, making it near impossible to have a steady supply chain.UI could use some improvement as well, need to go through many menus and options to do simple tasks for certain things like hire and fire workers from certain buildings, can't scroll through the list of available villagers to employ but have to choose from top three, when attempting to send your villagers to attack threats its difficult to select the threat nd not accidentally send your villagers to simply run past them to where you clicked, notices disspear to quickly for you to read what they are for, and there is a button up top to go to settings but not menu, being forced to hit the esc key in order to quit the game which is only minor but an annoyance.With improved functionality this can be a great game but as it is right now, hardly playable to past 30 or so villagers.

This game stinks of laziness from the devs side and because they got all the sales that they could have gotten, they don't feel the need to update this and give it more attention because again, its over.

content:

Early Access Review
								Folk Tale is shaping up to be a very good game. The developer responds to posts on the forums, regular weekly and monthly updates on the progress of the game, a breakdown of what they are currently working on, and next weeks tasks.The game is regulary updated, the developer asks for feedback on the the lastest patches, and responds to any issues discovered.The game is great, you get to build a township, fight the local beasts and enemies, now we are strating to get dungeon crawling as well. Recent patches have allowed you to build your township, pacify the area, then travel to the next area and build another township etc. You can send your heroes back and forth between sheets now.There is a inbuilt editor to design your own sheets and campaigns, there have been some really impressive buildings posted on the forum, and community made sheets/maps are starting to take off.The game is worth the price in my opinion, I am look forward to the next patch each time.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale is a fun city builder that puts you in the role of creating a town in order to help the citizens of the countryside recover after being exploited by bandits. You set off on your journey as you build lumber mills and stone works to collect the necessary resources for further your construction. Firewood, food, clothing, mead and many others resources are just a few of the things your citizens will want as you progress to a higher Culture rating. Your culture rating will determine the current needs of your people and when they will ask for the next set of items to keep them happy and working, fail to anticipate there needs could spell doom for your town, but be ever watchful as there are enemies all about just wanting for their time to take your city down. A RPG style of hero leveling allows for your characters to grow with you as you explore and build your way to victory.Pros:-	The beautiful graphics and music pulls you into the game and adds that immersion feeling as you delve ever deeper.-	The story is both well written and quite humorous at times, allowing you to grow a bond for the characters you control and care what happens to them as you make choices that will change the story line.-	The multiple choices you are presented with that can change the story from one play through to the next allow for the replay value to be quite high and very enjoyable.-	The controls of the game are quite easy to manage and allow for a very close view of your towns people or a high up god like view of your entire village.-	A simple at first building technique that opens up and becomes much more detailed as your understanding of the game grows, allowing for novice and expert players alike to find something here they can enjoy.Cons:     -	The game is still in early access so you are bound to find a bug or two from time to time. This isn’t so much a con as it is just a fact and often times doesn’t even factor into taking any of enjoyment away that’s to be had in the game.In conclusion, Folk Tale is a fun city builder that will take you through a journey you won’t soon forget, hours of fun building your cities will make your time here both enjoyable for those who like combat and for those who don’t. 4 out of 5.                                                                                                                                                                   AC-Gamerhttps://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLTyGAG_geVh6hZ5T_o3V9jTSsT_7IevXa

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game starts up well enough, even looks mighty impressive. However, there are some simple things to note even after over three years of early access. First of all, not everything is completed with in this game, ie, upgrades, units, buildings, quests, and such. The basics/core elements of game play with this game are not finished yet. Secondly, the story /quest line is no where near finished yet. The first bit is complete, and after three years seems to be bug free other than some loading issues on occasion when transitioning. The second quest/chapter is however riddled with bugs currently. From random allies attacking you to quests which cannot be completed due to a freezing in timers. Thirdly, in order to survive you will have to spend hours upon hours just setting up your village and nothing else. This is mostly in part due to the slow resource gain in comparrison to upgrade costs and villager demand. Resource gain is very slow and upgrade cost, even the beginning ones, is very expensive. Don't even think you will have any village defences until you have at least devoted four to six hours of play just building up your village.I really belive that this game has potential, but it's going to be a while before it is any where near complete. I would reccomend giving it a try if you are into beta's/alpha's and like to bug test things. But, as far as it being a playable game at this point, I am going to have to say it's a no go.

Early Access Review
								Folk tale is a fantasy RPG village builder, where you expand your village of peasant thriving market town, while  recruiting heroes, warriors and other worker to protect agents the evil.The game has a unique design, characters and is open for expanding, aswell for tax rating. The crafting system is a little bit annoying since it takes alot of your time. The sound of this game is really good, aswell for acting. But it's too "childish". The tutorial part gives a really good understanding about the dynamics about this game and how it should be running. Animations seems great, aswell for their running. It's looks funny. The controls of workers is great since you can pick anyone, and move him around or mark more at the same time. They do have looting inventory each of them. Upgrading buildings / expanding seems fine, but doesn't give as much profit or something like "5% building speed", since we have to buy additional upgrading seperated. - Which means, one skill at a time. So you can't make any "process three". The only negative thing i found about this game, is that there isn't any multiplayer. It would be a bit fun to play co-op or agens each other.Here is my old demo:

Early Access Review
								I waffled on getting this game because of the mixed reviews, but then it went on sale, and I read some of the more recent reviews, and I bought in.TLDR; BEST DECISION. DO BUY.The art style is great and cartoony and rich, the tutorial is very straight forward and helpful in getting you very comfortable with the controls and aspects of a successful town.I'm using the beta build and I've had no crashes, just the occasional bug report pop-up.It mixes the resource and micro-management that I love in Banished with a light RPG touch, complete with dungeon crawling missions and the ability to skill-up and equip your hero how you prefer.My ONLY complaint is that the campaign is incomplete - I want more! I got as far as possible in it and am looking supremely forward to more content being added, more dungeons and more campaigns.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first got this game in Early Access, I was intrigued. Not a lot was implemented, but I wanted to see where the game would go. After letting it sit for a while, I decided to pick it back up, and I've been pleasently surprised with how far the game has come. There's still a lot to be implemented, but this is a fun game overall. The graphics are good and the economy is fairly well balanced. The crafting system as of this review is still fairly basic, but both it and the building upgrade systems add depth. The music is quite nice and certainly adds to the experience. My one knock against the game so far is that the military units you can recruit are weak and, even with some in game improvements (armor and weapons), they do not stack up well to your opponents. So, while it's still very much a work in progress, it's a very playable, enjoyable work in progress.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is super fun! they blend several genres into one soo well. im not a huge fan on city builder RTS games but this game blends RPG elements into the mix and i love it! The project lead has weekly streams to give overview of new features, answer player's questions, and give sneak peaks at future features curently in development and direction they are going.The community involvment the developers take is unheard of in AAA titles and will even scrap a feature if players have issues with it. they have a clear timeline for future features and will look into any recomendations that the community gives if it has enough support and makes sence. the graphics are realy good kinda inbetween WoW and TES Skyrim, The animations are smooth and high quality. the camera contols take a bit to master at first but becomes easer the more you use them. the main gameplay has a slight learning curve to master with enimy atacks and exploration. the map designer is amazing  its easy to pick up and learn and the ability to make any landscape you want and play on the map is the best. the turrain is tile based not mesh so you cant fine tune certain aspects but the developers have included ALOT of tiles for many map features and have incuded props to add extra feartures you can add by hand.So I would recommend this game to anyone interested in the concept of a RPG-RTS game and would recomend watching the streams and go to the forums if your unsure, but you wont regret it.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								My first few hours on Folk tale is fun and disturbed at the same time. Tutorial is always what I go first and it left me with a bad impression with "Bob and a mouse." I need a straight forward tutorial, not that I hate the fact that the devs spent time making a story instead of a plain tutorial, but i just want to get into the game asap. So I kindda hate lengthy tutorial filled with texts, I had to read every words because I don't want to miss anything. Combat system is soso. I had a question with decisive victory skill though, it only deal 3 to 6 dmg even to a low health enemy when normal attack deal 20+ dmg. And if any heroes encounter combat anywhere on the main map, it said village is under attack. I read through review and comments, i saw someone said villagers will flee the battle when their health below 50% but that ain't happened in my case. Villagers fought to their death. And for the last thing to mention, I want an adjustable mini map, or a better one. I know you have UI scaling but I just only want a bigger mini map alone, everything else stay the same. I just bought Age of mythology a few days ago and its mini map work better than folk tale.Don't be mistaken, I don't hate this game. It looks like fun and has a good concept. But it still needs lots of work to make it shine. I will recommend only if I love it, but Folk tale is not there yet, just a good prospect with lots of potential.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's actually pretty awesome. Unlike some games that are alike this function to some degree as a realistic village. You can't just spam units because you can only support the population of your town which makes it far more realistic than some other RTS games. The game is just really limited. The campaign is alot of running between two places to talk to someone, but the gameplay overall provides enough to keep you busy. In addition, the sandbox mode needs some work. It includes the same people as the campaign but no one is good or bad, you have to kill everything on the map for some reason, no one is your ally. And sandbox is very limiting because after you annihilate your opposition with your one soldier, there's nothing else to do. No one attacks or anything. But overall, I love the economy system of managing a village and is why I recommend this game.

Early Access Review
								I played about 5 hours of this game straight through and felt as though I had a decent handle on the mechanics. I cannot, in good conscience, give this game a thumbs up at this time. The graphics and rendering were great, considering that it is an Early Access title. As always, a statement like that comes with some caveats.  This game has potential, however, it is essentially a Warcraft 3 map, with a world-map feature--- minus the "War" part of "Warcraft".It is a working title, and I expereinced no major bugs, crashes or hangups during my experience. Based on lack of content and replayability, I stand by my thumbs down.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
Early Access Review
								Still has a lot of potential as a mix of city/village building and ARPG.Good graphics and such, good mechanics and concepts, close to being very fun.  Played it through a bit of the campaign - so some of the items below I may not have seen yet.City building - relatively simplistic.   Tough to precisely place buildings, planting of saplings to keep trees going can obscure items/people.  Inherently I think I want roads, but goes against the current concept of just plopping buildings down.   I don't know why but I find it annoying to not be able to group things together easily like I want.   Might just be needing to work from the starting village and starting from a blank field may be better.  Anyway, personal preferences while it all 'works'.Action - Like the idea, concepts, etc.   Still feels cumbersome to control units and use abilities.   Can hotkey unit groupings to number keys, but can also use number keys to assign skills.   Missing something with the multiple heroes and abilities - think it needs a tab to next character in the group.Itemization is tough so far, but think I'm early enough that it may change.  I've found the 3rd hero and killed the dragon but only have 3 uncommon items so far.   Would be very useful if the non-equip able items greyed out when changing hero selection.   Alternatively let anyone wear anything with stat requirements.Stats are underwhelming.   Leveling up is underwhelming.Think it would be much better to be able to pick your starting hero and skill them up yourself.  Still keep it simple, but give some level of customization.I'll play it a bit more and then maybe wait for the next update.1/12/17 update:Experimental build update helped quite a bit - pause, better balance.  Also played the sandbox mode, liked that quite a bit.   Odd mechanic to start over on a new map though - doesn't seem like you really need to do anything since heroes don't need upkeep.   So, really - what's the point of building a town other than maybe crafting?    Still missing something - played a couple hours a few times now and I want to explore the map, so that's good.   Think there should be more/better encounters.   I don't care about stats/RPG aspect that much, think that should be tweaked.  Maybe extend the # of levels and add skill adds/increases.    Itemization is meh still.   I got 4 rare items!  They're all worker equipment :(  Haven't built a single military unit yet.  Haven't felt the need.No real challenge to building a good economy, unless you forget to build the distribution building like i did a few times.Wish I'd gotten it on sale, but not that sad if they keep up with the updates.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
Early Access Review
								Great game. Build your city and play a party of heroes, like only few other games out there. In your city, you'll research, collect and work on resourses, recruit, equip items, even do some crafting and build defense turrets and so on. Furthermore, in campaign mode, you can find a somewhat rich and somewhat long history, in which heroes will join your party while you interact with their original tribes. There's also a sandbox mode available to explore. And, although it's in alpha, there's a tutorial.Since the game isn't finished, there's still work to do, like implementing turrents and more heroes on sandbox mode, balancing/limiting respawns of monsters around city, balancing the army's strength so it can be more useful, maybe adding some more depth to the strategy/citybuilding dimension of the game, implementing a hotbar for better use of heroes' skills, adding a pause option etc.The game has been in alpha for too long and there's still work to do. But I can understand that: I think the game is so far great and there's originality in it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
Early Access Review
								Not one for leaving reviews, however after 6 hours today I have to say for an early access game it's great... yes there's bugs and a few aspects of the game that needs improving; but I expect that for any early access, so I can ignore them and look at the bigger picture.StoryTwo sides to choose from the outset story wise, so a welcoming replay value I am sure.  But for me it’s the wit in the writing; it’s great and refreshing for a game not taking itself seriously. I like and a few laughs while playing today. The tutorial was entertaining as well.... And I have to say that for an RPG game not being over the top with Dialog and no side quests (some games can over do it with side quests), it works and I feel the town building aspect works well to fill the void.GraphicsOk for someone with a 980TI I am all about the visuals, however I like the graphics. Simple yet detailed at the same time. Hats off to the games artist, “I like your style”. It is a good looking game. Game playSo the RPG aspect is fun, but i will say that I am all for the town building game play... its great and if you like Banished, Black & White etc. This game is for you. Learning how to play, the tutorial for once doesn’t spoon feed you and its refreshing once again to explore how to really play the game which I miss to be honest from games today... Only aspect i have found is missing is class selection of town folk for example, selecting all the soldiers rather than drawing a box hoping you get the soldiers to protect your town and you send half of the village into war by mistake. But if that’s my only concern with this EARLY ACCESS game then I will stand by my opinion. Its great, it’s refreshing, it’s a beautiful artistic game, great wit & narrative and its beyond addictive (6 hours straight). I will say though, you need to like RGPs and town builders games to enjoy this... both elements work hand in hand therefore if you are not a keen RPG’er than you won’t enjoy the game. But thumbs up from me and looking forward after work tomorrow to sit down and have a play!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								So far, this title has been well worth the sale price.It's a nice combination of RTS city building and RPG adventuring.  Great graphics and I like the humor element.  I've felt that the game has very high immersion potential.Some minor complaints would include the lack of good camera controls.  It is difficult to quickly change camera angles when your characters get into a fight which limits your ability to control individual actions for your characters.  The result is that pretty much every fight turns into one big Mongolian Cluster Click.  It would be great if the game engine used some kind of standard click and drag method to change camera views, like so many other games use.  Also, there's no way that I've seen to center the camera view on the characters, so when you get involved with the city management, it's easy to lose track of where your characters are and it can take a few minutes to locate them.  Some way to auto-center the camera view on them would be great, or even if their symbol on the overview map was a little different from the rest of the villagers that would be a big help.Overall this is a really good game, though.  I'm having a very good time with it and can't wait to see future developments.

number of helpful: 13 of 28 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Note to Developers---This has been an amazing Journey watching development of this game for the past two years. I bought into this game because I enjoyed the concept of what Games Foundry wanted the game to be.  Since the past two years there have been plenty of additional content added that was not anticipated and at the same time some content has sadly left. These changes do not diminish the dream that was two years ago, but development continued to adapted and has now given great depth to what is currently and what will be a great game.I admit that I do not play each update, but with how well they keep the interested community informed, I don't have to play to know whats going on. With each Twitch broadcast I can speak about development and ask question if I have any. I can review Game Foundrys website(Which I do more often) and look at the road map and read the patch notes. These things are a huge asset to me and I can't wait to see when the game enters a more complete state. Please keep heart and know there are people that look forward to seeing your dream come to light. Well done lads.----- End----Org. Review----I don't rate games very often because I never want to spend the time or because the game really isn't worth a review from me. In the case of this game, I feel its necessary to to at least give this game a thumbs up and say a thing or two as to why.   Too many people gave this game a thumbs down because the game is incomplete and taking a little longer to make then some of you out there may be comfortable with. Giving a thumbs down for that reason is ridiculous and juvenile. This game is nothing short of an accomplishment for Games Foundry, even in its infancy this game continues to deliver. You'll find updates in their store page, Twitch video updates and detailed information on what each update consist of on their website. The "I want it now Daddy" mentality wont get you anywhere with this game if were going to get what Games Foundry as in store for us.  Also its not even in BETA! They're still making the dang game! So Shut it with all the complain about how the game isn't even playable. Nuff said.  As this isn't really a review about the game I guess I should add a little something about the game. Simply put, I'm optimistic and excited to see the final product.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Its been 1 year since I last wrote a review of this game.  At the time I was very angry about a lot of things.  first being the fact that shortly after backing it.  I found myself un-able to play it at all.  Last week after the patch 0.3 I got my first crack at actually playing the game and walking thru the in game tutorial.   I was shock!  Finally I could understand and play the game with easy.  No more broken basic needs.  Or at least I didn't encounter any.  Last year I would not recommend this game to anyone.  For fear of losing a friend.  The game was so flustrating.  Most of the common stuff was broken or not even there at all.   Today I found it playable and while I think the game progression is rather slow.  I am happy to say its been worth the wait.   I feel a lot of folks will not know what to do with this game though.  Do you play it like warcraft 3 build a economy and conqueer X enemy?  Not so much.  Its more on the lines of Banish I think.  Like a sim settlement builder type of thing.  In the near future that will probably change with heros, and dungeons coming in to play.   I would recommend this on 2 things.  First they dev's have a monthly blog supporting the up comming ideals and fixs, and second its fun to play.  Don't take my word on it.  Get out there and give it a try!  Write your own view and claim the New world for your villagers!  Woohoo!

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
Early Access Review
								Really enjoying the game so far! It's sort of a cross between Warcraft 3, Age of Empires 2 and Civilisation. Maybe even a little bit of Diablo in there too. I've only played the campaign so far but I'm hooked.On the one hand, you are busy building things to keep your people happy and get a nice little city going and on the other, you are taking your heros off on well scripted and engaging adventures. It feels like a full and solid world and so far I have felt really immersed.Being early access, the game is not without its faults (spider attacks come thick and fast and your peasants and early army can't do much about it - you have to call your heros back to town to deal with them. Also tooltips could do with being a little more in depth) but it is definately a solid base from which to move forward and refine. For such a small dev team (only five of them I think), the game at the moment is something they should be really proud of and I hope they keep evolving it as time goes on (keep up the great work guys!).If you are thinking of buying it and enjoyed the games I mentioned above, definately give it a go.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you ever wanted to take a city building sim to the next level and actually have a hand in the individual lives of it's occupants, Folk Tale actually delivers. Folk Tale came across my screen one day and I was very impressed by it's intended scope so I immediately purchased it in early access. It's been a year since then and I can honestly say this game has come a long way. It's an incredibly ambitious game. No other city sim comes close to the complexity of strategy and rpg elements as Folk Tale in my opinion. It's beautifully rich in detail in respect to both graphics and game play. It fills a depth nitche that was absolutely missing in Banished. Having each individual in your village have a character sheet and equipment can feel a little overwhelming at first, but once you become familiar with how the game is played it's much easier to manage. I can honestly say I never expected this game to get here. It's worth every penny and then some. If you like city builder and rpgs you HAVE to give this a try. There is truly nothing else like it. While it's still a ways out from completion, the potential for greatness is OBVIOUS! :)

content:
Posted: March 9
Early Access Review
								I purchased this game quite a while ago, before the switch to the current Sandbox version. I liked it then and I like it now. I was looking for a city builder - with something more, and that's what I have gotten. My husband is a Skyrim fan, but I wanted something lighter; I am a casual player, and for me this is it. I also play Banished, but enjoy the humor and missions of Folk Tale.Yes, development is taking a long time. I play for a while, complete what is new, then I will go on and play something else for a while. When I remember and come back around, suprise - there is always something new. Last time I played turrets and walls had been disabled, this time there are new walls, gates, etc - and they work. And now there is fire - which I hate because it makes me look like a crazy person to my kids as I am yelling at the computer screen for the villagers to put the fire out! I do miss the giant snails, though.Over all I like this game, I understand why some are upset in the length of time development is taking, I guess I'm just not as bothered by that.

content:
Posted: March 25
Early Access Review
								ive been playing this style of game for a long time favorites such as black and white, warcraft and starcraft. This game is excellent honestly. It's one of the only games if not the only currently that continues this style of gaming. Warcraft was excellent because you got to be attached to you're favorite hero and level them up plus gear them. It felt fun and was a blast building a town to boot. Black and white is one of my favorites simply because the city building is so much fun. I love to grow the town and either become a utopia or turn into a fortress for war. This game continues on these charactistics. And to be honest does a pretty damn good job conisdering how large of a project this really is. There is far more in depth tools to ultlize and work with as you expand and conqure. However, this game truely needs to be tweaked around the balancing of AI, and looting. I mean it's pretty crap. You can run around a enemy in a circle and heal then rengage and win. The loot is always crap or it is for sir g. No good loot for fellow heros you pick up on the way AT ALL. So annoying. Tired of gearing my settlers with all the♥♥♥♥♥♥i get because my heros get nothing. The other A.I needs to become a living AI. not this dungeon stuff we are seeing. I want to see a town expanding and pressuring us to either progress and fight, or ally and work for. It can be done just needs something. Farming spiders, crabs, and other wild life is only so fun for so long. Id like to feel challenged with more decisions that lead to other results and not only one path dialogs. There are 4 options you choose everyone you want besides the answer, and it always makes you refer to what the game wants you to pick. Why even include the dialog then? -Noted Bugs-Weapons do not scale damage proporely on villagers and heros. -Repeated loot drops with no variations. -Dialog audio shutting off around End of Act I-Rocks, and landscape block buildings from being built in odd ways. -Disengage and re-engage do not reset enemies, this results in auto health regen for heros and not mobs. -Market does not provide needed resourses for posion potions, and upgraaded variations of health and mana potions. -Inproper seeding of need herbs.As i play more and promote more players to test the game i will update my orginal review.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stop taking your time. I have had this game since you was able to buy the game, I played it and by god i LOVED what i saw and it's potential, and couldnt wait to see the end product but realised that wouldnt be for a year. One year on you decided you would atleast have sandbox mode ready and able then move on to career mode, ok great, you still had a overall 'Very Positive' User review at that point, its now been what almost 4 years or more and you've had a HUGE boost in income to help pay the busy lil' workers, good feedback from the player base, yet still your dragging your heels using the excuse of "We want to do this right" which to start with was ok, but now we know it to just be code for "Were just gonna keep telling you BS because we have no good resaon as to why we can't be bothered", and now you have a Mixed User rating with over 770 reveiws if you have bothered to look lately, quickly becoming a rating of Very Poor, and then soon your gold mine will dry up and at which point you will be stuck trying to fill the promise of a great game with no income because no one else will be buying your game. There is soooo much more I could say but i think you get the point of what I am trying to say, and you only have to look at the reviews to see that I am right. It would be a shame to see this game go to waste because someone else or some other Company was able to take your concept and get a product out there for people to play a version of your game, and then you would be left in the dust with nothing but an alpha game shelved to show for your troubles.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game a while ago and played a fair few hours on the Sandbox mode. I have to say that while sometimes gameplay can be buggy it's an absolute gem. The development team have done a wonderful job of mixing a civil builder with RPG elements, you'll actually give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about your town/villagers and heroes. So far I've started let's playing the campaign on my youtube channel, thecoope550, and I love it. The humour is there, the story elements are there too. The only downside I've got with the game is that I haven't worked out how to build roads in the campaign mode yet, but I'm sure I will at some point. The economy system is clever, and follows a logical path for example you can't make pies without meat and flour it's not too difficult to pick up but at the same time if you don't do things in a sensible and logical order then you're peasents will leave and you'll end up♥♥♥♥♥♥creek without a paddle. In short it's the best £15 I've spent and the game isn't even finished yet. If they even put in a multiplayer system where you choose either a hero or to lead a town it'll truely be somthing spectacular. I've still got to test out the world editor but it's on my to-do list! Thanks for reading!

Early Access Review
								I bought this game back in June of 2013. Immedietaly after buying it I regretted it. That version of the game was bad. Now, fast forward to March of 2016. I decided to download it again after having not touching it for almost 3 years, due to the new screenshots I saw on the store page. I have been playing it for about 2 hours now and wow have they improved this game. The combination of village building, equipment to be found and equipped on everybody (villagers too), and dungeon exploration with your heroes is great! It reminds me of the early Settlers games, or the old game Knights and Merchants.Pros: Nice graphicsFully customizable charactersFree building, build where ever is the best spot for the buildingDungeon/Cave exploration is a good break from the normal gather/buildCons:It took them three years to get where they are now, so progress is a little slow, but it is thereWhen all is said and done, I would say to grab a copy of this. If you are worried about the price then just wait until there is a sale to see if it goes on sale on Steam. Otherwise I still think it is worth the price in its current state.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								At first in alpha, it's not going to be good. Not bug reporting I could see as the first openning page showed it was in Alpha. But no bug reporter in the game as far I saw; or no comment section about how to make the game better. Which would be nice. First time I played didn't played nesscially play correctly, and taxed my people. Second time went much better; food and resources are your primany starting assets. Of course if you can review my second game of it. I did much better and improved after about 40 minutes of playtime. I acctually liked the game more than then many in the genre. Graphics silmiar to World of Warcraft, yet that was some 10 years ago. Cartoonish yes. My kids could learn a lot about how much would it take a long long time ago to build an empire or a village. Although very boring if you don't use your hero to explore. Which I liked. To gain food from the start; it helps gives something to do while your people work. BUT DON'T FORGET ABOUT THEM, haha. Some werid things with how the game is played. I didn't like how I "techicnally" took over a an old builiding that looked like a mine. I personally think; there should be more like as it appered to be a mine. Which I could used. A of now in my second game, so far I got an extra pheasent. I like how easy access the game is. Very easy for kids to understand and think. "Well, If I save enough wood and stone, I could get..."  All builings mostly unlocked and yes, there are builinding options. One thing that would be exciting after playing for just 40 minutes; Is how deep the game could actually go. I played on easy. Normally I start games playing Hard. But have learned to play easy first to make it simple to go from easy to hard; then to medium and crush medium. But getting an exrta pheasent. Very Very usefull. I'm thinking of adding in another cottage just to see if gets more pheasents. Because they can work from the lumbermill or whatver it's called or the stone mason which give more resources. I also saw that the woodcutter's plant tree's. Yet, my fishwoman caught loads of fish and then would have to travel. So it's a game about location, location, location. Because if I do get exrta pheasents, which come by their own accord. Then it would be useful to have them pick ujp surranding exrta picking up things; food, wood, and stone. Yet again 40 minutes in Alpha 25 or 26 and I love it. Very rare for me to play a game and still want to play more of it, normally after I play I ponder how to play correctly. Almost like an addiction to video games to me again; coming back. Normally I'll play a few hours and then ponder and analize how I played. But this game is different it draws you in. Especially if your into RPG's villiage, city buildiers from an older time. Which I prefer. Tropico 5 is a very complicated game compared to this. This lays everything out for you. May take 3-4 times to get the hang of it. BUT PLAY EASY. And dev's don't speed up. Even it takes a couple or LESS years, haha. Take your time, Take you time; Good game I would pay $50-60 for. Which is very rare for me. But 24.99 for Alpha. A little steep. 19.99 would have been better. Remeber one comment box and you'll get a whole lot of advice, or bug reporter. Also remeber stick to your roots about those comments some mjean, some harsh; some useful; some actually from other players' who made the game with you. TO ALL DEVOPLERS DON'T DO EVERYTHING THEY WANT YOU TO DO OR IT MESS UP THE WHOLE GAME.

Early Access Review
								Love this game so far!  Beautiful graphics, fairly intuitive GUI (takes a little getting used to, then it's second nature).  Would love to see an addition of a way to scroll back through system messages.  Currently, the controls setup is that panning is controled via keyboard and zooming is controled by mousewheel.  Would be nicer if those were reversed.  Also, the hero's controls are a bit clumbsy... would be nice to be able to set his actions to the number bar on the keyboard.  Click/Point takes away some of the immersiveness.  I'm really enjoying this game overall.  I've played through the tutorial, and tried out the sandbox a bit... currently running through the campaign.  Keep up the good work!  Looking forward to updates.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
Early Access Review
								The Short- very good hybrid of RTS / RPG / Dungeon Crawler / Roguelike  The Long- I bought this game a while back, I think over 2 years ago? When I did it was still in beta and was actually bad; just a bear-bones tutorial with no save feature. I don't remember if Steam had the Refund thing at the time but honestly..if they did I may have refunded. I'm glad I didn't.    I decided on a whim to reinstall after reading dev updates. So far I am very pleased.    The devs have really broke the mold on Folktale- there is quirky graphics, humor ( plenty of that), RTS fighting, city-building and management...and....dungeon crawling.    You have "heros" that do the actual dungeons, and man these folks are quirky with a big "Q". The fighting can get a tad crazy at times as there is no pause feature ( mores the pity; at the time of this writing the Devs have said there will not ever be) but you can, however, just hit ESC if you need a break.    I still think a pause feature, just for dungeons, would have been a good idea. Your peasant population will actually gang up on enemies and are very effective ( and funny; scroll ALL THE WAY down during a fight for some funny dialogue)    The game is still in early release, and I hope the devs can keep up the good work.         1 / 1/ 2017  Rivscore-  86 / 100

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've had this game sitting in my Steam game list for about a year. I wanted to wait until it got a little deeper into development. I feel as though I can really give this a proper review now however. (Note my hours are not correct by any means. I actually have around 30 hours) The game can be compared to games such as The Settlers. I've always liked City Building games such as this, but they always lacked a flair of life, and they tended to have over complex mechanics for late game that made it more of a chore than a game, and really killed the fun. Even though those games aren't particularly hard, the "jump through 5 hoop resources to get what you want" just isn't that fun to me. Take Settlers 5 for instance. Why do certain soldiers need extra good food? Doesn't make sense to me outside of "throw something in to make it more difficult and extend the gameplay". City Building: Folk Tale as of right now. Does not do that. Food of any type is used to feed any villager. Pubs, etc increase happiness. Simple. Of course there is still balancing to be done in terms of needs, but this game isn't focused just on "get x resource to get x unit" like other city builders. Hence why the "City Building" and sustaining can be more simple. The real meat of the game is around this bone structure. This doesn't mean there aren't chains of course. You need wheat and water to make bread, meat to make meat pies, and the like, however there aren't any requirements or units which require these foods to unlock or use. Buildings will eventually be able to be upgraded, research can be done in every building to increase the towns prosperity and increase production. Walls, Towers and gates can be built just about anywhere except on sheer cliffs (straight vertical) As I said though. This is simply the bone of the game, the meat is in the rest. The RPG SideThis is where this game will be shining the most. The town building is cute, fun, and immersive, and this just adds the cherry ontop. Each NPC can be given items and equipment. You can build armor and weapons at the blacksmith and give each of your soldiers individual equipment, rings, boots, etc. Give your Captain a special helmet to make him stand out etc. The Peasants and normal workers also can be done doing the same. They will fight if need be, and can be given orders. Or they'll do what they need to do for whatever job you gave them, and go about their daily lives. The beasts, monsters, and such also live their own lives. They will expand and grow. They will make new dens, and increase the area where they wander. They will eventually if left unchecked butt heads with you if you don't keep the outskirts of your town in check.  ----------------------------------------------There are MANY things to come in Folk Tale, including: Interiors for buildings, New Area's. Linked Maps, Dungeons to send heroes and adventurers, Dungeons to clear out with your soldiers, New Buildings, and much more that will add depth and immersion. Last but definetly not least. The developers are excellent at listening to the community, responding to the community, and letting us know what they are doing and focusing on. They have laid out the road map for the game, and all the features they wish to impliment, and when they will be implimenting them, and so far they have kept to that road map perfectly. If you're interested in games such as this. The risk of this being another fail start game is extremely low, with no chance of the developers going dark with no word.

Early Access Review
								I'm not going to bash the negative reviewers because a few of them actually made sense and weren't just zero bombing.I for one, actually enjoyed this game. Even though it has been in my in for two years, I still like to come back to it from time to time to see what’s changed. As some of the negatives have said, there hasn’t been any ground breaking patches to where it jumps the game close to release, but hey, the devs are active and not giving up on their game, which is rare considering I've seen a few games go from amazing, to abandoned in less than a year or two.  So in some way, I can agree with the negative reviewers saying there hasn’t been a lot, because hey, I would like to see more too, but we aren't dealing with EA here.Now what I can't agree on is the negatives saying "I wasted my money on this game", "Before you say "Early Access Game" save your money it's not worth it.". I'm just going to say it...it's an Early Access Game. A lot of games aren’t worth their prices, for example, Call of Duty being 100bucks for a full game...not worth it, but some may think it is. And for the "I wasted my money" people, you "wasted 25 bucks"...that’s 3 hours of work. Also, it is an Early Access Game meaning you are choosing to pay the price of the game to aid in the development of the game. Honestly, now a days, EAGs and Kickstarters alike are a gamble because you never know if the devs will abandon it or not. So what do you do? Just make a decision, do you want to see this game become complete? Or can you live without it. If you are truly a gamer, you want to see a game you are interested in succeed and you won’t give up on it because it is taking a while. To put it in perspective, World of Warcraft took more than 5 years to develop...and it was developed with an already established gaming company with a huge dev team. So 2 years of a game with probably 1/6th of the staff isn’t bad for where the game is. You just have to look at it from a different angle.All in all, I agree and disagree with the Reviewers but I still will recommend this game, especially since it's on sale atm, because of the dedication on the dev team alone and the fact that I'm a gamer and I want to see games blossom!Do what you want, but remember, you are helping DEVELOPE a game, you are not buying a complete game. It will take time for it to be finished, are you ready for the long haul?

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								After having my opinion shrouded by the forum moderators a couple of times and by the fanatic community it self, I've decided to voice my opinion here. This game is far from ready. Having bought this game within the first couple of weeks of its release I am appalled by the lack of progress and content that has been added to this game. Being released over 16 months ago and having little to none progress to show for it, I feel like I've been utterly ripped off. The game is not ready and is a long way to go before completion. The dev state that this game is 46% playable in its current state, a state which is missing a core component of its gamely. Sandbox mode. The only update I've seen happen in the last year is a slummy map and character editor being added to the games content. A feature which is utterly useless considering you cannot play the game at all. The only feature which you are able to access is the tutorial mode which has a buggy save system. The idea for this game is rather good, which was one of the main reasons which compelled me to buy this title in the first place. Even though I am fully aware that this game is an INDIE title in the ALPHA stage, I am utterly appalled by the lack of progress and at the same time amazed by how well the developers are doing. Constantly updating their blogs and making new videos and moderating the forums. Maybe if they spend less time on the forum and editing their blogss and videos and more time on the game, we would see some progress. Do not buy -A
