content:
Posted: February 27
Early Access Review
								A long, long time ago...A knight set foot into a village which was attacked by bandits, business as usual it seemed.So the knight draw his sword and drove the thieves out.The village folk cheered at first, but were afraid that the thieves might return.The knight listened to the worried people and decided to stay, just in case.That wasn't the end of the story.The mayor asked the knight to help him rebuild the village, an unusual task for a knight, but you get your quests where you get them.The knight built houses for the people, woodcutters' homes, mines etc. People seemed to be happy, praised the Holy Toast, went on their business and raised a mug of mead every now and then.That sounds easy in the beginning, but the knight noticed, that some of the townfolk acted erratic.Fields were standing in full bloom, but nobody was harvesting them for a while, people were more interested in filling their bellies than honest work.That changed for the better after a while. A LONG while.At one point the knight realized this quest might take forever, so he went down on his knees and prayed to the Holy Toast for guidance.And the Holy Toast answered "Don't give up yet, the powers in control will not let you down, be patient."And the knight asked "How much longer ?"The Toast replied "Haven't you seen them doing their work ? Haven't you noticed the change for the better ?"The knight nodded.The Toast went on "Don't get me wrong, child, though they are the ones in control, but they are only a few. You... and your quest were not forgotten." A pause "And they know they sent you on your quest too early, far too early"The knight remained silent, so the Toast went on."Don't you like it here ? The people are hard working but cheerful. Granted they have an immense appetite, but still"The knight nodded again.The Toast continued "And from what I can see, you keep yourself busy as well, bandits, wolves and even finding new friends along the way, what an illustrious bunch you have there"The knight got up from his knees and kicked some dirt "I know you're right, I will try to keep my patience, thank you Holy Toast"The Holy Toast smiled, or at least it seemed like it, you can never be sure with toast."Your patience will be rewarded, child, just don't give up hope" and with an uncharacteric pop the Toast vanished into thin air.------To cut a long story short:This game is in EA forever. The devs acknowledge they went into EA far too early, but there is still a LOT of communication going on between the team and the players.Still, what is in the game is fantastic, if you are looking for something to scratch your Settlers or Spellforce itch.It is well served with humor and a good graphic.The progress dev-wise is slow, yes, but they listen. As mentioned above there are improvements made to the villagers behaviour which resulted from the exchange between the programmers and the audience.I enjoy what I have seen so far.A recommendation from me, yes, but only for people that can be patient and let the devs do their work.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								TLDR not worth the price, large scope slow updates, half finished implementations22/01/2016 UpdateIf its any indication I brought a game called Crashlands and  played that the same amount of hours in a week that I have played this game in 3 years and that comes down to playable content, there is just not enough in this game. No updates still in the same condition as months ago. So much promised content but nothing works when implemented the scope for this game has just grown out of proportion.Always hopefully and after so long in EA I figured surely by now they would have some semblemence of a nearly complete game. Unfortunately this is not the case. While that have added in a small questline, the issue is that it is very small and also buggy. Buttons still don't work.Progress on this game is so slow, the developers seem to spend more time writing long blogs about the changes they are making vs actually working on the game. Not worth the price.Update 28/3/15 after leaving this game for up to 6 months i figured the devs would have had time to flesh it out a bit. Sadly it is still fill of broken features, now there all these shiny new buttons that dont actutally work.The game has a small amount of playable content but with no real direction and alot of the features still not working it gets boring pretty quick.  Very slow development. I would still not recommend.Previous review from about June 2014:At first glance this game looked really enjoyable the tutorial was fun and and interesting with a little bit of everything.you got to start building a town and learn what the different buildings did, you got to make an army and go on a action filled adventure killing all sorts of monsters. The tutorial introduced a game I thought I could really get into.Sadly the actual game is nothing like the tutorial. Currently there is only a broken sandbox mode, half the buttons don't work, the controls are different to the ones you use in the tutorial so you have to learn what the new ones are. With the majority of the building and character controls, even menus not working the sandbox mode is very limited.The tutorial is misleading and suggests the game is something it is not. The development is slow and all around sandbox.Not worth the price.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have had this since the Early Release Edition and I finally got to see the end results of waiting. First the Pro's: Easy to learn reminds me alot of Age Of Empires where you collect resources. Reminds me of Colonization where settlers come over when you are doing good:) I went and tried the tutorial and it helped me with 90% of the game.  You can assign any inactive to any job & you can change them up.Now the Con's You really have no way of knowing how many peasants are inactive until you want to build and there is no way you can call them over to any 1 spot where you can assign them tasks. Also you really can't tell how your research is going accept that it tells you when you are done. Unlike Civ series where it tells you how many turns left to get to your ending reseach.Over all it feels like Civ series but on a smaller scale. With a little more work it could be a Fun  game without the frustration you may feel from time to time. Is it worth the asking price maybe. Depends how you like the Civ Series:)Overall I would give the game a 8 out of 10. Nothing more then that though at this time:)

number of helpful: 12 of 28 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale has been one early access game that at the moment I can say is really how all early access games should be made. The communication between the developer and the community is fantastic to say the least, probably the best I've seen yet. The game itself goes through regular substantial updates that actually add real content to the game (surprising I know). Even though right now the game has plenty of content to play and enjoy, especially with the recent 3.0 update, every update moves the game forward to being better and better. The game is great now and I honestly cannot wait until it's finished and is an amazing game!*Edit* And to all the reviewers stating that "this isn't the game they bought 2 years ago" or that "I thought it would be a story but they took that all out for nothing", these developers (unlike many in early access) actually put forward a choice to their community. They set up a survey for everyone to take to get their input on the direction the game should follow http://blog.gamesfoundry.com/2014/05/folk-tale-player-satisfaction-survey.html and really listened to those who were playing the game. SO all these people complaining here, this wasn't the devs who suddenly felt the need to take out your favorite part of the game, it was the community saying it wanted more sandbox and village management over story. How can you blame video game developers for wanting to please the people who actually play their video game?

content:
Posted: March 2
Early Access Review
								Having purchased more than a few Early Access games i can say that Folk Tale is among the best Early Access games, with surprisingly high quality of content, good stability and few bugs. It receives steady updates with improvements to existing features and addition of new features. This has been the case since the very first release which was basically a demo, after which development was essentially started from scratch.  Many EA games are said to have "potential" - which is usually said in contrast to a myriad of problems that those games have. Although Folk Tale is obviously far from perfect simply because it is not yet finished, this game does not just have potential, it also is of high quality and very much looks like it will deliver.

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale is a game where you build a Village and have Heros go into Dungeons and find epic loot for you to take Home and be used by your Village. I bought this game a week ago and saw what I have to saw, I saw everything it had to offer. The Campaign, the Sandbox. All was boring. I even tried to subscribe to workshop mods but when I try to load a few, I crash instantly. Don't get me wrong, the concept of Folk Tale is amazing. I like it where it's like Diablo but you can build a Huge City while your Heros go into Dungeons and find loot. Building in this game is quite similar to the game Banished. However, the game is mostly aimed at City Building. But it doesn't have that feel, you should have more buildings that your Colony actually needs. The game just doesn't have that challenge. Like for example, just put down one wood cutter and in a few hours of gameplay you should have 3.0k Wooden logs and 3.0k Fire wood. Literally, that's how easy the game can be while you wait for things to get produced. The combat in this game is fairly decent, however there is still some flaws. Your Hero can easily get overpowered by a Spider Queen. Literally, they should not. Spider Queens are common and should be weaker than your Heros, they will also attack your Village as well, killing most or all of your Villagers in a second. I also HATE the fact that automated defenses you put in *e.g Turrets* have a limit to how many can be placed. The limit should not exist, Engineers should be able to place as much Turrets and traps as you want. They don't maintence or give ammo to them, so why bother give them a limit? One other issue is that your Villagers will consume resources fast. Faster than you can produce most of the time. Literally, it tooked me three hours to find out how to make more basic clothes than what will be produced in the future. Oh, almost forgot. If you are unlucky, Spider invaders or others will kill your Villagers that have important jobs. Your Villagers should flee from incoming enemies, not retaliate. They should just let them destroy their buildings, who cares? They should shout out for help so nearby City watchers and other combat units will hear and approach who said help. This is the reason why your Villagers die so quickly and all of your Cities needs are easily overused. Now, the AI. The AI is terrible in this game. When there is literally trillions of friendlies attacking a enemy. Your Hero will not attack and just walk away if the enemy attempts to walk closer for a attack. Their special abilties work, however they will not attack regulary, rendering them useless. This also happens to other friendly NPCs and your Villagers. Now, my final problem. Not a lot of players may not like just sending your Heros to Dungeons and other areas. You should be able to claim Dungeons, for example. Make it your mining facility, or JUST plain another Village there. You should also be able to send Combat Villagers with your Heros. I hate sending only my Heros. I would love to see if my Combat Villagers will follow my Heros, even to Dungeons and other areas. In conclusion, I never write bad reviews but this one deserves one. I do however blame the Developers for not adding those simple features, it's just common sense, why not add those I just said. I certaintly hope the Developers will see this review and fix bugs and add new features in I just addressed, then I will change my review to positive. For now, don't buy this game. The Developers haven't been adding good features for a while and they deserve a review that addresses this issue. Do not buy this game, it's not worth your money for now.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is not worth it right now, if I could do it over I would not bought into this game. I don't have a problem with how slow the updates are coming out, for me I voted on this game when it was in green lit I liked the vision they had and that's the game I wanted to play. So as soon as it was released I got it. My problem with the game is this is not the game I bought, their vision has changed alot since green lit, mostly because the community wanted the game changed to a sand box game. That's not what this game was going to be, they where going to add a sand box game play maybe at the end of devlopment, now that's all the games about this is not what I paid for. Getting community opinions is one thing & making minor changes is ok I am all for that, but changing the game in the ways that they have changed is not fair to the people who bought into the origanal vision of this game. In time this may be a great game if it's the kind of game you want to play, for me I will have to wait and see. I would wait until it is alot more developed before invisting in this game, who know's what other changes are in store for the future.Ok I did what Games Foundry asked me to do in the comments. I gave the game another try. Even putting my previous grips aside about them making it a sandbox game first and taking away the story and choices your where going to have to make, I gave it a go.After spending a couple of hours playing it, I still cant recommend this game. Yes they have added more to the game then just a tutorial. As an RTS you have very little control of the game. You have no lists I cant tell who is doing what and who is doing nothing. I dont even have a way to click and bring all of my gaurds together at one point. In a game like this I need to click on list so I can oversee everything not just click on random buildings to get info for it. The way people move around to do stuff you lose track of who is where and finding them can get faustrating. Just like I want to click on something and bring all none working peasants to a single place so I can look over their stats and decide what to do with them and that cant be done easily if at all.The game world looks nice and the game runs smooth graphics are nice. For me graphics dont mean much I dont care about eyecandy if I have a good playable game that is fun. Right now it is a good looking game with no real game play and clunky controls without any real way to manage your town.Sorry I still cant recommend the game and it has nothing to do with the fact it aint the game a bought when it was released. I tried to give it a fair shake anyway and as it stands it still needs alot of work and the player needs to have alot more control of everything.

number of helpful: 13 of 31 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has been released on early access for over a year and a half and it barely has enough functionality to be considered a level editor.  The tutorial seemed like it had promise and the videos seemed cool.  Until you play it and realize every single scene in the video is in the first hour of gameplay.  Then you get to sandbox mode.  A couple buildings and tier 1 units, and of course no storyline, because its sandbox mode. It is missing a lot of basic functionality, the controls are clunky and sensitive, there is very little guidance toward what needs to be done and with the small selection of units it takes a couple hours to play through the entire content available.  Which sums up to a level editor with some basic testing ability.  The early access terms say that it is intended for games a few months from completion so devs can get some help to clear that final hurdle.  This is more like a kickstarter where they haven't done much of anything and want you to pay them to work on it anyway.  I saw this game summer of 2013 and figured I'd wait and see how it progresses, and over a year later I decided to give it a shot.  I cringe to think of what was available last year and I cringe even further to think of the damage this does to the early access program.  I would say you shoud buy this game if you want to support early access, but that won't apply for another two years.  Once the devs get this game to be within 6 months of a decent release, then I would support that statement.  For now I would say stay away until at least 2016.  By then it may be in a beta quality state closing on nearly released.  My prediction is that they jumped the gun on their release on steam, will work on it until the initial profits run out, then release a heartfelt statement on why its the communities fault they cant continue development.  Oh yeah, and I only played a few hours before writing this review because thats the amount of time it took to cover all of the content, and the game became nonresponsive and crashed.  So there's that.  On a final note, if this was one guy working between shifts and on weekends I would be much less critical.  For a full development team working full time, on a commitment to build a product they got people to pay for up front, this is unacceptable progress.

Early Access Review
								I only bought in to the Early Access recently, i missed some of the earlier complaints so i can only speak of the game as it is right now, not how it was 12 months ago.I have to say Folk Tale is looking good. The game is already playable and in the few months i have had it there have been 3 updates, each bringing more options and flesh to the basic engine. This is happening even as the Devs are adding Editing Options and Systems to ease modding.The game as it stands is already playable to a similar degree as say 'Banished' (build your community and survive) but obviously the intention is to go much further and it is by no means polished enough for release as it is. It will be at least another year in Development i would assume.As an Early Access is it doing what it is supposed to do; with regular updates, input from the community and system evolution.If you understand the core concept behind Early Access then it is a recomended 'buy' - if not, 'wait' but put it on your Wish List.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Folk Tale has the potential to be a great game, but it's been an early release for more than a year, begging the question on when, precisely, Games Foundry intends to finish it.  Despite the monthly patches at this point Folk Tale is boring. There is little challenge to it and the one, limited quest that was included in the game was removed during the last patch. It's pure sandbox now, which wouldn't be a problem if it was at all interesting. It's not. What may be worse, however, is Games Foundry's attitude toward customer satisfaction; any criticism or question about when the game will be complete is met with veiled threats that mixed reviews may hamper game completion (despite earlier claims that early release sales have provided enough funds to finish Folk Tale). One gamer was even chided to "focus on the positive" when he questioned when the game will be completed. Doesn't make me want to give them my money. Or recommend anyone else do so.

content:
Posted: March 2
Early Access Review
								Nice little game - I love strategic fantasy games, though I would say this is more tactical than strategic.You control a small number of heroes, to defend your growing town and also to go complete quests, including delving into dungeons and fighting groups of monsters and eventually boss monsters.At the same time, you're improving on your town, managing resources such as food production, training town guards and equipping them. There's a really neat mechanic here, that the hero equipment and the town guard equipment can be moved around, so your heroes can come back from a dungeon with a bunch of loot and use some of it to equip the town guards better. Nice!Currently limited content, as they're still working on it, but there are regular updates and the devs are constantly communicating with the playerbase.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Text book boring. The description and comparisons to other games are atrocious and misleading. This game is a bad warcraft 3 clone (sans map design, production value on heroes, existence of any units at all and even an AI opponent) a slightly upgraded version of warcraft base building (there are some mild production chains and the resources are a bit more Age of Empire like).There is some boring trite dialogue that would humor a 12 year old or someone who finds humor in a rousing "ouch my nutts!" rendition. The hero character designs are brutally text book. There is a campaign that couldn't drag on any slower and a horrible sandbox experiance awaiting those who don't want to plumb there way through some tired hack story with unintresting tropes.Also, you can't pause... because reasons...I am guessing the developer hasn't stopped eating PB&Js with the crust cut off since childhood. This game lacks character, depth and design.The only credit I will give is he doesn't seem to give up on it and is charging 20 bucks for it. And it is a whole lot of boring for 20 bucks.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updating my review since this guy did actually decided to develop this game a little. So I'll eat crow and take back what I said about it being abandonware, but that's about all the praise I can offer. Its being called sandbox but what its really mounting up to be is an objectiveless RTS game. Something along the lines of stronghold only you will question why you're playing it 10-15 minutes in. The maps available so far are just too restrictive to call it a city building game as well. Its not a matter of building what you want where you want. Its more like building where you can and should as though it were an age of empires match only there is no real opponent to defeat. There is a map editor but its daunting enough to use that you might as well learn how to use a game engine and make your own game at that point.You can max cap your economy in like 5 minutes where you're making gold faster than you could ever spend it. Yeah that might get tweaked in the future but that won't make the economy feel any more meaningful, not even on a pet rock level as it is in banished. You can level your military units but there isn't much point in it since there is no real progression or challenge. I only found 1 map that spawns invading enemies with any kind of regularity and even then higher level units don't really benefit you. Unit routing is terrible. Camera controls are also intolerably slow and don't work with the minimap.Sure, you can say that things will change or be added in the future. Lets say all of that is true and wonderful changes and additions come. That would still mean this game might be fun to play 6 years from now as I've mentioned previously at the rate its going.P.S. It says I have 20 hours in it but the vast majority of that was leaving the game run sort of as a screen saver since you can leave a game run for 20 days or more and your village will be doing the same exact thing it was when you left.

content:
Posted: March 20
Early Access Review
								I've owned this game for a LONG time.  It was my first EA game and I've been dying to play it but I've been waiting for launch so I can get the full experience in one go.Lately the game has received a LOT of negative reviews because of how long it's been in EA (though games like Kenshi have been in EA just as long and don't see the negative reviews because of it).  I decided to fire it up today as the game is very far into development and is getting close to release, WOW... WHAT... A... GAME!!!  So far, this game is a perfect 10, I'm having sooooo much fun in it and if I didn't have to go to work tomorrow, I'd probably play it through the night.  Can't wait to pick it up again tomorrow and the best part of it is... I'm still on the tutorial!I seriously don't understand the negative reviews, this game is everything we've ever wanted from an RTS / RPG combo and has definitely been worth the wait.10/10, will buy again... and again... and again... and again...

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								To charge $25 for this game is completely outrageous.I really, really wanted to give this game a shot, but when compared to other early access titles, this game falls dramatically short of what should be acceptable. After doing some research, it seems that this was an early access title before there were standards on what was considered OK.It's a real shame that it took me just more than 2 hours to discover just what sort of poor shape this game was really in after years in development, given the refund policy. Any fan of early-access games on Steam would do well to steer clear of this one. I was pulled in by reviewers that stated things like, "The developer really cares, and really listens."That does seem to be the case, but the results after X years in development speak for themselves. A developer telling me that I have a good idea is not what I wasted my money on. I wasted my money on what I can best describe as an "Early Access Idea."

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, right now, I can't recommend this game. It looks lovely, it's got the kernal of a great idea, it has lots of potential, and a lot of talent has gone into the making of it. But, it's a mile away from being playable. The tutorial has bugs, and crashed before i got to the end of it. The sandbox mode is pointless due to no enemies, no costs and no consequences.But...it could be a very good game. I hope and recommend the developers stick at it, and hope they get it right, because I want to play it when they do.UPDATE: 18 months later...So, firstly, I really appreciate the developers replying to the review, that's a rare thing. It took me a while to get round to giving the game another try. My first impressions were things had made a big leap forward, I wondered was it close to a finished game already?However, I would now argue that the story mode has a couple of hours of gameplay before you complete the quests (which there are about three of). There's still potential in the game, it's still a wierd hybrid of settlers and an RPG, with a playable hero and the ability to build your village.However, as the RPG is short, and the village building still seems frustrating (it follows an "expand till your villagers desert you as you can't keep them happy, then watch new villagers arrive once it's shrunk to a sutainable level, and repat" pattern).I will come back again in another 6 months & see what's progressed. The positive still remains the high level of quality, in the artwork & other elements, and the continued development. It's not a cynical money grab, but I still can't recommend it, other than to those who wish to throw some money the developers way to see what happens next.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Game is horrible.  I wasted money on this before it was complete.  Waited a year.  Now it appears to be done and they fixed none of the major issues.  Slow, boring, annoying interface.  just trying to train a villager as a certain type of worker takes numerous clicks.  Per the game instructions you select a peasant and then right click on a building to train them.  However, when you click on the building if you aren't in the exact right spot, it deselects the peasant.  You have to then find that peasant or another (they wander off), go back and try again (and most likely click on wrong spot again as there appears to be no indicator where to click).  Just bad all around.  FYI, this is first and only review I've ever left.  It was so bad, it drove me to post.

Early Access Review
								[IMPORTANT, READ.]Before i continue on, i have to say that i've been targetted, attacked and Harassed, including disrespected by the Developement team due to my opinions and mine alone. So therefore, i have uninstalled, refunded and sending a complaint to Steam regarding the matter of unfair censorship. I'll just do this since i have a right, like all people, to our entitled views and opinions as long as they don't go against national laws, this, is not and they are in the wrong.[IMPORTANT, READ]So, let's begin.Folk Tale is a game where you build, construct and erect a village of happy people and heroes, where you'll be able to manage the city you make and send your guards and Heroes out to fight for your land.From what i've read from the description of said game, it's been compared to many major franchises, this, i do not believe and is an attempt to grab attention, after all... this is how companies trick you. Gameplay/GraphicsGemplay is very... clunky, a tad off, if not to say, and the graphics are alright for modern-time made game... but Westwood has done it better and i'll have to admit that the Westwood franchise is something they need to draw inspiration from.Issues With my Game:The only issue i encountered was the framerate dying faster than the wrong-people losing confidence on the Jeremy Kyle Show, and i use that term very fixed on. So i had to just refund the game and ship it back off to the company that is so similar to another one that has had a bad concept of money.. Uber Entertainment.So i've uninstalled and refunded, the Developement team are disrespectful, and so i've no reason to be friends with a developement team who only care for money. Uber Entertainment did the same, and they're now a dying company, it'll inevitably happen to this one.Reasons why Westwood is a better game to play than this:-It had a short, but successfull alpha/beta/testing period.-It spans many games of the franchise, from the Western American Frontiers to the Classic Knights and Kings.-It's mechanics are more simple and the graphics are decent for it's creation of when it was made-The developement team never did censor or attack people who had bad opinions, instead truly listened in and took that to their hearts.-They are not Uber Entertainment or the company that made this game. Not in desires, that is.So here is what another following attack on me was:"you have been banned from Folk Tale DiscussionsYou have been banned from Folk Tale Discussions by a Folk Tale developer for your post in "Thinking of buying this": I prefer the Westwod games, so i just refunded and put my review up, got attacked minutes after by dev harassment. I took it down and now reposted it, no trouble so far. I'll just keep doing that incase they copy Uber Ent who made that Planetary Annihilation and decide to attack reviews for no reason. As a community we have rights to hold our opinions, not to be attacked unfairly. i said i don't want their help because i've left the game, then i'm instantly on their attack list. If i get banned for this, then it just supports my claim and just how wrong they are in such strict censorship IDENTICAL to Uber Entertainment.Ban Reason: Don't delete dev replies to reviews when they are trying to support you, then try to necro raise old negative threads. Goodbye.Please review the Discussions Rules and Guidelines.This is a permanent ban."So all-in-all, i have little to say to this game, it does not need, or even worthy of a description that will say to what goods are in it because there are none. Get a Westwood game from Big Fish Games, they're way better. [NOTICE TO ALL WHO WISH TO POST OR COMMENT]I'll be deleting all form of comments to disagree to this, call me hypocrite but i'll simply say this: If you can't take it in, don't give it back.In other words, if the Devs/Community can't take back in with being censored, then they shouldn't censor others then, should they?P.S: This review stands to be my opinion and belief, hating, negative-attacking or in any form of communication to disagree with me is merely the act of a fool's errand, for it's my opinion, my life, and i'll use it as i deem fit.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated review - After almost 4 years of waiting (and still waiting) for what looked like a promising city builder/strategy/rpg game it has been morphed into something that is simply not all that fun for me. I had huge hopes for this game, I so wanted it to succeed but it seems to have failed miserably. They have come too far away from what it was originally supposed to be for me to really like this. Good points - The graphics are nice and the enviroment looks pretty. There is some great humour interjected into it and I love the voice acting. World builder is good. You can build your own world and play around with it. There is modding support. Updates are regular. The devs keep you informed.Bad points - Taking way too long to finish. It isn't what was originally advertised. I can't really get anywhere my hero is overpowered way too easily. There isn't enough functionality, sandbox mode gets boring too quickly. It gets stale as there isn't enough to do, I can't see that there will ever be enough to keep you entertained to be honest. The city building side just isn't enough and the rpg element isn't fun. Updates, even though they are regular, don't really fix many bugs or what is fundamentally wrong. The devs can be childish.If you are into this sort of game then I recommend trying it. Who knows you might like it, it may be just the game for you. But for me its not what I was looking for. I try to like it, I really do. But I am really starting to believe that I have paid £14.99 for a game which is no longer much like the game I originally paid for.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I gave the game another try after a few months. There has been some good progress and they seem to be going in the right direction.Combat has been improved a lot since I last had a look. This was the most noticable improvement.Sandbox works as expected, there are a few features missing. But overall works quite well.Starting out fresh was a little hard at first and I had to restart a few times. This was due to villagers leaving without their needs being met. I think there might need to be a rebalance here. I ended up with a town of around 300 villagers.Campaign looked promising and had some nice voice acting. This is where most people should start out as it is basically a tutorial. Sandbox does not have a tutorial.stuff that I would like to see:* Retink Research, possibly move to a tech tree that has items unlocked when certain building criteria are met?* Balance on carrots (I ran out of these but had 3000 bread)* Workers seem to go to random warehouses, instead of the closest.* I ran out of iron a lot, but this was balanced with buying it from the market and building remote blacksmiths.* Maybe increase the limit of workers for mines/quarries?* Possibly look at adding a better heating element, like coal? * Add some sort of mechanic to increase walkspeed of workers via shoes or roads?* I was running out of pies quickly as well, due to a lack of meat. Maybe add livestock as a farm type?Keep up the good work.

Early Access Review
								About 3 years ago I saw this game and was intrigued, so I bought it. The game really had potential and I really enjoyed the first tutorial. With the fun, comical story, fully voiced cutscenes and everything! I played through the tutorial (which had no save function at that point =P) and eagerly awaited more.Recently remembered this game and thought of giving it a try to see what is has become. And what a surprise that was... What happened? Where is the fun, comical RPG elements that they had used time and effort to include? Voice acting, cutscenes, all that, stripped away for some... Well, whatever it is now anyways...And what is bugging me most of all, which is a game breaker to me... In first alpha, soldiers actually engaged enemies automaticly. Now they attack the first target, and remain idle until they get attacked, even if they are sorrounded by enemies and their friends are being slaughtered... What?Why is this game becoming more like a sad, though colourfull, rippoff of settlers? It had so much interesting when they started 3 years ago... Why did they walk down this path? Now they are just one amongst a gazillion other city building sims. And they are not even a good one at that... So it is a negative from me.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is still highly in development and used to be absolutely terrible, but the developers have in the past 2 years have been extremely dedicated to working on the game. Originally this game was pitched as more like a survival game with and old timey fantasy village that you had to build, grow, and defend. Now the game still has those features and more. With the addition of Ser Gregory, a much diffrent unit from the rest of the villagers, it is now much easier to defend and expand your village. I used to try playing this game and expanding and building a happy little village, and then wolves would attack in the first 5 minutes and all my villagers were so weak they would all die and it would be game over. After 5 minutes...Ser Gregory fixed all that and is really like the super hero of the village. He is so unique in the game that he stands out but feels like he has been in the game this whole time. The developers has really wrapped the game's functionality and even campaign around Ser Gregory's existance. This game has gone from a sad excuse as a strategy survival simulator to a pretty promising game that could potentially make a lot of fans, if it ever is finished that is.Now the game keeps crashing on me but I've been able to dabble. There is no reason for it to crash on me but it is, even on clean install and verified integrity.2 Suggestions: Make SerGregory's field of vision wider than the other villagers. He is supposed to be the main star and problem solver of the game and when I use him to scout out areas and kill enemies it's made much more tedius because of that small field of vision revealing the fog of war. I have to run down narrow pathways 2 or 3 times to reveal it all and it wont even be a thick enough pathway to fit the smallest building in the game and that is very tedious.And also the editor needs a lot of work I think. For example I just want to build a nice large area to build a fancy village and then make the outer rims of the maps a little more fancy maybe, but all you give us to use are very odd shapped and small blocks. Either the editor needs to be made more user friendly by a large margin or you need to give us better blocks or materials to work with so that map creation can be a more common thing.Keep up the good work and hopefully the game will stop crashing on me! :)OLD: Great concept, but the development is way too slow. Feels like it really never will be a finished game and that the developers arent taking it seriously. Each update barely does a thing and it's almost a joke at this point. Hopefully they finish soon because nobody payed money for a game that will never get finishedEdit: You start out with basically no ingots, which you need to make a windmill to train farmers to get any food, and villagers are starving to death by the time you can train a farmer, not to mention you have to focus on food and even on easy mod wolves and♥♥♥♥♥♥run in and since you have only 4 villagers they just kill them (just 2 wolves) and end the game. And when that doesnt happen the game crashes if you zoom out too far and start scrolling. The game may have more content but functionality hasn't been fixed for in game play and the resource system needs tweeked majorly

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 3, 2013
Early Access Review
								Folk tale has been on early access for about 4 years at the time of writing but the game had a semi playable campaign from day 1 which was pretty dam funny. However the devs listened to feedback and completely changed the game so the game I purchased 4 years ago, is not the game I have today. Fortunately I still like it, but thats not always been the case when this happens to early access games. Changing an entire games design based on feedback only ends well if the devs dont take 4 years to finish a game and I warned them of this 3 years ago when the massive changes started. Its always wiser to stick to an achievable goal and work your way up, not aim far higher than you can reach too soon in a companies life. The best games started small and got bigger as the companies that made them grew from game to game. Todays early access devs seem to be trying to go from zero to hero in a single early access release and thats just never going to happen. Its a recipe for failure. I get the impression that Folk Tales Dev team is a realatively small developement team trying to make a treble AAA game and not without some success. But all artists have to learn when to call a product finised and move on. However, there are some things that are wrong with this game that should be fixed before that happens. 1) Having a settlement replace settlers based on happiness is a little shallow, it needs to be more interesting than that. The current system means a simple fire can pretty much ruin a settlement unless the player notices he has to empty all the advanced buildings to to ensure the basic ones are fully manned in order to recover. This means they player is playing the system, not the game. A better idea would be a formula that controls how fast settlers come to the settlement, based on what is in the settlement jobs, empty houses and then gets modified by other factors such as happiness, number of soldiers, about of spare food etc.  This will stop new players games ending with the first settlement fire happiness drops off and nobody wants to come to the village, it just means recruitment takes a lot longer than if the settlement was working correctly. 2) The campaign quest line is not as much fun as the original release of this game on early access, there is a lot of back and forth to the same locations. A lot of Quest giver speaks, and that enables a bad guy model that you must to kill in the same location you just came from. Not good quest writing and I specialise in quest mods, having writen 40+ large quest mods and I can tell you now, go there fight this, is generic and boring from a player perspective. Players like a story that matters, it does not have to be complicated, it does not have to offer lots of multiple choices, though they do like that too. It just has to be interesting and for most it has to be fully voice acted. Voice acting tends to generate a lot of negative comments, even when its done well because players have different opinions on accents and other such things. That said, its absence is always noticed and takes away from the game. The voice work I heard in this game has so far been pretty good for a game of this type. I have liked it so far. Folk Tales early releases understood this, it was interesting, it was funny but during the huge change in game design, that good aspect of the game was lost and I think it should be brought back, bring back the chavie goblins and camp wizards. They made the game IMO.The game it self is fairly simple with some solid game play, looking at it as a 50 year old gamer that saw how small companies because the size of EA making games like this. I think the devs should get this finished quickly, and start making a sequel to hold improvements. This is good business, it means people like me will "if" we like the sound of the sequel buy another game from the devs. Each sequel would mean a step forward for the game, which is has it should be. Many developers have used this to keep updating the same game and they have in my opinion made some of the best games this way.Instead we are locked in an endless cycle of developement here that shows very slow improvements over a long period of time. A risk all on 1 product approach.Would I recommend the product ?Well let me put it this way, if I say I recommend you wait until its finished, your never going to see the game but if I say yes I recommend it, your going to be playing a game with some kinks that still need to be worked out as explained above. So would I recommend it... Honestly, yes, as long as you know this is an endless developement cycle and dont buy it and wait for the game to be finished as I started to do. The games not a bad game, the devs are not bad devs, its just taking a VERY LONG time to make.Remember its only £15, and its pretty good for the price, though my £1 per hour of game play =s games worth means I have not actually gotten my money out of it yet but then again, I have been waiting for the finished game.... and waiting.... and waiting.... and waiting....

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								(Updated at the end)Though "Review" is probably the wrong way to go about this, I'll opine on my thoughts from what I've seen so far.  Having only played the tutorial area mode. (I need to try the recent updates with the partially complete sandbox/builder)  I honestly do see the potential in the game, and I like the idea of where the devs are going with it. Whether or not it ends up being successful depends on what features make it into the final product, and how well those features actually mesh. Right now, there's not enough to go on to really make a "yes get it, or no, stay away" kind of decision. It is very much "wait and see how it develops" at this juncture.In it's current state, I cannot recommend it. But, I would say, do keep an eye on it, and see where it goes. If you're looking for a near-complete playable game experience, stay away. But yeah, the final product could very well be worth waiting for. I am glad to have bought the early access to help support the developers.UPDATE: Nov. 28th, 2016Okay, so, I've given the game a fair amount of time to continue development, and recently came back to give the game another shot, and see what is new. I've only looked at sandbox mode so far, but I do like what I see. Keep in mind, the last time I looked at the game was when it was in its infancy as a tech demo that showed a concept.That said, development has been pretty slow, but I don't really care about development time frames as just about anything can happen in the early stages to severely delay a project. Given the pacing, I think you can expect this game to be in development for some time, but I think at this point the devs are making pretty steady progress.So, do I recommend giving the game a try in it's current state? I do, but with the caveat that I feel the price is just a tad high at $20, and it is still very early access. But maybe my opinion is wrong since I haven't looked at the campaign mode yet, and it sounds like they've fleshed out quite a bit of the first part of the campaign.  Though it was totally unlike Folk Tale, I think Starbound was similarly priced when it was in Early Access, and I did not regret jumping on board with that game. Nor do I regret paying to support the devs with this game.So far in Folk Tale's sandbox, there was a little bit of learning curve, but I did jump right in and skip any tutorials. I was able to figure things out as I went without too much problem. So far, the building construction and placement mechanics have been pretty easy to work with. (I haven't built any walls yet, but all in good time) Everything there seemed pretty straightforward to me. Combat with troops and the hero is pretty straightforward. I haven't really had any "interesting" situations to really test unit AI yet, but as long as they're not dumb as bricks like some RTS games, I think it will turn out okay.By "interesting" situations, I'm thinking of scenarios where enemy units might try to ambush my group of soldiers, or have situations where they try to distract while a second squad tries to flank, or trying to pincer or trap us in a place with little maneuverability. AI is important when it comes to RTS based combat, and having an AI that responds well to various situations is very important. Maybe there will be some of that in the end product, I don't know, and I haven't really kept tabs on the dev discussions along the way. I'm not really expecting a hardcore RTS experience given the flavor of this game, but it would be nice to see some amount of complexity in combat situations, or in raids on your structures, or in dungeons.But yeah, give the game a try, put an hour or so in, and if you can't stand where the progress is right now, refund, and maybe give it another several months to a year.

content:
Posted: April 25
Early Access Review
								I love this game, but I wish it got updated more often.But that isn't all! I also hope that eventually you can set routes for the city watch and spearmen/cavalry, since they just stand where you last left them, staring blankly into a random direction as everything in the village gets mauled by damn spider queens yet again!I love the latest building aspect and style, but the storyline feels worse than what I saw originally. Back then your peasants were running from their lord because they couldn't eat toast. Done, simple, explains why you're there and why you care about the village. Now a hero saves a village and builds it up because the mayor has found a new love for sitting down and refuses to move his fat♥♥♥♥♥♥ There's no reason for you to care about the village besides as an excuse for building up and the eventual spider queen swarm.4/5 for village construction. Yes, it's a village, not a city. Though eventually you may turn it into a bastion of hope against the spider swarms.3/5 for the combat. Hero combat is decent, you have abilities and level them up, plus new gear. But other than that, that's it. No leveling up your guards, no patrolling your guards around so they stop staring into the distance thinking of toast or the inevitable spiders, and no easy way of locating your guards unless I'm blind.1/5 for story. I genuinely don't know why I, the hero, am here. Did I take a fancy to the mayor's daughter? did I want to try running a village and eventually move up to a military garrison? Or was it because building is fun and the story needs to be vaguely there when you aren't dying to spiders?overall: 2.5/5. SPIDERS!!!
